 	 Â 
 feasible	 Â  and	 Â  appropriate.	 Â  	 Â  In	 Â  some	 Â  cases,	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  will	 Â  carry	 Â  out	 Â  various	 Â  policies	 Â  and	 Â

 support	 Â  the	 Â  goal.	 Â  	 Â  Following	 Â  each	 Â  objective	 Â  is	 Â  a	 Â  set	 Â  of	 Â  policies	 Â  and	 Â         how	 Â a	 Â goal	 Â may	 Â be	 Â achieved.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â

                                                                                                                                 Once	 Â  adopted,	 Â  policies	 Â  represent	 Â

                                                                                                                                 City	 Â  to	 Â  help	 Â  achieve	 Â  a	 Â  specified	 Â  goal	 Â

              	 Â 
              	 Â

 	 Â 
 GOAL CI 1                 Create a Circulation Network That Reinforces the Desired
                           Land Use Pattern for Cotati, and Provides for the Safe and
                           Efficient Movement of People and Goods to All Parts of the
                           City
 Objective	 Â CI	 Â 1A	 Â  Maintain	 Â  Safe	 Â  and	 Â  Efficient	 Â  Operating	 Â  Conditions	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  Citywide	 Â 
                            Circulation	 Â Network	 Â 
         Policy	 Â CI	 Â 1.1	 Â  Ensure	 Â  that	 Â  the	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  circulation	 Â  network	 Â  is	 Â  maintained	 Â  and	 Â 
         improved	 Â over	 Â time	 Â to	 Â support	 Â buildout	 Â of	 Â the	 Â General	 Â Plan	 Â in	 Â a	 Â manner	 Â that	 Â is	 Â 
         consistent	 Â with	 Â the	 Â Cityâ€™s	 Â Circulation	 Â Diagram	 Â Figure	 Â 2.1.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
         Policy	 Â CI	 Â 1.2	 Â  Ensure	 Â  that	 Â  the	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  circulation	 Â  network	 Â  is	 Â  a	 Â  well-Â­â€connected	 Â 
         system	 Â  of	 Â  streets,	 Â  roads,	 Â  highways,	 Â  sidewalks,	 Â  and	 Â  bicycle/pedestrian	 Â  paths	 Â 
         that	 Â effectively	 Â accommodates	 Â vehicular	 Â and	 Â non-Â­â€vehicular	 Â traffic	 Â in	 Â a	 Â manner	 Â 
         that	 Â  considers	 Â  the	 Â  context	 Â  of	 Â  surrounding	 Â  land	 Â  uses	 Â  and	 Â  the	 Â  needs	 Â  of	 Â  all	 Â 
         roadway	 Â users.	 Â 
         Policy	 Â CI	 Â 1.3	 Â  Establish	 Â  a	 Â  minimum	 Â  motor	 Â  vehicle	 Â  Level	 Â  of	 Â  Service	 Â  (LOS)	 Â 
         standard	 Â  of	 Â  LOS	 Â  D	 Â  at	 Â  intersections.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  following	 Â  shall	 Â  be	 Â  taken	 Â  into	 Â 
         consideration	 Â in	 Â applying	 Â LOS	 Â standards:	 Â 
                              â€¢   Levels	 Â  of	 Â  service	 Â  shall	 Â  be	 Â  calculated	 Â  using	 Â  the	 Â  average	 Â  hourly	 Â 
                                  delay	 Â for	 Â all	 Â vehicles	 Â entering	 Â the	 Â intersection,	 Â and	 Â assessed	 Â for	 Â 
                                  the	 Â  entire	 Â  peak	 Â  hour	 Â  (60	 Â  minutes)	 Â  rather	 Â  than	 Â  the	 Â  peak	 Â  15-Â­â€
                                  minute	 Â period	 Â (PHF=1.0).	 Â 
                              â€¢   At	 Â  unsignalized	 Â  intersections,	 Â  levels	 Â  of	 Â  service	 Â  shall	 Â  be	 Â 
                                  determined	 Â for	 Â both	 Â controlled	 Â movements	 Â and	 Â for	 Â the	 Â overall	 Â 
                                  intersection.	 Â 	 Â Controlled	 Â movements	 Â operating	 Â at	 Â LOS	 Â E	 Â or	 Â LOS	 Â 
                                  F	 Â are	 Â allowable	 Â if	 Â 1)	 Â the	 Â intersection	 Â is	 Â projected	 Â to	 Â operate	 Â at	 Â 
                                  LOS	 Â C	 Â or	 Â better	 Â overall,	 Â and	 Â 2)	 Â the	 Â projected	 Â traffic	 Â volume	 Â on	 Â 
                                  the	 Â  controlled	 Â  movement	 Â  is	 Â  30	 Â  vehicles	 Â  or	 Â  less	 Â  per	 Â  hour	 Â  on	 Â 
                                  approaches	 Â with	 Â single	 Â lanes,	 Â or	 Â on	 Â multi-Â­â€lane	 Â approaches,	 Â 30	 Â 
                                  vehicles	 Â or	 Â less	 Â per	 Â hour	 Â on	 Â lanes	 Â serving	 Â left	 Â turns	 Â and	 Â through	 Â 
                                  movements.	 Â 
                              â€¢   Level	 Â of	 Â service	 Â standards	 Â shall	 Â not	 Â apply	 Â to	 Â minor	 Â intersections	 Â 
                                  comprised	 Â of	 Â only	 Â local	 Â streets.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
                              â€¢   For	 Â  projects	 Â  within	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  limits	 Â  that	 Â  are	 Â  consistent	 Â  with	 Â  the	 Â 
                                  General	 Â  Plan,	 Â  a	 Â  standard	 Â  of	 Â  LOS	 Â  E	 Â  is	 Â  considered	 Â  to	 Â  be	 Â 
                                  acceptable	 Â  for	 Â  intersections	 Â  within	 Â  the	 Â  boundaries	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â 
                                  Downtown	 Â Specific	 Â Plan.	 Â 
                              â€¢   Intersection	 Â  queuing	 Â  shall	 Â  be	 Â  evaluated	 Â  in	 Â  tandem	 Â  with	 Â  LOS.	 Â 	 Â 
                                  Projected	 Â  95th	 Â  percentile	 Â  queues	 Â  at	 Â  signalized	 Â  intersections	 Â

                   Policy	 Â CI	 Â 1.4	 Â  Intersections	 Â  may	 Â  be	 Â  exempted	 Â  from	 Â  the	 Â  vehicle	 Â  LOS	 Â  and	 Â

2. CIRCULATION
              	 Â 
              Objective	 Â CI	 Â 1B	 Â  Create	 Â a	 Â Street	 Â Network	 Â that	 Â Promotes	 Â Smooth	 Â Traffic	 Â Flow	 Â at	 Â Low	 Â

         emphasizing	 Â  the	 Â  use	 Â  of	 Â  shared	 Â  parking	 Â  wherever	 Â  possible,	 Â  including	 Â  provision	 Â 
         of	 Â multi-Â­â€purpose	 Â parking	 Â lots	 Â that	 Â serve	 Â both	 Â residential	 Â and	 Â commercial	 Â uses.	 Â 
         Policy	 Â CI	 Â 5.2	 Â  Pursue	 Â  the	 Â  formation	 Â  of	 Â  a	 Â  downtown	 Â  parking	 Â  assessment	 Â 
         district	 Â  which	 Â  assembles	 Â  parking	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  rear	 Â  of	 Â  Hub	 Â  businesses	 Â  as	 Â  depicted	 Â  in	 Â 
         the	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â Downtown	 Â Specific	 Â Plan.	 Â 
                          Action	 Â CI	 Â 5a:	 Â  Continue	 Â  to	 Â  work	 Â  with	 Â  downtown	 Â  property	 Â  owners	 Â  to	 Â 
                          facilitate	 Â the	 Â creation	 Â of	 Â parking	 Â assessment	 Â districts.	 Â

                          district	 Â  or	 Â  the	 Â  preservation	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  site	 Â  for	 Â  the	 Â  future	 Â  formation	 Â  of	 Â  an	 Â 
                          assessment	 Â  district	 Â  when	 Â  reviewing	 Â  all	 Â  Hub-Â­â€related	 Â  development	 Â 
                          proposals.	 Â

         efficient	 Â supply	 Â that	 Â is	 Â not	 Â â€œoverparked.â€	 Â 
         Policy	 Â CI	 Â 5.4	 Â  Ensure	 Â  that	 Â  the	 Â  parking	 Â  demand	 Â  associated	 Â  with	 Â  future	 Â

                                  process	 Â  may	 Â  involve	 Â  an	 Â  equivalent	 Â  dwelling	 Â  unit	 Â  (EDU)-Â­â€type	 Â  fee	 Â  and	 Â

                                                              5. CONSERVATION
 	 Â 
 Natural	 Â  resources,	 Â  including	 Â  waterways,	 Â  hillsides,	 Â  and	 Â  wildlife	 Â  habitat,	 Â  and	 Â  historical	 Â

                                                                                                                              5. CONSERVATION
 	 Â 
               Action	 Â CON	 Â 1a:	 Â  Require	 Â  development	 Â  project	 Â  proposals,	 Â  infrastructure	 Â 
               projects,	 Â  long-Â­â€range	 Â  planning	 Â  projects,	 Â  and	 Â  other	 Â  projects	 Â  that	 Â  may	 Â

               submit	 Â  a	 Â  biological	 Â  resources	 Â  evaluation	 Â  which	 Â  determines	 Â  whether	 Â 
               significant	 Â  adverse	 Â  impacts	 Â  will	 Â  occur.	 Â  Evaluations	 Â  shall	 Â  be	 Â  carried	 Â  out	 Â 
               under	 Â  the	 Â  direction	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  Community	 Â  Development	 Â  Department	 Â  and	 Â 
               consistent	 Â  with	 Â  applicable	 Â  state	 Â  and	 Â  federal	 Â  guidelines.	 Â  	 Â  Projects	 Â  shall	 Â 
               be	 Â  designed	 Â  to	 Â  avoid	 Â  or	 Â  reduce	 Â  impacts	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  maximum	 Â  extent	 Â 
               feasible.	 Â Where	 Â adverse	 Â impacts	 Â cannot	 Â be	 Â feasibly	 Â reduced	 Â or	 Â avoided	 Â 
               through	 Â  project	 Â  design,	 Â  projects	 Â  shall	 Â  include	 Â  the	 Â  implementation	 Â  of	 Â 
               site-Â­â€specific	 Â or	 Â project-Â­â€specific	 Â effective	 Â mitigation	 Â strategies	 Â developed	 Â 
               by	 Â a	 Â qualified	 Â professional	 Â in	 Â consultation	 Â with	 Â state	 Â or	 Â federal	 Â resource	 Â 
               agencies	 Â  with	 Â  jurisdiction	 Â  (if	 Â  applicable)	 Â  that	 Â  may	 Â  include,	 Â  but	 Â  are	 Â  not	 Â 
               limited	 Â to,	 Â the	 Â following	 Â strategies:	 Â 	 Â 
               a. Preservation	 Â  of	 Â  habitat	 Â  and	 Â  connectivity	 Â  of	 Â  adequate	 Â  size,	 Â  quality,	 Â 
                      and	 Â  configuration	 Â  to	 Â  support	 Â  the	 Â  special-Â­â€status	 Â  species.	 Â 
                      Connectivity	 Â  shall	 Â  be	 Â  determined	 Â  based	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  specifics	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â 
                      species'	 Â needs.	 Â

               e. Provision	 Â of	 Â replacement	 Â habitat	 Â of	 Â like	 Â quantity	 Â and	 Â quality	 Â on-Â­â€	 Â or	 Â 
                      off-Â­â€site	 Â  for	 Â  special-Â­â€status	 Â  species.	 Â  Preference	 Â  shall	 Â  be	 Â  given	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â

         source	 Â  toxic	 Â  air	 Â  contaminant	 Â  health	 Â  risks.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  analysis,	 Â  if	 Â  necessary,	 Â  shall	 Â

               1. Design	 Â  styles,	 Â  age	 Â  of	 Â  home,	 Â  and	 Â  other	 Â  criteria	 Â  to	 Â  determine	 Â

               Policy	 Â EV	 Â 2.4:	 Â 	 Â Continue	 Â to	 Â encourage	 Â and	 Â support	 Â community	 Â festivals	 Â (such	 Â as	 Â 
               jazz	 Â concerts,	 Â art	 Â shows,	 Â craft	 Â fairs,	 Â and	 Â energy	 Â forums)	 Â in	 Â La	 Â Plaza	 Â Park.	 Â 
               Policy	 Â EV	 Â 2.5:	 Â Encourage	 Â a	 Â concentration	 Â of	 Â public	 Â art	 Â within	 Â the	 Â Hub.	 Â 
               Policy	 Â  EV	 Â  2.6:	 Â  	 Â  Encourage	 Â  the	 Â  conservation	 Â  and/or	 Â  restoration	 Â  of	 Â  existing	 Â 
               structures	 Â with	 Â recognized	 Â historical	 Â value.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
                           Action	 Â EV	 Â 2a:	 Â  Pursue	 Â  funding	 Â  sources,	 Â  as	 Â  they	 Â  become	 Â  available,	 Â  to	 Â 
                           implement	 Â  the	 Â  public	 Â  improvements	 Â  and	 Â  infrastructure	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â 
                           Downtown	 Â Specific	 Â Plan.	 Â 
                           Action	 Â EV	 Â 2b:	 Â 	 Â  Continue	 Â  to	 Â  work	 Â  with	 Â  the	 Â  Chamber	 Â  of	 Â  Commerce	 Â  to	 Â 
                           devise	 Â  plans	 Â  to	 Â  promote	 Â  various	 Â  festivals	 Â  and	 Â  community	 Â  events	 Â  that	 Â 
                           are	 Â unique	 Â to	 Â Cotati.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â La	 Â Plaza	 Â Park	 Â or	 Â the	 Â inner	 Â Hub	 Â area	 Â shall	 Â be	 Â

 	 Â 
 GOAL LU 1                Establish an Efficient, Harmonious, and Environmentally
                          Sensitive Land Use Pattern That Enhances Cotatiâ€™s Small
                          Town Character, Provides Adequate Space to Accommodate
                          Sustainable Economic and Housing Growth, and Encourages
                          Orderly Growth
 Objective	 Â LU	 Â 1A	 Â  Provide	 Â a	 Â Balanced	 Â Mix	 Â of	 Â Land	 Â Uses	 Â that	 Â Reflect	 Â the	 Â Needs	 Â of	 Â City	 Â 
                           Residents	 Â and	 Â Businesses	 Â 
         Policy	 Â LU	 Â 1.1:	 Â  Maintain	 Â  a	 Â  supply	 Â  of	 Â  developable	 Â  mixed-Â­â€use,	 Â  commercial,	 Â 
         industrial,	 Â  and	 Â  residential	 Â  lands	 Â  sufficient	 Â  to	 Â  meet	 Â  desired	 Â  growth	 Â  and	 Â 
         economic	 Â needs	 Â over	 Â the	 Â planning	 Â period.	 Â 
         Policy	 Â LU	 Â 1.2:	 Â 	 Â  Assign	 Â  the	 Â  following	 Â  range	 Â  of	 Â  land	 Â  use	 Â  designations	 Â  throughout	 Â 
         the	 Â  City	 Â  and	 Â  to	 Â  parcels	 Â  within	 Â  the	 Â  Urban	 Â  Growth	 Â  Boundary,	 Â  as	 Â  shown	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â 
         Land	 Â Use	 Â Map	 Â (Figure	 Â 7.1):	 Â 
         AGRICULTURAL	 Â  (A)	 Â  â€“	 Â  The	 Â  Agricultural	 Â  land	 Â  use	 Â  designation	 Â  identifies	 Â  	 Â  rural,	 Â 
         agricultural	 Â areas	 Â intended	 Â to	 Â serve	 Â as	 Â a	 Â buffer	 Â and	 Â community	 Â separator.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â 
         A	 Â designation	 Â provides	 Â for	 Â very	 Â low	 Â densities	 Â of	 Â residential	 Â development,	 Â small	 Â 
         acreage	 Â  intensive	 Â  farming,	 Â  commercial	 Â  uses	 Â  that	 Â  directly	 Â  support	 Â  agricultural	 Â 
         operations,	 Â  and	 Â  part-Â­â€time	 Â  farming.	 Â  	 Â  Densities	 Â  up	 Â  to	 Â  one	 Â  dwelling	 Â  unit	 Â  per	 Â  five	 Â 
         acres	 Â are	 Â allowed	 Â in	 Â the	 Â A	 Â designation,	 Â with	 Â site	 Â coverage	 Â of	 Â up	 Â to	 Â 10	 Â percent.	 Â 
         RURAL	 Â RESIDENTIAL	 Â (RR)	 Â -Â­â€	 Â The	 Â Rural	 Â Residential	 Â land	 Â use	 Â designation	 Â identifies	 Â 
         areas	 Â  with	 Â  limited	 Â  variety	 Â  of	 Â  agricultural	 Â  and	 Â  rural	 Â  uses,	 Â  primarily	 Â  along	 Â  the	 Â 
         southern	 Â and	 Â western	 Â city	 Â borders.	 Â The	 Â RR	 Â designation	 Â allows	 Â agricultural	 Â uses	 Â 
         such	 Â as	 Â orchards,	 Â vineyards,	 Â and	 Â grazing	 Â as	 Â well	 Â as	 Â low-Â­â€density	 Â residential	 Â and	 Â 
         associated	 Â neighborhood	 Â retail	 Â uses,	 Â where	 Â development	 Â and	 Â agricultural	 Â uses	 Â 
         maintain	 Â  existing	 Â  natural	 Â  vegetation	 Â  and	 Â  topography	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  maximum	 Â  extent	 Â 
         feasible.	 Â  Densities	 Â  up	 Â  to	 Â  one	 Â  dwelling	 Â  unit	 Â  per	 Â  acre	 Â  are	 Â  allowed	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  RR	 Â 
         designation,	 Â with	 Â site	 Â coverage	 Â of	 Â up	 Â to	 Â 15	 Â percent.	 Â 
         LOW	 Â  DENSITY	 Â  RESIDENTIAL	 Â  (LDR)	 Â  â€“	 Â  The	 Â  Low	 Â  Density	 Â  Residential	 Â  designation	 Â 
         allows	 Â  single	 Â  family	 Â  residential	 Â  attached	 Â  or	 Â  detached	 Â  homes	 Â  and	 Â  associated	 Â 
         neighborhood	 Â retail	 Â uses.	 Â Densities	 Â of	 Â two	 Â dwelling	 Â units	 Â per	 Â acre	 Â are	 Â allowed	 Â 
         in	 Â the	 Â LDR	 Â designation,	 Â with	 Â site	 Â coverage	 Â of	 Â up	 Â to	 Â 40	 Â percent.	 Â 
         LOW-Â­â€MEDIUM	 Â  DENSITY	 Â  RESIDENTIAL	 Â  	 Â  (LMDR)	 Â  -Â­â€	 Â  The	 Â  Low-Â­â€Medium	 Â  Density	 Â 
         Residential	 Â  designation	 Â  allows	 Â  single	 Â  family	 Â  attached	 Â  and	 Â  detached	 Â  units,	 Â

         per	 Â  acre	 Â  are	 Â  allowed	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  LMDR	 Â  designation,	 Â  with	 Â  site	 Â  coverage	 Â  of	 Â  up	 Â  to	 Â  45	 Â

                 PUBLIC	 Â  FACILITIES	 Â  (PF)	 Â  -Â­â€	 Â  The	 Â  Public	 Â  Facilities	 Â  designation	 Â  applies	 Â  to	 Â  land	 Â  areas	 Â

      LU-1: General Plan Land Use Designation and Zoning District Compatibility

            affect	 Â  the	 Â  City.	 Â  	 Â  Therefore,	 Â  cooperative	 Â  planning	 Â  among	 Â  jurisdictions	 Â  is	 Â  important	 Â  to	 Â

                                                                                                                                               7. LAND USE
 	 Â 
                   Boundary	 Â if	 Â it	 Â finds	 Â that	 Â such	 Â amendment	 Â is	 Â necessary	 Â for	 Â the	 Â development	 Â 
                   of	 Â a	 Â public	 Â park,	 Â public	 Â school,	 Â public	 Â facility,	 Â or	 Â public	 Â open	 Â space	 Â project,	 Â 
                   and	 Â  such	 Â amendment	 Â is	 Â otherwise	 Â consistent	 Â with	 Â the	 Â General	 Â Plan	 Â then	 Â in	 Â 
                   effect.	 Â 
        d.	 Â  To	 Â  promote	 Â  the	 Â  public	 Â  health,	 Â  safety,	 Â  and	 Â  welfare,	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  Council	 Â  may,	 Â  by	 Â 
                   the	 Â affirmative	 Â vote	 Â of	 Â a	 Â majority	 Â of	 Â the	 Â Council,	 Â amend	 Â the	 Â Urban	 Â Growth	 Â 
                   Boundary	 Â if	 Â they	 Â make	 Â each	 Â of	 Â the	 Â following	 Â findings:	 Â 
                   1. The	 Â amendment	 Â is	 Â the	 Â only	 Â feasible	 Â method	 Â of	 Â addressing	 Â a	 Â significant	 Â

                   2. The	 Â amendment	 Â would	 Â not	 Â provide	 Â for	 Â new	 Â development;	 Â and	 Â 
                   3. The	 Â  amendment	 Â  only	 Â  involves	 Â  developed	 Â  or	 Â  substantially	 Â  developed	 Â 
                           lands.	 Â 
        e.	 Â  The	 Â City	 Â Council	 Â may,	 Â by	 Â the	 Â affirmative	 Â vote	 Â of	 Â a	 Â majority	 Â of	 Â the	 Â Council,	 Â 
                   exempt	 Â  projects	 Â  that	 Â  have	 Â  a	 Â  vested	 Â  right	 Â  under	 Â  law	 Â  to	 Â  proceed	 Â  with	 Â 
                   development,	 Â if	 Â the	 Â Council	 Â determines	 Â that	 Â the	 Â exemption	 Â is	 Â necessary	 Â for	 Â 
                   the	 Â project	 Â to	 Â proceed	 Â consistent	 Â with	 Â that	 Â vested	 Â right.	 Â 
        Policy	 Â LU	 Â 1.8:	 Â 	 Â The	 Â Urban	 Â Growth	 Â Boundary	 Â is	 Â established.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â Urban	 Â Growth	 Â 
        Boundary	 Â  is	 Â  generally	 Â  coterminous	 Â  with	 Â  the	 Â  Sphere	 Â  of	 Â  Influence	 Â  boundary	 Â  as	 Â 
        set	 Â forth	 Â in	 Â the	 Â Land	 Â Use	 Â Map,	 Â Figure	 Â LU	 Â 7.1.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â Land	 Â Use	 Â Map	 Â shall	 Â represent	 Â 
        the	 Â limit	 Â for	 Â the	 Â ultimate	 Â expansion	 Â of	 Â urban	 Â services	 Â and	 Â urban	 Â development.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
        i.	 Â 	 Â  The	 Â Urban	 Â Growth	 Â Boundary	 Â shall	 Â remain	 Â in	 Â effect	 Â during	 Â the	 Â 20-Â­â€year	 Â time-Â­â€
                   frame	 Â of	 Â the	 Â General	 Â Plan.	 Â

                                                                                       8. NOISE
 	 Â 
 The	 Â Noise	 Â Element	 Â is	 Â a	 Â mandatory	 Â component	 Â of	 Â the	 Â General	 Â Plan.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â overall	 Â purpose	 Â

                                                                                                                                            4. Community Services &

8. NOISE
         	 Â 
         GOAL N 1                  Create a Pleasant Sound Environment by Minimizing
                                   Exposure to Harmful and Annoying Noise
         Objective	 Â N	 Â 1A	 Â        Minimize	 Â Noise	 Â Levels	 Â to	 Â Enhance	 Â the	 Â Quality	 Â of	 Â Existing	 Â and	 Â Future	 Â 
                                        Land	 Â Uses	 Â 
                 Policy	 Â N	 Â 1.1:	 Â  Ensure	 Â the	 Â noise	 Â compatibility	 Â of	 Â existing	 Â and	 Â future	 Â uses	 Â when	 Â 
                 making	 Â land	 Â use	 Â planning	 Â decisions.	 Â 
                 Policy	 Â N	 Â 1.2:	 Â  Require	 Â  development	 Â  and	 Â  infrastructure	 Â  projects	 Â  to	 Â  be	 Â 
                 consistent	 Â  with	 Â  the	 Â  Land	 Â  Use	 Â  Compatibility	 Â  for	 Â  Community	 Â  Noise	 Â  Environments	 Â 
                 standards	 Â  indicated	 Â  in	 Â  Table	 Â  N-Â­â€1	 Â  to	 Â  ensure	 Â  acceptable	 Â  noise	 Â  levels	 Â  at	 Â  existing	 Â 
                 and	 Â future	 Â uses.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
                 Policy	 Â N	 Â 1.3:	 Â  Require	 Â development	 Â to	 Â mitigate	 Â excessive	 Â noise	 Â through	 Â best	 Â

 items.	 Â 
 For	 Â each	 Â of	 Â the	 Â actions	 Â listed	 Â below,	 Â the	 Â letters	 Â â€œAâ€	 Â or	 Â â€œBâ€	 Â refer	 Â to	 Â a	 Â relative	 Â priority	 Â for	 Â 
 implementation.	 Â  More	 Â  specifically,	 Â  the	 Â  letter	 Â  A	 Â  implies	 Â  that	 Â  the	 Â  action	 Â  will	 Â  be	 Â 
 implemented	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  relatively	 Â  short-Â­â€term	 Â  (most	 Â  likely,	 Â  1	 Â  to	 Â  5	 Â  years).	 Â  The	 Â  letter	 Â  B	 Â 
 similarly	 Â implies	 Â a	 Â somewhat	 Â longer-Â­â€term	 Â implementation,	 Â approximately	 Â 5	 Â to	 Â 10	 Â years.	 Â 
 In	 Â  other	 Â  cases,	 Â  the	 Â  reader	 Â  may	 Â  notice	 Â  the	 Â  use	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  term	 Â  "ongoing"	 Â  which	 Â  refers	 Â  to	 Â 
 actions	 Â already	 Â being	 Â undertaken	 Â by	 Â the	 Â City	 Â or	 Â those	 Â that	 Â are	 Â expected	 Â to	 Â continue	 Â on	 Â 
 either	 Â a	 Â periodic	 Â or	 Â perpetual	 Â basis.	 Â The	 Â party	 Â or	 Â parties	 Â that	 Â are	 Â primarily	 Â responsible	 Â 
 for	 Â implementing	 Â each	 Â action	 Â are	 Â also	 Â indicated	 Â where	 Â applicable.	 Â 	 Â 
 The	 Â reader	 Â should	 Â keep	 Â some	 Â caveats	 Â in	 Â mind	 Â regarding	 Â the	 Â implementation	 Â schedule.	 Â 
 One	 Â  is	 Â  that	 Â  many	 Â  of	 Â  these	 Â  actions	 Â  will	 Â  require	 Â  both	 Â  staff	 Â  and	 Â  financial	 Â  resources	 Â  to	 Â 
 implement,	 Â thus	 Â making	 Â them	 Â difficult	 Â to	 Â definitively	 Â schedule,	 Â given	 Â the	 Â annual	 Â nature	 Â 
 of	 Â  the	 Â  budgetary	 Â  process	 Â  and	 Â  changing	 Â  priorities	 Â  over	 Â  the	 Â  years.	 Â  A	 Â  second	 Â  caveat	 Â  to	 Â 
 keep	 Â in	 Â mind	 Â is	 Â that	 Â it	 Â is	 Â often	 Â difficult	 Â to	 Â clearly	 Â state	 Â the	 Â duration	 Â of	 Â tasks;	 Â therefore,	 Â 
 estimated	 Â  starting	 Â  dates	 Â  (priority	 Â  levels)	 Â  are	 Â  presented	 Â  for	 Â  actions	 Â  rather	 Â  than	 Â 
 completion	 Â  dates.	 Â  A	 Â  third	 Â  caveat	 Â  is	 Â  that,	 Â  in	 Â  some	 Â  instances,	 Â  the	 Â  selection	 Â  of	 Â  priority	 Â 
 level	 Â  (A	 Â  or	 Â  B)	 Â  reflects	 Â  the	 Â  level	 Â  of	 Â  complexity	 Â  and	 Â  the	 Â  level	 Â  of	 Â  effort	 Â  required	 Â  to	 Â 
 implement	 Â an	 Â action	 Â rather	 Â than	 Â the	 Â importance	 Â of	 Â the	 Â Action	 Â itself.	 Â

priority	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  highest	 Â  order."	 Â  	 Â  Broad	 Â  based	 Â  community	 Â  participation	 Â  is	 Â  essential	 Â  to	 Â  preparing	 Â  an	 Â

       â€¢    Housing	 Â  Element.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  Housing	 Â  Element	 Â  is	 Â  a	 Â  stand-Â­â€alone	 Â  policy	 Â  document,	 Â  supported	 Â  by	 Â  the	 Â

H O U S IN G 	 Â  P L A N : 	 Â 	 Â  G O A L S , 	 Â  P O L IC IE S 	 Â A N D 	 Â  P R O G R A M S 	 Â 
This	 Â section	 Â describes	 Â housing	 Â goals,	 Â policies	 Â and	 Â programs	 Â for	 Â the	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati.	 Â 	 Â A	 Â goal	 Â is	 Â defined	 Â as	 Â a	 Â 
general	 Â  statement	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  highest	 Â  aspirations	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  community.	 Â  	 Â  A	 Â  policy	 Â  is	 Â  a	 Â  course	 Â  of	 Â  action	 Â  chosen	 Â 
from	 Â  among	 Â  many	 Â  possible	 Â  alternatives.	 Â  	 Â  It	 Â  guides	 Â  decision-Â­â€making	 Â  and	 Â  provides	 Â  a	 Â  framework	 Â  around	 Â 
which	 Â the	 Â housing	 Â programs	 Â operate.	 Â 	 Â A	 Â program	 Â is	 Â a	 Â specific	 Â action,	 Â which	 Â implements	 Â the	 Â policy	 Â and	 Â 
moves	 Â the	 Â community	 Â toward	 Â the	 Â achievement	 Â of	 Â its	 Â goals.	 Â 	 Â Programs	 Â are	 Â a	 Â part	 Â of	 Â the	 Â Cityâ€™s	 Â action	 Â plan	 Â 
and	 Â constitute	 Â the	 Â Cityâ€™s	 Â local	 Â housing	 Â strategy.	 Â 
State	 Â Housing	 Â Goals	 Â 
According	 Â to	 Â the	 Â California	 Â Statewide	 Â Housing	 Â Plan	 Â Update,	 Â it	 Â is	 Â the	 Â goal	 Â of	 Â the	 Â state	 Â to	 Â â€œensure	 Â to	 Â all	 Â 
Californians	 Â  the	 Â  opportunity	 Â  to	 Â  obtain	 Â  safe,	 Â  adequate	 Â  housing	 Â  in	 Â  a	 Â  suitable	 Â  living	 Â  environment.â€	 Â 	 Â 
Additionally,	 Â  the	 Â  State	 Â  Department	 Â  of	 Â  Housing	 Â  and	 Â  Community	 Â  Development	 Â  has	 Â  established	 Â  the	 Â 
following	 Â four	 Â primary	 Â goals:	 Â 
         â€¢      Provision	 Â of	 Â new	 Â housing;	 Â 
         â€¢      Preservation	 Â of	 Â existing	 Â housing	 Â and	 Â neighborhoods;	 Â 
         â€¢      Reduction	 Â of	 Â housing	 Â costs;	 Â and,	 Â 
         â€¢      Improvement	 Â of	 Â housing	 Â conditions	 Â for	 Â special	 Â needs	 Â groups.	 Â 
Housing	 Â Element	 Â Goals,	 Â Policies	 Â and	 Â Programs	 Â

Housing	 Â Plan	 Â was	 Â developed	 Â to	 Â be	 Â consistent	 Â with	 Â its	 Â General	 Â Plan	 Â and	 Â the	 Â community	 Â input	 Â received	 Â 
for	 Â  the	 Â  General	 Â  Plan	 Â  update	 Â  that	 Â  is	 Â  underway.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  goals	 Â  of	 Â  this	 Â  Housing	 Â  Element	 Â  serve	 Â  at	 Â  the	 Â  local	 Â  level	 Â 
to	 Â enhance	 Â and	 Â build	 Â upon	 Â State	 Â of	 Â California	 Â goals	 Â for	 Â providing	 Â safe,	 Â decent,	 Â and	 Â affordable	 Â housing	 Â 
available	 Â  for	 Â  all	 Â  City	 Â  residents.	 Â  	 Â  These	 Â  goals	 Â  encompass	 Â  new	 Â  construction,	 Â  conservation	 Â  of	 Â  existing	 Â  stock,	 Â 
affordability	 Â and	 Â provision	 Â of	 Â adequate	 Â housing	 Â for	 Â all	 Â persons.	 Â 
Policies	 Â  and	 Â  programs	 Â  from	 Â  the	 Â  2012	 Â  Housing	 Â  Element	 Â  have	 Â  been	 Â  incorporated	 Â  herein	 Â  or	 Â  updated,	 Â 
otherwise	 Â modified,	 Â or	 Â deleted	 Â as	 Â deemed	 Â appropriate.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â funding	 Â source	 Â for	 Â all	 Â programs	 Â is	 Â the	 Â Cityâ€™s	 Â 
General	 Â Fund,	 Â unless	 Â otherwise	 Â noted.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â Community	 Â Development	 Â Department	 Â is	 Â the	 Â primary	 Â party	 Â 
responsible	 Â for	 Â implementation	 Â of	 Â the	 Â Housing	 Â Element	 Â programs.	 Â 	 Â Where	 Â programs	 Â require	 Â City	 Â Council	 Â 
approval,	 Â such	 Â as	 Â amendments	 Â to	 Â the	 Â Land	 Â Use	 Â Code,	 Â the	 Â City	 Â Council	 Â is	 Â also	 Â an	 Â entity	 Â responsible	 Â for	 Â 
implementation.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  timeframe	 Â  for	 Â  each	 Â  program	 Â  identifies	 Â  the	 Â  time	 Â  for	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  to	 Â  take	 Â  the	 Â  actions	 Â 
described	 Â in	 Â the	 Â program.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
       3	 Â       Housing	 Â Element	 Â |	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â

                      HOUSING	 Â ELEMENT	 Â                                                                               	 Â

Goal H-1                       Conserve and improve the existing housing stock to provide adequate, safe,
                               and decent housing for all Cotati residents
Goal H-2                       Provide adequate sites to accommodate the housing needs of all economic
                               segments of the community
Goal H-3                       Expand affordable housing opportunities for lower income households and
                               persons with special housing needs, including seniors, disabled persons,
                               large households, and homeless persons and families
Goal H-4                       Promote housing opportunities for all persons regardless of race, gender,
                               age, marital status, ancestry, national origin, color, or sexual orientation
Goal H-5                       Promote energy efficiency and conservation in residential development
Goal H-6                       Ensure public participation in the development of the Cityâ€™s housing
                               policies
For	 Â each	 Â goal,	 Â a	 Â set	 Â of	 Â policies	 Â and	 Â implementation	 Â programs	 Â is	 Â provided	 Â to	 Â assist	 Â the	 Â City	 Â in	 Â attaining	 Â 
the	 Â goal.	 Â 	 Â Each	 Â implementation	 Â program	 Â contains	 Â the	 Â following	 Â information:	 Â 
       â€¢   A	 Â concise	 Â statement	 Â of	 Â the	 Â specific	 Â City	 Â actions	 Â that	 Â will	 Â be	 Â taken	 Â to	 Â implement	 Â the	 Â program.	 Â 	 Â 
       â€¢   Funding	 Â source.	 Â 
       â€¢   The	 Â City	 Â department	 Â or	 Â other	 Â agency	 Â responsible	 Â for	 Â implementation.	 Â 	 Â 
       â€¢   Schedule	 Â for	 Â completion.	 Â 
The	 Â expected	 Â results	 Â of	 Â each	 Â program	 Â are	 Â summarized	 Â as	 Â quantified	 Â objectives	 Â in	 Â Tables	 Â 1	 Â and	 Â 2.	 Â 	 Â

                             Provide Adequate, Safe, and Decent Housing for all Cotati
                             Residents

Overcrowded	 Â Households	 Â

        SOURCE:	 Â 	 Â DE	 Â NOVO	 Â PLANNING	 Â GROUP,	 Â 2015	 Â 
   OVERPAYMENT	 Â 
   Overpayment	 Â compares	 Â the	 Â total	 Â housing	 Â cost	 Â for	 Â a	 Â household	 Â to	 Â the	 Â ability	 Â of	 Â that	 Â household	 Â to	 Â pay.	 Â 	 Â 
   Overpayment	 Â  is	 Â  specifically	 Â  defined	 Â  as	 Â  monthly	 Â  shelter	 Â  costs	 Â  in	 Â  excess	 Â  of	 Â  30	 Â  percent	 Â  of	 Â  a	 Â  householdâ€™s	 Â 
   income.	 Â  	 Â  Shelter	 Â  cost	 Â  is	 Â  defined	 Â  as	 Â  the	 Â  monthly	 Â  owner	 Â  costs	 Â  (mortgages,	 Â  deed	 Â  of	 Â  trust,	 Â  contracts	 Â  to	 Â 
   purchase	 Â  or	 Â  similar	 Â  debts	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  property	 Â  and	 Â  taxes,	 Â  insurance	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  property,	 Â  and	 Â  utilities)	 Â  or	 Â  the	 Â 
   gross	 Â rent	 Â (contract	 Â rent	 Â plus	 Â the	 Â estimated	 Â average	 Â monthly	 Â cost	 Â of	 Â utilities).	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
   According	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  2007-Â­â€2011	 Â  ACS,	 Â  48.6	 Â  percent	 Â  of	 Â  owner	 Â  households	 Â  and	 Â  42.1	 Â  percent	 Â  of	 Â  renter	 Â 
   households	 Â are	 Â overpaying	 Â for	 Â housing,	 Â which	 Â is	 Â considered	 Â paying	 Â in	 Â excess	 Â of	 Â 30	 Â percent	 Â of	 Â household	 Â 
   income	 Â  toward	 Â  housing	 Â  costs.	 Â  	 Â  Lower	 Â  income	 Â  households	 Â  have	 Â  much	 Â  higher	 Â  overpayment	 Â  rates	 Â  than	 Â 
   moderate	 Â and	 Â above	 Â moderate	 Â income	 Â households.	 Â 	 Â Extremely	 Â low	 Â income	 Â households,	 Â those	 Â earning	 Â 
   up	 Â  to	 Â  30	 Â  percent	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  area	 Â  median	 Â  income	 Â  (AMI),	 Â  overpay	 Â  at	 Â  the	 Â  highest	 Â  rate,	 Â  with	 Â  90	 Â  percent	 Â  of	 Â 
   renters	 Â overpaying	 Â and	 Â 83	 Â percent	 Â of	 Â owners	 Â overpaying.	 Â 	 Â Extremely	 Â low	 Â income	 Â households	 Â also	 Â have	 Â 
   the	 Â highest	 Â rate	 Â of	 Â extreme	 Â overpayment,	 Â with	 Â almost	 Â 76	 Â percent	 Â of	 Â extremely	 Â low	 Â income	 Â households	 Â 
   paying	 Â  more	 Â  than	 Â  50	 Â  percent	 Â  of	 Â  their	 Â  income	 Â  to	 Â  housing	 Â  costs.	 Â  	 Â Of	 Â  the	 Â  325	 Â  very	 Â  low	 Â  income	 Â  households,	 Â 
   almost	 Â  82	 Â  percent	 Â  overpay	 Â  for	 Â  housing.	 Â  In	 Â  the	 Â  low	 Â  and	 Â  moderate/above	 Â  moderate	 Â  income	 Â  groups,	 Â  a	 Â 
   higher	 Â percentage	 Â of	 Â owner	 Â households	 Â overpays	 Â compared	 Â to	 Â renter	 Â households.	 Â Table	 Â 1-Â­â€28	 Â identifies	 Â 
   overpayment	 Â by	 Â income	 Â group	 Â and	 Â tenure,	 Â illustrating	 Â that	 Â those	 Â households	 Â in	 Â the	 Â extremely	 Â low	 Â and	 Â 
   very	 Â low	 Â income	 Â categories	 Â are	 Â those	 Â that	 Â overpay	 Â the	 Â most.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â

	 Â 
J O B S -Â­â€H O U S IN G 	 Â 
The	 Â  jobs-Â­â€housing	 Â  balance	 Â  is	 Â  a	 Â  meaningful	 Â  way	 Â                                  TABLE	 Â 1-Â­29:	 Â 	 Â JOBS-Â­HOUSING	 Â BALANCE
to	 Â  gain	 Â  a	 Â  sense	 Â  of	 Â  how	 Â  many	 Â  people	 Â  will	 Â 
commute	 Â  to	 Â  work	 Â  and	 Â  how	 Â  far	 Â  they	 Â  will	 Â  have	 Â  to	 Â                               	 Â                      2000	 Â              2010	 Â 
commute.	 Â The	 Â jobs/housing	 Â balance	 Â is	 Â the	 Â ratio	 Â  Cotati	 Â                                                              0.98	 Â              0.77	 Â 
of	 Â  jobs	 Â  in	 Â  a	 Â  jurisdiction	 Â  compared	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â                          SOURCE:	 Â 	 Â DE	 Â NOVO	 Â PLANNING	 Â GROUP,	 Â 2011	 Â 
number	 Â  of	 Â  housing	 Â  units	 Â  in	 Â  that	 Â  jurisdiction.	 Â  If	 Â 
the	 Â ratio	 Â is	 Â less	 Â than	 Â one,	 Â then	 Â the	 Â jurisdiction	 Â is	 Â likely	 Â to	 Â export	 Â workers.	 Â A	 Â perfect	 Â jobs/housing	 Â ratio	 Â 
would	 Â be	 Â the	 Â number	 Â of	 Â employed	 Â households	 Â working	 Â within	 Â a	 Â town	 Â equal	 Â to	 Â the	 Â number	 Â of	 Â housing	 Â 
units	 Â in	 Â that	 Â town.	 Â However,	 Â there	 Â is	 Â no	 Â perfect	 Â scenario	 Â for	 Â a	 Â jurisdiction	 Â and	 Â what	 Â works	 Â in	 Â one	 Â area	 Â 
may	 Â not	 Â work	 Â in	 Â another.	 Â 	 Â An	 Â unbalanced	 Â jobs-Â­â€housing	 Â ratio	 Â implies	 Â employees	 Â will	 Â be	 Â spending	 Â more	 Â 
time	 Â  on	 Â  roadways	 Â  that	 Â  may	 Â  be	 Â  better	 Â  spent	 Â  with	 Â  their	 Â  families,	 Â  at	 Â  work,	 Â  or	 Â  recreationally.	 Â  If	 Â  the	 Â 
jobs/housing	 Â ratio	 Â is	 Â less	 Â than	 Â one,	 Â then	 Â the	 Â jurisdiction	 Â is	 Â likely	 Â to	 Â have	 Â more	 Â workers	 Â employed	 Â outside	 Â 
the	 Â jurisdiction.	 Â 	 Â 
In	 Â 2000,	 Â Cotati	 Â had	 Â a	 Â jobs/housing	 Â ratio	 Â of	 Â 0.98:1,	 Â meaning	 Â that	 Â there	 Â is	 Â an	 Â almost	 Â one	 Â job	 Â in	 Â the	 Â City	 Â for	 Â 
each	 Â housing	 Â unit.	 Â 	 Â This	 Â ratio	 Â has	 Â decreased	 Â to	 Â an	 Â estimated	 Â 0.77:1	 Â in	 Â 2010	 Â (Table	 Â 1-Â­â€29).	 Â 	 Â The	 Â decrease	 Â in	 Â 
the	 Â  jobs-Â­â€housing	 Â  balance	 Â  is	 Â  primarily	 Â  due	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  increase	 Â  in	 Â  housing	 Â  construction	 Â  from	 Â  2000	 Â  to	 Â  2010,	 Â 
which	 Â  coupled	 Â  with	 Â  the	 Â  recession	 Â  and	 Â  related	 Â  decrease	 Â  in	 Â  employment	 Â  and	 Â  jobs,	 Â  resulted	 Â  in	 Â  a	 Â  decline	 Â  in	 Â 
the	 Â jobs-Â­â€housing	 Â balance.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
A F F O R D A B L E 	 Â  H O U S IN G 	 Â  I N V E N T O R Y 	 Â

a	 Â  total	 Â  of	 Â  47	 Â  very	 Â  low	 Â  and	 Â  low	 Â  income	 Â  senior	 Â  units	 Â  and	 Â  101	 Â  very	 Â  low	 Â  and	 Â  low	 Â  income	 Â  family	 Â  units.	 Â

approximately	 Â  29	 Â  affordable	 Â  ownership	 Â  units	 Â  subsidized	 Â  by	 Â  Federal	 Â  and/or	 Â  State	 Â  programs.	 Â  	 Â  An	 Â

	 Â

Seniors	 Â 
Seniors	 Â  are	 Â  considered	 Â  persons	 Â  age	 Â  65	 Â  or	 Â  older	 Â  in	 Â  this	 Â  Housing	 Â  Element.	 Â  However,	 Â  it	 Â  must	 Â  be	 Â  noted	 Â  that	 Â

services	 Â  to	 Â  perform	 Â  activities	 Â  of	 Â  daily	 Â  living,	 Â  conservators	 Â  to	 Â  assist	 Â  with	 Â  personal	 Â  care	 Â  and	 Â  financial	 Â

      FACILITIES.	 Â 
Senior	 Â Housing	 Â 
There	 Â are	 Â two	 Â senior	 Â housing	 Â facilities	 Â in	 Â Cotati:	 Â 
        â€¢         Charles	 Â Street	 Â Village,	 Â 770	 Â E.	 Â Cotati	 Â Avenue	 Â â€“	 Â 47	 Â units	 Â of	 Â lower	 Â income	 Â senior	 Â housing	 Â 
        â€¢         Oaks	 Â of	 Â Hebron	 Â Sierra,	 Â 405	 Â W.	 Â Sierra	 Â Avenue	 Â -Â­â€	 Â 6-Â­â€bed	 Â elderly	 Â residential	 Â care	 Â facility,	 Â market	 Â rate	 Â 
By	 Â 2022,	 Â  approximately	 Â 140	 Â additional	 Â  senior	 Â  households	 Â  are	 Â  anticipated	 Â  in	 Â  Cotati.	 Â  	 Â  This	 Â  is	 Â  slightly	 Â  larger	 Â 
than	 Â the	 Â Cityâ€™s	 Â share	 Â of	 Â the	 Â RHNA.	 Â 	 Â It	 Â is	 Â anticipated	 Â that	 Â some	 Â of	 Â these	 Â senior	 Â households	 Â will	 Â be	 Â existing	 Â

approximately	 Â 45	 Â to	 Â 70	 Â units	 Â of	 Â the	 Â senior	 Â household	 Â growth.	 Â 	 Â 
Disabled	 Â Persons	 Â 
A	 Â  "disability"	 Â  includes,	 Â  but	 Â  is	 Â  not	 Â  limited	 Â  to,	 Â  any	 Â  physical	 Â  or	 Â  mental	 Â  disability	 Â  as	 Â  defined	 Â  in	 Â  California	 Â 
Government	 Â  Code	 Â  Section	 Â  12926.	 Â  A	 Â  "mental	 Â  disability"	 Â  involves	 Â  having	 Â  any	 Â  mental	 Â  or	 Â  psychological	 Â 
disorder	 Â or	 Â condition,	 Â such	 Â as	 Â mental	 Â retardation,	 Â organic	 Â brain	 Â syndrome,	 Â emotional	 Â or	 Â mental	 Â illness,	 Â 
or	 Â specific	 Â learning	 Â disabilities	 Â that	 Â limits	 Â a	 Â major	 Â life	 Â activity.	 Â A	 Â "physical	 Â disability"	 Â involves	 Â having	 Â any	 Â 
physiological	 Â disease,	 Â disorder,	 Â condition,	 Â cosmetic	 Â disfigurement,	 Â or	 Â anatomical	 Â loss	 Â that	 Â affects	 Â body	 Â 
systems	 Â  including	 Â  neurological,	 Â  immunological,	 Â  musculoskeletal,	 Â  special	 Â  sense	 Â  organs,	 Â  respiratory,	 Â 
speech	 Â  organs,	 Â  cardiovascular,	 Â  reproductive,	 Â  digestive,	 Â  genitourinary,	 Â  hemic	 Â  and	 Â  lymphatic,	 Â  skin	 Â  and	 Â 
endocrine.	 Â  In	 Â  addition,	 Â  a	 Â  mental	 Â  or	 Â  physical	 Â  disability	 Â  limits	 Â  a	 Â  major	 Â  life	 Â  activity	 Â  by	 Â  making	 Â  the	 Â 
achievement	 Â of	 Â major	 Â life	 Â activities	 Â difficult	 Â including	 Â physical,	 Â mental,	 Â and	 Â social	 Â activities	 Â and	 Â working.	 Â 
Physical,	 Â  mental,	 Â  and/or	 Â  developmental	 Â  disabilities	 Â  could	 Â  prevent	 Â  a	 Â  person	 Â  from	 Â  working,	 Â  restrict	 Â  a	 Â 
persons'	 Â mobility	 Â or	 Â make	 Â caring	 Â for	 Â oneself	 Â difficult.	 Â Therefore,	 Â disabled	 Â persons	 Â often	 Â require	 Â special	 Â 
housing	 Â  needs	 Â  related	 Â  to	 Â  potential	 Â  limited	 Â  earning	 Â  capacity,	 Â  the	 Â  lack	 Â  of	 Â  accessible	 Â  and	 Â  affordable	 Â 
housing,	 Â  and	 Â  higher	 Â  health	 Â  costs	 Â  associated	 Â  with	 Â  disabilities.	 Â  Additionally,	 Â  people	 Â  with	 Â  disabilities	 Â 
require	 Â a	 Â wide	 Â range	 Â of	 Â different	 Â housing,	 Â depending	 Â on	 Â the	 Â type	 Â and	 Â severity	 Â of	 Â their	 Â disability.	 Â Housing	 Â 
needs	 Â  can	 Â  range	 Â  from	 Â  institutional	 Â  care	 Â  facilities	 Â  to	 Â  facilities	 Â  that	 Â  support	 Â  partial	 Â  or	 Â  full	 Â  independence	 Â 
(i.e.,	 Â group	 Â care	 Â homes).	 Â Supportive	 Â services	 Â such	 Â as	 Â daily	 Â living	 Â skills	 Â and	 Â employment	 Â assistance	 Â need	 Â 
to	 Â be	 Â integrated	 Â in	 Â the	 Â housing	 Â situation.	 Â The	 Â disabled	 Â person	 Â with	 Â a	 Â mobility	 Â limitation	 Â requires	 Â housing	 Â 
that	 Â  is	 Â  physically	 Â  accessible.	 Â  Examples	 Â  of	 Â  accessibility	 Â  in	 Â  housing	 Â  include	 Â  widened	 Â  doorways	 Â  and	 Â 
hallways,	 Â  ramps,	 Â  bathroom	 Â  modifications	 Â  (i.e.,	 Â  lowered	 Â  countertops,	 Â  grab	 Â  bars,	 Â  adjustable	 Â  shower	 Â 
heads,	 Â etc.)	 Â and	 Â special	 Â sensory	 Â devices	 Â including	 Â smoke	 Â alarms	 Â and	 Â flashing	 Â lights.	 Â 	 Â 
The	 Â  2009-Â­â€2013	 Â  ACS	 Â  identifies	 Â  six	 Â  types	 Â  of	 Â  disabilities	 Â  including	 Â  hearing,	 Â  vision,	 Â  cognitive,	 Â  ambulatory,	 Â 
self-Â­â€care,	 Â and	 Â independent	 Â living.	 Â  A	 Â  disability	 Â is	 Â defined	 Â as	 Â a	 Â mental,	 Â physical,	 Â or	 Â health	 Â condition	 Â  that	 Â 
lasts	 Â over	 Â six	 Â months	 Â and	 Â persons	 Â may	 Â have	 Â more	 Â than	 Â one	 Â disability.	 Â According	 Â to	 Â the	 Â 2009-Â­â€2013	 Â ACS,	 Â

The	 Â  â€œWith	 Â  a	 Â  Disabilityâ€	 Â  category	 Â  includes	 Â  persons	 Â  with	 Â  developmental	 Â  disabilities.	 Â  "Developmental	 Â 
disability"	 Â means	 Â a	 Â disability	 Â that	 Â originates	 Â before	 Â an	 Â individual	 Â attains	 Â age	 Â 18	 Â years,	 Â continues,	 Â or	 Â can	 Â

persons	 Â  employed	 Â  specifically	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  agricultural	 Â  industry	 Â  or	 Â  occupation.	 Â 	 Â There	 Â  is	 Â  no	 Â  farmworker	 Â  data	 Â

within	 Â the	 Â City	 Â limits.	 Â 
The	 Â  2014	 Â  Sonoma	 Â  County	 Â  Housing	 Â  Element	 Â  indicates	 Â  that	 Â  there	 Â  is	 Â  a	 Â  need	 Â  for	 Â  housing	 Â  within	 Â  the	 Â 
unincorporated	 Â  County	 Â  to	 Â  accommodate	 Â  both	 Â  the	 Â  migrant	 Â  worker	 Â  category	 Â  as	 Â  well	 Â  as	 Â  an	 Â  increasing	 Â

Sonoma	 Â County	 Â 2014	 Â Housing	 Â Element,	 Â there	 Â are	 Â a	 Â total	 Â of	 Â 238	 Â farmworker	 Â family	 Â housing	 Â units	 Â in	 Â the	 Â 
                                                                                                                                                      City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â |	 Â Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report	 Â            1-Â­â€22	 Â

                                                                                              	 Â      1.	 Â 	 Â HOUSING	 Â NEEDS	 Â ASSESSMENT	 Â 
	 Â 
unincorporated	 Â County,	 Â including	 Â 104	 Â rental	 Â units	 Â within	 Â four	 Â developments,	 Â and	 Â 134	 Â units	 Â within	 Â seven	 Â 
ownership	 Â  developments.	 Â  In	 Â  addition,	 Â  there	 Â  are	 Â  732	 Â  seasonal	 Â  and	 Â  year-Â­â€round	 Â  farmworker	 Â  beds	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â 
unincorporated	 Â  County.	 Â  Some	 Â  Sonoma	 Â  County	 Â  vineyards	 Â  provide	 Â  bunkhouses	 Â  for	 Â  workers,	 Â  although	 Â 
many	 Â  migrant	 Â  farmworkers	 Â  live	 Â  in	 Â  motel	 Â  rooms	 Â  or	 Â  outdoor	 Â  encampments.	 Â  Vineyard	 Â  Worker	 Â  Services	 Â 
provides	 Â temporary	 Â housing	 Â at	 Â two	 Â trailer	 Â camps	 Â in	 Â the	 Â County.	 Â 
While	 Â  there	 Â  is	 Â  a	 Â  significant	 Â  amount	 Â  of	 Â  agricultural	 Â  production	 Â  in	 Â  Sonoma	 Â  County	 Â  and	 Â  a	 Â  demand	 Â  for	 Â

land,	 Â  there	 Â  are	 Â  no	 Â  parcels	 Â  in	 Â  Cotati	 Â  designated	 Â  for	 Â  agricultural	 Â  use.	 Â  	 Â  Agricultural	 Â  uses,	 Â  such	 Â  as	 Â  crop	 Â

subject	 Â to	 Â the	 Â issuance	 Â of	 Â a	 Â use	 Â permit.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â Cotati	 Â is	 Â anticipated	 Â to	 Â continue	 Â to	 Â urbanize	 Â in	 Â the	 Â future	 Â and	 Â

Element.	 Â 	 Â It	 Â is	 Â therefore	 Â anticipated	 Â that	 Â the	 Â need	 Â for	 Â farmworker	 Â housing	 Â in	 Â Cotati	 Â will	 Â not	 Â increase	 Â in	 Â

Homeless	 Â Persons	 Â 
Homeless	 Â individuals	 Â and	 Â families	 Â have	 Â perhaps	 Â the	 Â most	 Â immediate	 Â housing	 Â need	 Â of	 Â any	 Â group.	 Â They	 Â 
also	 Â  have	 Â  one	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  most	 Â  difficult	 Â  sets	 Â  of	 Â  housing	 Â  needs	 Â  to	 Â  meet,	 Â  due	 Â  to	 Â  both	 Â  the	 Â  diversity	 Â  and	 Â 
complexity	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  factors	 Â  that	 Â  lead	 Â  to	 Â  homelessness,	 Â  and	 Â  to	 Â  community	 Â  opposition	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  siting	 Â  of	 Â 
facilities	 Â that	 Â serve	 Â homeless	 Â clients.	 Â 	 Â A	 Â person	 Â or	 Â family	 Â is	 Â considered	 Â homeless	 Â if	 Â they	 Â lack	 Â a	 Â fixed	 Â and	 Â

living	 Â  accommodations.	 Â  	 Â  	 Â  Homelessness	 Â  occurs	 Â  for	 Â  a	 Â  variety	 Â  of	 Â  reasons,	 Â  including	 Â  insufficient	 Â  income,	 Â 
personal	 Â emergencies,	 Â inadequate	 Â support	 Â systems,	 Â chronic	 Â substance	 Â abuse,	 Â spousal/partner	 Â abuse	 Â or	 Â 
abandonment,	 Â physical	 Â or	 Â mental	 Â illness,	 Â lack	 Â of	 Â life	 Â skills,	 Â and	 Â loss	 Â of	 Â employment.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
In	 Â  2013,	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  assisted	 Â  in	 Â  funding	 Â  a	 Â  County-Â­â€wide	 Â  count	 Â  of	 Â  homeless	 Â  persons.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  Police	 Â 
Department	 Â and	 Â local	 Â service	 Â providers	 Â were	 Â contacted	 Â as	 Â part	 Â of	 Â the	 Â survey	 Â to	 Â ensure	 Â a	 Â thorough	 Â count	 Â 
of	 Â the	 Â homeless.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â 2013	 Â Sonoma	 Â County	 Â Homeless	 Â Census	 Â and	 Â Survey	 Â identified	 Â 21	 Â homeless	 Â persons	 Â 
in	 Â Cotati.	 Â 	 Â Five	 Â of	 Â the	 Â homeless	 Â persons	 Â were	 Â in	 Â a	 Â shelter	 Â and	 Â the	 Â remaining	 Â 16	 Â were	 Â unsheltered.	 Â 	 Â 
In	 Â addition	 Â to	 Â persons	 Â counted	 Â in	 Â the	 Â surveys,	 Â there	 Â may	 Â be	 Â individuals	 Â and	 Â families	 Â that	 Â are	 Â homeless	 Â 
but	 Â  temporarily	 Â  living	 Â  with	 Â  other	 Â  families	 Â  or	 Â  in	 Â  a	 Â  motel	 Â  but	 Â  are	 Â  in	 Â  need	 Â  of	 Â  permanent	 Â  shelter.	 Â  	 Â  This	 Â 
population	 Â is	 Â difficult	 Â to	 Â count.	 Â 	 Â Lower	 Â income	 Â families	 Â and	 Â individuals	 Â that	 Â are	 Â significantly	 Â overpaying	 Â 
for	 Â  housing	 Â  are	 Â  particularly	 Â  vulnerable	 Â  to	 Â  homelessness	 Â  as	 Â  their	 Â  income	 Â  levels	 Â  combined	 Â  with	 Â  housing	 Â 
and	 Â other	 Â living	 Â costs	 Â do	 Â not	 Â typically	 Â leave	 Â much	 Â cushion	 Â in	 Â the	 Â event	 Â of	 Â an	 Â emergency.	 Â 	 Â In	 Â Cotati,	 Â 46	 Â

The	 Â Sonoma	 Â County	 Â Community	 Â Development	 Â Commission	 Â (CDC)	 Â receives	 Â and	 Â administers	 Â federal	 Â block	 Â

Chapter	 Â 3,	 Â Resources.	 Â 	 Â Cotati	 Â has	 Â two	 Â housing	 Â facilities	 Â operated	 Â by	 Â Community	 Â Support	 Â Network	 Â that	 Â

North	 Â  House	 Â  â€“	 Â  8050	 Â  Old	 Â  Redwood	 Â  Highway:	 Â  Eight-Â­â€bed	 Â  residential	 Â  Transitional	 Â  Training	 Â  Program	 Â  for	 Â 
mentally	 Â ill,	 Â homeless	 Â adults.	 Â There	 Â is	 Â minimal	 Â supervision	 Â and	 Â services	 Â focus	 Â on	 Â helping	 Â clients	 Â  assess	 Â 
their	 Â own	 Â skills	 Â and	 Â abilities	 Â relating	 Â to	 Â independent	 Â living	 Â stabilization.	 Â Clients	 Â stay	 Â 6-Â­â€10	 Â months.	 Â 	 Â 
A	 Â  Step	 Â  Up	 Â  â€“	 Â  420	 Â  East	 Â  Cotati	 Â  Avenue:	 Â  Eight-Â­â€bed	 Â  facility	 Â  providing	 Â  dual	 Â  diagnosed	 Â  adults	 Â  (mental	 Â  illness	 Â 
with	 Â  alcohol	 Â  and/or	 Â  other	 Â  drug	 Â  issues)	 Â  the	 Â  opportunity	 Â  to	 Â  develop	 Â  habits	 Â  and	 Â  skills	 Â  	 Â  necessary	 Â  to	 Â  remain	 Â

provides	 Â six-Â­â€	 Â to	 Â nine-Â­â€month	 Â residential	 Â treatment	 Â and	 Â counseling,	 Â 12	 Â step	 Â recovery.	 Â 
Cotati	 Â  has	 Â  also	 Â  funded	 Â  other	 Â  homeless	 Â  programs,	 Â  including	 Â  the	 Â  Committee	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  Shelterless	 Â  (COTS)	 Â 
which	 Â  provides	 Â  emergency	 Â  and	 Â  transitional	 Â  shelter	 Â  and	 Â  permanent	 Â  housing	 Â  for	 Â  the	 Â  homeless	 Â  (almost	 Â 
325	 Â  beds	 Â  nightly)	 Â  and	 Â  programs	 Â  in	 Â  Petaluma.	 Â  	 Â  Several	 Â  shelters	 Â  are	 Â  also	 Â  available	 Â  in	 Â  Santa	 Â  Rosa,	 Â  including	 Â 
facilities	 Â  and	 Â  programs	 Â  operated	 Â  by	 Â  Catholic	 Â  Charities	 Â  which	 Â  receive	 Â  CDC	 Â  funding	 Â  and	 Â  administer	 Â  several	 Â 
programs	 Â that	 Â are	 Â available	 Â to	 Â Cotati	 Â residents.	 Â

persons	 Â  in	 Â  Cotati	 Â  at	 Â  any	 Â  given	 Â  point	 Â  in	 Â  time	 Â  that	 Â  are	 Â  in	 Â  need	 Â  of	 Â  emergency	 Â  shelter	 Â  or	 Â  transitional	 Â

     1.	 Â 	 Â HOUSING	 Â NEEDS	 Â ASSESSMENT	 Â                                                   	 Â 
	 Â 
	 Â 
	 Â 
	 Â 
	 Â

	 Â 
	 Â 
	 Â 
	 Â 
	 Â

	 Â 

                                               	 Â                                                                     2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
2.	 Â           CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
Governmental	 Â and	 Â non-Â­â€governmental	 Â constraints	 Â that	 Â can	 Â affect	 Â the	 Â housing	 Â market	 Â and	 Â development	 Â 
of	 Â  housing	 Â  in	 Â  Cotati	 Â  are	 Â  discussed	 Â  below.	 Â  The	 Â  Housing	 Â  Plan	 Â  includes	 Â  policies	 Â  and	 Â  programs,	 Â  where	 Â 
feasible,	 Â  to	 Â  reduce	 Â  or	 Â  overcome	 Â  constraints	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  maintenance,	 Â  improvement,	 Â  and	 Â  development	 Â  of	 Â 
housing	 Â for	 Â all	 Â income	 Â levels.	 Â 	 Â 
G O V E R N M E N T A L 	 Â  C O N S T R A IN T S 	 Â 
Governmental	 Â  regulations,	 Â  while	 Â  intentionally	 Â  regulating	 Â  the	 Â  quality	 Â  and	 Â  safety	 Â  of	 Â  development	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â 
community	 Â  can	 Â  also,	 Â  unintentionally,	 Â  increase	 Â  the	 Â  cost	 Â  of	 Â  development	 Â  and	 Â  thus	 Â  the	 Â  cost	 Â  of	 Â  housing.	 Â 
These	 Â  governmental	 Â  constraints	 Â  include	 Â  land	 Â  use	 Â  controls,	 Â  such	 Â  as	 Â  policies,	 Â  standards,	 Â  codes,	 Â 
requirements,	 Â development	 Â fees,	 Â processing	 Â procedures,	 Â and	 Â other	 Â exactions	 Â required	 Â of	 Â developers.	 Â 
Land	 Â  use	 Â  controls	 Â  may	 Â  limit	 Â  the	 Â  amount	 Â  or	 Â  density	 Â  of	 Â  development,	 Â  thus	 Â  increasing	 Â  the	 Â  cost	 Â  per	 Â  unit.	 Â 
They	 Â may	 Â also	 Â require	 Â improvements	 Â and/or	 Â off-Â­â€site	 Â mitigation	 Â that	 Â increase	 Â the	 Â cost	 Â of	 Â development.	 Â 
Processing	 Â  procedures,	 Â  including	 Â  review	 Â  by	 Â  multiple	 Â  agencies	 Â  and	 Â  permitting	 Â  requirements,	 Â  may	 Â  delay	 Â 
the	 Â approval	 Â process	 Â and	 Â increase	 Â the	 Â cost	 Â of	 Â development.	 Â 
Federal	 Â and	 Â State	 Â 
Federal	 Â  and	 Â  state	 Â  programs	 Â  and	 Â  agencies	 Â  play	 Â  a	 Â  role	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  imposition	 Â  of	 Â  non-Â­â€local	 Â  governmental	 Â 
constraints.	 Â Federal	 Â and	 Â state	 Â requirements	 Â are	 Â generally	 Â beyond	 Â the	 Â influence	 Â of	 Â local	 Â government,	 Â and	 Â 
therefore	 Â cannot	 Â be	 Â effectively	 Â addressed	 Â in	 Â this	 Â document.	 Â 
CALIFORNIA	 Â ENVIRONMENTAL	 Â QUALITY	 Â ACT	 Â 
The	 Â  California	 Â  Environmental	 Â  Quality	 Â  Act	 Â  (CEQA)	 Â  was	 Â  developed	 Â  to	 Â  protect	 Â  the	 Â  quality	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â 
environment	 Â  and	 Â  the	 Â  health	 Â  and	 Â  safety	 Â  of	 Â  persons	 Â  from	 Â  adverse	 Â  environmental	 Â  effects.	 Â  Discretionary	 Â 
projects	 Â are	 Â required	 Â to	 Â be	 Â reviewed	 Â consistent	 Â with	 Â the	 Â requirements	 Â of	 Â CEQA	 Â to	 Â determine	 Â if	 Â there	 Â is	 Â 
potential	 Â  for	 Â  the	 Â  project	 Â  to	 Â  cause	 Â  a	 Â  significant	 Â  adverse	 Â  effect	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  environment.	 Â  Depending	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â 
type	 Â  of	 Â  project	 Â  and	 Â  its	 Â  potential	 Â  effects,	 Â  technical	 Â  traffic,	 Â  noise,	 Â  air	 Â  quality,	 Â  biological	 Â  resources,	 Â  and	 Â 
geotechnical	 Â  reports	 Â  may	 Â  be	 Â  needed.	 Â  If	 Â  potential	 Â  adverse	 Â  effects	 Â  can	 Â  be	 Â  mitigated,	 Â  a	 Â  mitigated	 Â  negative	 Â 
declaration	 Â  is	 Â  required.	 Â  If	 Â  potentially	 Â  adverse	 Â  effects	 Â  cannot	 Â  be	 Â  mitigated,	 Â  an	 Â  environmental	 Â  impact	 Â 
report	 Â  is	 Â  required.	 Â  These	 Â  documents	 Â  have	 Â  mandated	 Â  content	 Â  requirements	 Â  and	 Â  public	 Â  review	 Â  times.	 Â 
Preparation	 Â of	 Â CEQA	 Â documents	 Â can	 Â be	 Â costly	 Â and,	 Â despite	 Â maximum	 Â time	 Â limits	 Â set	 Â forth	 Â in	 Â the	 Â Public	 Â 
Resources	 Â Code,	 Â can	 Â extend	 Â the	 Â processing	 Â time	 Â of	 Â a	 Â project	 Â by	 Â a	 Â year	 Â or	 Â longer.	 Â 
PREVAILING	 Â WAGE	 Â LAWS	 Â 
Public	 Â works	 Â projects	 Â and	 Â affordable	 Â housing	 Â financed	 Â through	 Â the	 Â use	 Â of	 Â public	 Â funds	 Â are	 Â required	 Â to	 Â 
pay	 Â  prevailing	 Â  wages,	 Â  which	 Â  create	 Â  a	 Â  significant	 Â  cost	 Â  impact	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  construction	 Â  or	 Â  rehabilitation	 Â  of	 Â 
affordable	 Â  housing	 Â  units	 Â  for	 Â  low	 Â  or	 Â  moderate-Â­â€income	 Â  persons	 Â  and	 Â  the	 Â  infrastructure	 Â  to	 Â  support	 Â  such	 Â 
housing.	 Â  The	 Â  rehabilitation	 Â  of	 Â  certain	 Â  qualifying	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â  units	 Â  for	 Â  low	 Â  or	 Â  moderate-Â­â€income	 Â 
persons	 Â  is	 Â  exempted	 Â  from	 Â  this	 Â  requirement.	 Â  SB	 Â  972	 Â  provided	 Â  for	 Â  exemptions	 Â  from	 Â  prevailing	 Â  wage	 Â 
requirements	 Â for	 Â the	 Â construction	 Â or	 Â rehabilitation	 Â of	 Â privately	 Â owned	 Â residential	 Â projects.	 Â 
Local	 Â 
Land	 Â use	 Â controls	 Â are	 Â minimum	 Â standards	 Â included	 Â within	 Â the	 Â General	 Â Plan,	 Â and	 Â implemented	 Â through	 Â 
the	 Â Cityâ€™s	 Â Land	 Â Use	 Â Code.	 Â 	 Â General	 Â Plan	 Â land	 Â use	 Â designations	 Â are	 Â a	 Â means	 Â of	 Â ensuring	 Â that	 Â the	 Â land	 Â uses	 Â 
in	 Â  the	 Â  community	 Â  are	 Â  properly	 Â  situated	 Â  in	 Â  relation	 Â  to	 Â  one	 Â  another	 Â  and	 Â  providing	 Â  adequate	 Â  space	 Â  for	 Â 
     2-Â­â€1	 Â      Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report|	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â 
	 Â 

                                                     	 Â                                                                  2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
each	 Â type	 Â of	 Â development.	 Â Zoning	 Â regulations	 Â are	 Â designed	 Â to	 Â implement	 Â the	 Â intentions	 Â of	 Â the	 Â General	 Â 
Plan	 Â land	 Â use	 Â designations.	 Â They	 Â also	 Â control	 Â such	 Â features	 Â as	 Â height	 Â and	 Â bulk	 Â of	 Â buildings,	 Â lot	 Â area,	 Â yard	 Â 
setbacks,	 Â population	 Â density,	 Â the	 Â building	 Â use,	 Â etc.	 Â If	 Â zoning	 Â standards	 Â are	 Â significantly	 Â more	 Â rigid	 Â than	 Â 
private	 Â sector	 Â design	 Â standards	 Â and	 Â do	 Â not	 Â allow	 Â sufficient	 Â land	 Â use	 Â flexibility,	 Â then	 Â development	 Â costs	 Â 
could	 Â increase	 Â and	 Â housing	 Â production	 Â may	 Â decrease.	 Â 
CITY	 Â OF	 Â COTATI	 Â GENERAL	 Â PLAN	 Â 
The	 Â General	 Â Plan	 Â accommodates	 Â a	 Â range	 Â of	 Â residential	 Â building	 Â types	 Â and	 Â densities	 Â in	 Â various	 Â areas	 Â of	 Â

uses.	 Â

designation	 Â also	 Â permits	 Â associated	 Â neighborhood	 Â retail.	 Â 	 Â

units	 Â  per	 Â  acre	 Â  of	 Â  single	 Â  family	 Â  attached	 Â  and	 Â  detached	 Â  units,	 Â  duplexes,	 Â  and	 Â  planned	 Â  unit	 Â  development.	 Â

General	 Â Plan	 Â sets	 Â forth	 Â policies	 Â related	 Â to	 Â land	 Â use,	 Â circulation,	 Â safety,	 Â noise,	 Â open	 Â space,	 Â conservation,	 Â

community,	 Â including	 Â preservation	 Â of	 Â community	 Â character	 Â and	 Â economic	 Â development.	 Â 	 Â While	 Â policies	 Â

                                              	 Â                                                                   2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
related	 Â  to	 Â  safety,	 Â  open	 Â  space,	 Â  and	 Â  natural	 Â  resources	 Â  may	 Â  constrain	 Â  development,	 Â  these	 Â  policies	 Â  are	 Â

LAND	 Â USE	 Â CODE	 Â 
The	 Â  Land	 Â  Use	 Â  Code	 Â  identifies	 Â  five	 Â  residential	 Â  zones,	 Â  and	 Â  six	 Â  other	 Â  zones	 Â  and	 Â  overlay	 Â  zones	 Â  that	 Â  allow	 Â 
residential	 Â  development.	 Â  Table	 Â  2-Â­â€1	 Â  identifies	 Â  the	 Â  types	 Â  of	 Â  residential	 Â  uses	 Â  allowed	 Â  in	 Â  each	 Â  zone.	 Â 	 Â

Residential	 Â Z ones	 Â 
Rural	 Â Residential	 Â (RR).	 Â The	 Â RR	 Â zone	 Â accommodates	 Â low	 Â density	 Â single-Â­â€family	 Â residential	 Â uses,	 Â with	 Â the	 Â

and	 Â implements	 Â the	 Â medium	 Â density	 Â residential	 Â land	 Â use	 Â designation	 Â of	 Â the	 Â general	 Â plan.	 Â

Residential	 Â  care	 Â  facilities	 Â  for	 Â  the	 Â  elderly	 Â  and	 Â  residential	 Â  care	 Â  facilities	 Â  that	 Â  serve	 Â  seven	 Â  or	 Â  more	 Â  clients	 Â

Commercial,	 Â East	 Â Cotati	 Â Ave.	 Â Corridor	 Â (CE).	 Â 	 Â The	 Â CE	 Â zone	 Â is	 Â a	 Â mixed	 Â use	 Â classification	 Â that	 Â is	 Â applied	 Â to	 Â 
specific	 Â  parcels	 Â  on	 Â  both	 Â  sides	 Â  of	 Â  East	 Â  Cotati	 Â  Avenue,	 Â  from	 Â  Arthur	 Â  Street	 Â  east	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  city	 Â  limits.	 Â  The	 Â 
corridor	 Â is	 Â appropriate	 Â for	 Â a	 Â wide	 Â range	 Â of	 Â retail	 Â and	 Â service	 Â land	 Â uses	 Â that	 Â primarily	 Â serve	 Â local	 Â residents	 Â 
      2-Â­â€3	 Â      Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report|	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â

                                                  	 Â                                                                   2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
and	 Â  businesses,	 Â  including	 Â  offices,	 Â  shops,	 Â  personal	 Â  and	 Â  business	 Â  services,	 Â  and	 Â  small-Â­â€scale	 Â  restaurants,	 Â

Specific	 Â  Plan,	 Â  Santero	 Â  Way	 Â  (SPSW). The	 Â  SPSW	 Â  zoning	 Â  district	 Â  is	 Â  applied	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  area	 Â  covered	 Â  by	 Â  the	 Â 
Santero	 Â  Way	 Â  Specific	 Â  Plan,	 Â  which	 Â  provides	 Â  detailed	 Â  and	 Â  comprehensive	 Â  guidance	 Â  and	 Â  standards	 Â  for	 Â 
development.	 Â The	 Â SPSW	 Â zoning	 Â district	 Â is	 Â consistent	 Â with	 Â and	 Â implements	 Â the	 Â Santero	 Â Way	 Â Specific	 Â Plan	 Â

Commercial,	 Â Gravenstein	 Â Corridor	 Â (CG).	 Â 	 Â The	 Â CG	 Â zone	 Â is	 Â a	 Â mixed	 Â use	 Â classification	 Â that	 Â is	 Â applied	 Â to	 Â both	 Â

for	 Â  a	 Â  wide	 Â  range	 Â  of	 Â  retail	 Â  and	 Â  service	 Â  land	 Â  uses	 Â  that	 Â  serve	 Â  both	 Â  the	 Â  local	 Â  population	 Â  and	 Â  regional	 Â 
markets,	 Â  including	 Â  retail	 Â  uses	 Â  and	 Â  restaurants,	 Â  with	 Â  additional	 Â  uses	 Â  such	 Â  as	 Â  personal	 Â  and	 Â  business	 Â 
services,	 Â  and	 Â  offices	 Â  limited	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  second	 Â  floor	 Â  along	 Â  the	 Â  Gravenstein	 Â  frontage,	 Â  where	 Â  structures	 Â 
fronting	 Â  Gravenstein	 Â  are	 Â  generally	 Â  two	 Â  stories.	 Â  Residential	 Â  uses	 Â  are	 Â  allowed	 Â  as	 Â  part	 Â  of	 Â  mixed	 Â  use	 Â 
projects,	 Â at	 Â a	 Â maximum	 Â density	 Â of	 Â fifteen	 Â units	 Â per	 Â acre.	 Â The	 Â CG	 Â zone	 Â is	 Â consistent	 Â with	 Â and	 Â implements	 Â

variety	 Â  of	 Â  land	 Â  uses,	 Â  with	 Â  retail	 Â  and	 Â  other	 Â  pedestrian-Â­â€oriented	 Â  uses	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  ground	 Â  floors	 Â  of	 Â  street	 Â

density	 Â  of	 Â  fifteen	 Â  units	 Â  per	 Â  acre.	 Â  Street	 Â  fronting	 Â  structures	 Â  are	 Â  generally	 Â  two	 Â  stories.	 Â  The	 Â  CD	 Â  zone	 Â  is	 Â

DOWNTOWN	 Â SPECIFIC	 Â PLAN	 Â 
The	 Â  Downtown	 Â  Specific	 Â  Plan	 Â  established	 Â  five	 Â  districts;	 Â  the	 Â  four	 Â  districts	 Â  that	 Â  allow	 Â  residential	 Â  uses	 Â  are	 Â 
described	 Â  below.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  Downtown	 Â  Specific	 Â  Plan	 Â  does	 Â  not	 Â  establish	 Â  minimum	 Â  or	 Â  maximum	 Â  residential	 Â 
densities,	 Â  but	 Â  rather	 Â  identifies	 Â  the	 Â  number	 Â  of	 Â  units	 Â  that	 Â  can	 Â  be	 Â  accommodated	 Â  in	 Â  each	 Â  district	 Â  and	 Â 
provides	 Â building	 Â height	 Â and	 Â floor	 Â area	 Â ratio	 Â standards	 Â to	 Â guide	 Â the	 Â mass	 Â of	 Â each	 Â building.	 Â 	 Â Based	 Â on	 Â the	 Â

units	 Â  per	 Â  acre	 Â  may	 Â  be	 Â  accommodated	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  NG	 Â  district	 Â  in	 Â  solely	 Â  residential	 Â  projects	 Â  and	 Â  densities	 Â  of	 Â  up	 Â 
to	 Â  22	 Â  units	 Â  per	 Â  acre	 Â  may	 Â  be	 Â  accommodated	 Â  in	 Â  mixed	 Â  use	 Â  projects	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  NG	 Â  ,	 Â  CA,	 Â  HC,	 Â  and	 Â  LP	 Â  zones.	 Â 	 Â

(courtyard	 Â  housing	 Â  projects),	 Â  15	 Â  to	 Â  22	 Â  units	 Â  per	 Â  acre	 Â  for	 Â  mixed	 Â  use	 Â  projects,	 Â  14	 Â  units	 Â  per	 Â  acre	 Â  for	 Â  duplex	 Â 
â€“	 Â quadplex	 Â projects,	 Â and	 Â 10	 Â units	 Â per	 Â acre	 Â for	 Â rowhouse	 Â projects.	 Â 	 Â 
Historic	 Â  Core	 Â  (HC).	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  HC	 Â  district	 Â  is	 Â  intended	 Â  to	 Â  maintain	 Â  smaller-Â­â€scale	 Â  pedestrian	 Â  orientation,	 Â  with	 Â

facing	 Â  Old	 Â  Redwood	 Â  Highway.	 Â  	 Â  Office	 Â  and	 Â  residential	 Â  uses	 Â  may	 Â  be	 Â  permitted	 Â  above	 Â  or	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  ground	 Â 
floor	 Â on	 Â other	 Â streets.	 Â 	 Â This	 Â district	 Â will	 Â accommodate	 Â 71	 Â dwellings.	 Â

	 Â 
Street.	 Â  	 Â  Properties	 Â  are	 Â  intended	 Â  to	 Â  provide	 Â  for	 Â  small-Â­â€scale	 Â  ground	 Â  floor	 Â  retail	 Â  with	 Â  some	 Â  office	 Â  and	 Â

The	 Â Downtown	 Â Specific	 Â Plan	 Â allows	 Â a	 Â variety	 Â of	 Â housing	 Â types,	 Â including	 Â stand-Â­â€alone	 Â residential	 Â buildings	 Â 
as	 Â  well	 Â  as	 Â  mixed	 Â  use	 Â  buildings.	 Â  	 Â  Table	 Â  2-Â­â€2	 Â  identifies	 Â  standards	 Â  for	 Â  each	 Â  type	 Â  of	 Â  residential	 Â  use	 Â  allowed	 Â  in	 Â 
the	 Â Downtown	 Â Specific	 Â Plan.	 Â 
Courtyard	 Â  Housing:	 Â  	 Â  Courtyard	 Â  housing	 Â  is	 Â  a	 Â  building	 Â  designed	 Â  for	 Â  either	 Â  residential	 Â  or	 Â 
retail/service/office	 Â uses	 Â on	 Â the	 Â ground	 Â floor,	 Â with	 Â upper	 Â floors	 Â providing	 Â residential	 Â uses..	 Â 
Commercial	 Â  Block:	 Â  	 Â  A	 Â  commercial	 Â  block	 Â  is	 Â  a	 Â  building	 Â  designed	 Â  for	 Â  occupancy	 Â  by	 Â  retail,	 Â  service,	 Â  and	 Â  or	 Â

Rowhouse:	 Â  	 Â  A	 Â  rowhouse	 Â  is	 Â  an	 Â  individual	 Â  structure	 Â  that	 Â  may	 Â  be	 Â  residential	 Â  or	 Â  mixed	 Â  use	 Â  and	 Â  occupied	 Â  by	 Â

SANTERO	 Â WAY	 Â SPECIFIC	 Â PLAN	 Â 
The	 Â Santero	 Â Way	 Â Specific	 Â Plan	 Â was	 Â adopted	 Â on	 Â July	 Â 12,	 Â 2000.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â plan	 Â area	 Â is	 Â located	 Â on	 Â the	 Â eastern	 Â 
edge	 Â  of	 Â  Cotati.	 Â  	 Â  A	 Â  governing	 Â  objective	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  plan	 Â  is	 Â  to	 Â  allow	 Â  for	 Â  a	 Â  mix	 Â  of	 Â  uses	 Â  resulting	 Â  in	 Â  a	 Â  vital	 Â 
neighborhood	 Â that	 Â complements	 Â the	 Â existing	 Â character	 Â of	 Â Cotati.	 Â 	 Â Development	 Â is	 Â planned	 Â to	 Â support	 Â all	 Â 
modes	 Â  of	 Â  transportation,	 Â  including	 Â  bus	 Â  and	 Â  the	 Â  future	 Â  Sonoma	 Â  Marin	 Â  Area	 Â  Rapid	 Â  Transit	 Â  (SMART)	 Â 
station,	 Â  to	 Â  reduce	 Â  use	 Â  of	 Â  single-Â­â€occupant	 Â  automobiles.	 Â  	 Â  Land	 Â  use	 Â  regulations	 Â  developed	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  plan	 Â 
ensure	 Â  a	 Â  mix	 Â  of	 Â  uses	 Â  providing	 Â  for	 Â  residential,	 Â  commercial,	 Â  and	 Â  employment	 Â  needs	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  community	 Â 
that	 Â are	 Â complementary	 Â with	 Â development	 Â of	 Â the	 Â downtown	 Â Hub.	 Â 
The	 Â SWSP	 Â establishes	 Â objectives	 Â related	 Â to	 Â land	 Â use	 Â and	 Â community	 Â character,	 Â circulation,	 Â utilities	 Â and	 Â

     2-Â­â€5	 Â          Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report|	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â 
	 Â 

                                             	 Â                                                                2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
270,000	 Â square	 Â feet	 Â of	 Â commercial	 Â and	 Â employment	 Â development,	 Â and	 Â 100,000	 Â to	 Â 125,000	 Â square	 Â feet	 Â 
of	 Â  public	 Â  and	 Â  private	 Â  open	 Â  space.	 Â  	 Â  Five	 Â  land	 Â  use	 Â  districts:	 Â  Retail	 Â  Mixed-Â­â€Use,	 Â  Office	 Â  Mixed-Â­â€Use,	 Â 
Employment,	 Â Residential,	 Â and	 Â Parks	 Â are	 Â identified	 Â in	 Â the	 Â plan.	 Â 	 Â Each	 Â of	 Â the	 Â mixed-Â­â€use	 Â and	 Â employment	 Â 
districts	 Â  identifies	 Â  a	 Â  maximum	 Â  percentage	 Â  of	 Â  allowed	 Â  uses,	 Â  including	 Â  retail,	 Â  office,	 Â  live/work,	 Â  and	 Â 
residential,	 Â  allowed	 Â  in	 Â  each	 Â  development	 Â  to	 Â  ensure	 Â  that	 Â  no	 Â  building	 Â  is	 Â  limited	 Â  to	 Â  a	 Â  single	 Â  use	 Â  and	 Â  a	 Â 
variety	 Â of	 Â uses	 Â is	 Â provided.	 Â 
The	 Â following	 Â four	 Â districts	 Â in	 Â the	 Â SWSP	 Â accommodate	 Â residential	 Â uses:	 Â 
Retail	 Â  Mixed-Â­â€Use	 Â  â€“	 Â  The	 Â  Retail	 Â  Mixed-Â­â€Use	 Â  district	 Â  requires	 Â  development	 Â  of	 Â  retail	 Â  or	 Â  office	 Â  uses	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â 
ground	 Â floor,	 Â with	 Â residential	 Â uses	 Â limited	 Â to	 Â work	 Â and	 Â entrance	 Â lobbies	 Â of	 Â residential	 Â units,	 Â while	 Â the	 Â 
upper	 Â floor	 Â may	 Â have	 Â office	 Â and	 Â residential	 Â uses.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
Office	 Â Mixed-Â­â€Use	 Â â€“	 Â The	 Â Office	 Â Mixed-Â­â€Use	 Â district	 Â requires	 Â development	 Â of	 Â office,	 Â work	 Â area,	 Â apartments	 Â 
or	 Â  condominium	 Â  uses	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  ground	 Â  floor,	 Â  with	 Â  upper	 Â  floors	 Â  limited	 Â  to	 Â  residential	 Â  and	 Â  any	 Â  portion	 Â  of	 Â 
live/work	 Â units.	 Â 	 Â 
Employment	 Â â€“	 Â The	 Â Employment	 Â district	 Â allows	 Â cottage	 Â business,	 Â office,	 Â and	 Â live/work	 Â units.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
Residential	 Â â€“	 Â The	 Â Residential	 Â district	 Â is	 Â intended	 Â to	 Â add	 Â activity	 Â to	 Â the	 Â neighborhood	 Â in	 Â the	 Â evenings	 Â and	 Â 
weekends	 Â while	 Â allowing	 Â a	 Â mix	 Â of	 Â housing	 Â that	 Â accommodates	 Â affordable	 Â units	 Â allowing	 Â people	 Â to	 Â live	 Â 
and	 Â work	 Â in	 Â the	 Â neighborhood.	 Â 	 Â Allowed	 Â land	 Â uses	 Â include	 Â single	 Â family	 Â attached	 Â and	 Â detached	 Â homes,	 Â 
including	 Â duplexes,	 Â townhomes,	 Â and	 Â live/work	 Â units.	 Â This	 Â district	 Â is	 Â fully	 Â developed.	 Â

                                                    	 Â                                                                        2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
	 Â 
Definitions	 Â 
The	 Â Land	 Â Use	 Â Code	 Â classifies	 Â the	 Â following	 Â types	 Â of	 Â residential	 Â uses	 Â that	 Â may	 Â be	 Â permitted	 Â in	 Â a	 Â zone:	 Â 
         1. "Condominium,"	 Â  as	 Â  defined	 Â  by	 Â  Civil	 Â  Code	 Â  Section	 Â  1351(f),	 Â  means	 Â  a	 Â  development	 Â  where	 Â 
                undivided	 Â interest	 Â in	 Â common	 Â in	 Â a	 Â portion	 Â of	 Â real	 Â property	 Â is	 Â coupled	 Â with	 Â a	 Â separate	 Â interest	 Â in	 Â 
                space	 Â  called	 Â  a	 Â  unit,	 Â  the	 Â  boundaries	 Â  of	 Â  which	 Â  are	 Â  described	 Â  on	 Â  a	 Â  recorded	 Â  final	 Â  map	 Â  or	 Â  parcel	 Â 
                map.	 Â 
         2. "Dwelling,"	 Â  "unit,"	 Â  or	 Â  "housing	 Â  unit"	 Â  means	 Â  a	 Â  room	 Â  or	 Â  group	 Â  of	 Â  internally	 Â  connected	 Â  rooms	 Â  that	 Â 
                have	 Â  sleeping,	 Â  cooking,	 Â  eating,	 Â  and	 Â  sanitation	 Â  facilities,	 Â  but	 Â  not	 Â  more	 Â  than	 Â  one	 Â  kitchen,	 Â  which	 Â 
                constitute	 Â an	 Â independent	 Â housekeeping	 Â unit,	 Â occupied	 Â by	 Â or	 Â intended	 Â for	 Â one	 Â household	 Â on	 Â a	 Â 
                long-Â­â€term	 Â basis.	 Â 
         3. "Emergency/transitional	 Â  shelter"	 Â  means	 Â  a	 Â  facility	 Â  for	 Â  the	 Â  temporary	 Â  shelter	 Â  and	 Â  feeding	 Â  of	 Â 
                indigents	 Â or	 Â disaster	 Â victims,	 Â operated	 Â by	 Â a	 Â public	 Â or	 Â nonprofit	 Â agency.	 Â 
         4. "Live/work	 Â unit"	 Â means	 Â an	 Â integrated	 Â housing	 Â unit	 Â and	 Â working	 Â space,	 Â occupied	 Â and	 Â utilized	 Â by	 Â 
                a	 Â single	 Â household	 Â in	 Â a	 Â structure,	 Â either	 Â single-Â­â€family	 Â or	 Â multifamily,	 Â that	 Â has	 Â been	 Â designed	 Â or	 Â 
                structurally	 Â modified	 Â to	 Â accommodate	 Â joint	 Â residential	 Â occupancy	 Â and	 Â work	 Â activity.	 Â 
         5. "Mixed	 Â use	 Â project"	 Â means	 Â a	 Â project	 Â that	 Â combines	 Â both	 Â commercial	 Â and	 Â residential	 Â uses	 Â on	 Â the	 Â 
                same	 Â site.	 Â 	 Â 
         6. "Mobilehome"	 Â means	 Â a	 Â trailer,	 Â transportable	 Â in	 Â one	 Â or	 Â more	 Â sections,	 Â that	 Â is	 Â certified	 Â under	 Â the	 Â 
                National	 Â  Manufactured	 Â  Housing	 Â  Construction	 Â  and	 Â  Safety	 Â  Standards	 Â  Act	 Â  of	 Â  1974,	 Â  which	 Â  is	 Â  over	 Â 
                eight	 Â  feet	 Â  in	 Â  width	 Â  and	 Â  forty	 Â  feet	 Â  in	 Â  length,	 Â  with	 Â  or	 Â  without	 Â  a	 Â  permanent	 Â  foundation	 Â  and	 Â  not	 Â 
                including	 Â  recreational	 Â  vehicle,	 Â  commercial	 Â  coach	 Â  or	 Â  factory-Â­â€built	 Â  housing.	 Â  A	 Â  mobilehome	 Â  on	 Â  a	 Â 
                permanent	 Â foundation	 Â is	 Â included	 Â under	 Â the	 Â definition	 Â of	 Â "Single-Â­â€family	 Â dwellings."	 Â 
         7. "Multifamily	 Â  housing"	 Â  means	 Â  a	 Â  structure	 Â  containing	 Â  two	 Â  or	 Â  more	 Â  units.	 Â  Multifamily	 Â  dwellings	 Â 
                include:	 Â duplexes,	 Â triplexes,	 Â fourplexes	 Â (buildings	 Â under	 Â one	 Â ownership	 Â with	 Â two,	 Â three	 Â or	 Â four	 Â 
                units,	 Â respectively,	 Â in	 Â the	 Â same	 Â structure);	 Â apartments	 Â (five	 Â or	 Â more	 Â units	 Â under	 Â one	 Â ownership	 Â 
                in	 Â a	 Â single	 Â building);	 Â townhouse	 Â development	 Â (three	 Â or	 Â more	 Â attached	 Â dwellings	 Â where	 Â no	 Â unit	 Â 
                is	 Â  located	 Â  over	 Â  another	 Â  unit);	 Â  rowhouses;	 Â  and	 Â  other	 Â  building	 Â  types	 Â  containing	 Â  multiple	 Â  units	 Â  (for	 Â 
                example,	 Â condominiums,	 Â courtyard	 Â housing,	 Â stacked	 Â flats,	 Â etc.).	 Â 
         8. "Residential	 Â care"	 Â means	 Â a	 Â single-Â­â€family	 Â dwelling	 Â or	 Â multi-Â­â€unit	 Â facility	 Â licensed	 Â or	 Â supervised	 Â by	 Â 
                a	 Â federal,	 Â state,	 Â or	 Â local	 Â health/welfare	 Â agency	 Â that	 Â provides	 Â twenty-Â­â€four-Â­â€hour	 Â nonmedical	 Â care	 Â 
                of	 Â  unrelated	 Â  persons	 Â  who	 Â  are	 Â  handicapped	 Â  and	 Â  in	 Â  need	 Â  of	 Â  personal	 Â  services,	 Â  supervision,	 Â  or	 Â 
                assistance	 Â  essential	 Â  for	 Â  sustaining	 Â  the	 Â  activities	 Â  of	 Â  daily	 Â  living	 Â  or	 Â  for	 Â  the	 Â  protection	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â 
                individual	 Â in	 Â a	 Â family-Â­â€like	 Â environment.	 Â Does	 Â not	 Â include	 Â day	 Â care	 Â facilities,	 Â which	 Â are	 Â separately	 Â 
                defined.	 Â 
         9. "Residential	 Â  care	 Â  facility	 Â  for	 Â  the	 Â  elderly	 Â  (RCFE)"	 Â  means	 Â  a	 Â  housing	 Â  arrangement	 Â  chosen	 Â 
                voluntarily	 Â  by	 Â  the	 Â  residents,	 Â  or	 Â  the	 Â  residents'	 Â  guardians,	 Â  conservators	 Â  or	 Â  other	 Â  responsible	 Â 
                persons;	 Â  where	 Â  seventy-Â­â€five	 Â  percent	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  residents	 Â  are	 Â  at	 Â  least	 Â  sixty-Â­â€two	 Â  years	 Â  of	 Â  age,	 Â  or,	 Â  if	 Â 
                younger,	 Â  have	 Â  needs	 Â  compatible	 Â  with	 Â  other	 Â  residents;	 Â  and	 Â  where	 Â  varying	 Â  levels	 Â  of	 Â  care	 Â  and	 Â 
                supervision	 Â are	 Â provided,	 Â as	 Â agreed	 Â to	 Â at	 Â the	 Â time	 Â of	 Â admission	 Â or	 Â as	 Â determined	 Â necessary	 Â at	 Â 
                subsequent	 Â times	 Â of	 Â reappraisal	 Â (definition	 Â from	 Â California	 Â Code	 Â of	 Â Regulations	 Â Title	 Â 22,	 Â Division	 Â

                6,	 Â  Chapter	 Â  6,	 Â Residential	 Â  Care	 Â  Facilities	 Â  for	 Â  the	 Â  Elderly).	 Â  RCFE	 Â  projects	 Â  may	 Â  include	 Â  basic	 Â  services	 Â

                guesthouses.	 Â 
         12. "Single-Â­â€family	 Â  dwelling"	 Â  means	 Â  a	 Â  building	 Â  designed	 Â  for	 Â  and/or	 Â  occupied	 Â  exclusively	 Â  by	 Â  one	 Â 
                family.	 Â  Also	 Â  includes	 Â  factory-Â­â€built,	 Â  modular	 Â  housing	 Â  units,	 Â  constructed	 Â  in	 Â  compliance	 Â  with	 Â  the	 Â

                the	 Â National	 Â Manufactured	 Â Housing	 Â Construction	 Â and	 Â Safety	 Â Standards	 Â Act	 Â of	 Â 1974,	 Â placed	 Â on	 Â 
                permanent	 Â foundation	 Â systems.	 Â

Parking	 Â

Cityâ€™s	 Â  parking	 Â  requirements	 Â  require	 Â  market	 Â  rate	 Â  projects	 Â  to	 Â  provide	 Â  two	 Â  spaces	 Â  per	 Â  single	 Â  family	 Â  unit	 Â

requirements,	 Â  upon	 Â  request	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  project	 Â  developer.	 Â  	 Â  	 Â  	 Â  Senior	 Â  housing	 Â  projects	 Â  have	 Â  a	 Â  lower	 Â  parking	 Â

of	 Â project.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â City	 Â allows	 Â the	 Â following	 Â parking	 Â reductions	 Â and	 Â accommodations:	 Â 
         â€¢      All	 Â Residential	 Â Projects.	 Â The	 Â review	 Â authority	 Â may	 Â reduce	 Â the	 Â number	 Â of	 Â parking	 Â spaces	 Â by	 Â up	 Â to	 Â 
                fifteen	 Â percent	 Â through	 Â use	 Â permit	 Â approval,	 Â based	 Â on	 Â quantitative	 Â information	 Â provided	 Â by	 Â the	 Â 
                applicant	 Â that	 Â documents	 Â the	 Â need	 Â for	 Â fewer	 Â spaces	 Â (e.g.,	 Â sales	 Â receipts,	 Â documentation	 Â of	 Â

         â€¢      Senior	 Â Housing	 Â Projects.	 Â The	 Â review	 Â authority	 Â may	 Â reduce	 Â the	 Â number	 Â of	 Â parking	 Â spaces	 Â for	 Â

                         â€¢  Mixed	 Â Use	 Â Projects.	 Â Horizontal	 Â mixed	 Â use	 Â projects	 Â may	 Â reduce	 Â the	 Â parking	 Â requirement	 Â by	 Â the	 Â
