Land	 Â Use	 Â Code	 Â Chapter	 Â 17.32	 Â establishes	 Â density	 Â bonus	 Â standards;	 Â these	 Â standards	 Â are	 Â consistent	 Â with	 Â 
the	 Â requirements	 Â of	 Â Government	 Â Code	 Â Section	 Â 65915.	 Â 	 Â Chapter	 Â 17.32	 Â provides	 Â for	 Â a	 Â density	 Â bonus	 Â and	 Â 
additional	 Â incentives	 Â if	 Â the	 Â project	 Â has	 Â at	 Â least	 Â five	 Â units	 Â and	 Â meets	 Â one	 Â of	 Â the	 Â following	 Â requirements:	 Â 
         â€¢ At	 Â least	 Â 10	 Â percent	 Â of	 Â the	 Â total	 Â units	 Â are	 Â for	 Â lower	 Â income	 Â households;	 Â 	 Â 
         â€¢ At	 Â least	 Â five	 Â percent	 Â of	 Â the	 Â total	 Â units	 Â are	 Â for	 Â very	 Â low	 Â income	 Â households;	 Â 	 Â 
         â€¢ In	 Â a	 Â condominium	 Â project,	 Â at	 Â least	 Â 10	 Â  percent	 Â of	 Â the	 Â total	 Â dwelling	 Â units	 Â are	 Â for	 Â moderate	 Â income	 Â 
                households;	 Â 	 Â 
         â€¢ In	 Â  a	 Â  senior	 Â  citizen	 Â  housing	 Â  development	 Â  or	 Â  mobilehome	 Â  park,	 Â  residency	 Â  is	 Â  limited	 Â  based	 Â  on	 Â  age	 Â 
                requirements	 Â for	 Â housing	 Â for	 Â older	 Â persons;	 Â or	 Â 
         â€¢ The	 Â  project	 Â  provides	 Â  an	 Â  eligible	 Â  land	 Â  donation,	 Â  which	 Â  is	 Â  at	 Â  least	 Â  one	 Â  acre	 Â  or	 Â  sufficient	 Â  to	 Â 
                accommodate	 Â 40	 Â units	 Â and	 Â meets	 Â minimum	 Â requirements.	 Â 
The	 Â  amount	 Â  of	 Â  density	 Â  bonus	 Â  varies	 Â  according	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  percentage	 Â  of	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â  units,	 Â  but	 Â 
generally	 Â  ranges	 Â  from	 Â  20	 Â  to	 Â  35	 Â  percent	 Â  above	 Â  the	 Â  density	 Â  established	 Â  by	 Â  the	 Â  General	 Â  Plan	 Â  and	 Â  zoning	 Â 
requirements.	 Â  	 Â  However,	 Â  Chapter	 Â  17.32	 Â  does	 Â  not	 Â  provide	 Â  a	 Â  density	 Â  bonus	 Â  for	 Â  senior	 Â  housing	 Â  based	 Â  on	 Â  a	 Â 
percentage	 Â of	 Â the	 Â senior	 Â housing	 Â units,	 Â as	 Â required	 Â by	 Â Government	 Â Code	 Â Section	 Â 65915(f)(3).	 Â 	 Â 
In	 Â  addition	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  density	 Â  bonus,	 Â  eligible	 Â  projects	 Â  may	 Â  receive	 Â  one	 Â  to	 Â  three	 Â  additional	 Â  incentives,	 Â 
depending	 Â on	 Â the	 Â percentage	 Â of	 Â affordable	 Â units	 Â and	 Â level	 Â of	 Â affordability.	 Â The	 Â following	 Â development	 Â 
incentives	 Â may	 Â be	 Â requested:	 Â 
         â€¢ Reduced	 Â site	 Â development	 Â standards	 Â or	 Â design	 Â requirements;	 Â 
         â€¢ Approval	 Â of	 Â mixed-Â­â€use	 Â zoning	 Â in	 Â conjunction	 Â with	 Â the	 Â housing	 Â project;	 Â 	 Â 
         â€¢ Other	 Â regulatory	 Â incentives	 Â or	 Â concessions	 Â proposed	 Â by	 Â the	 Â applicant	 Â or	 Â the	 Â City	 Â that	 Â would	 Â result	 Â 
                in	 Â identifiable	 Â cost	 Â reductions;	 Â and/or	 Â 
         â€¢ A	 Â direct	 Â financial	 Â contribution	 Â from	 Â the	 Â City	 Â Council,	 Â at	 Â its	 Â sole	 Â discretion.	 Â 
Projects	 Â eligible	 Â for	 Â a	 Â density	 Â bonus	 Â that	 Â include	 Â an	 Â eligible	 Â child	 Â care	 Â facility	 Â are	 Â allowed	 Â an	 Â additional	 Â

standards,	 Â  regardless	 Â  of	 Â  whether	 Â  a	 Â  density	 Â  bonus	 Â  is	 Â  requested,	 Â  consistent	 Â  with	 Â  State	 Â  requirements	 Â  as	 Â

                                               	 Â                                                                           2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â

The	 Â  density	 Â  bonus	 Â  program	 Â  has	 Â  been	 Â  successful	 Â  in	 Â  encourage	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â  and	 Â  accommodating	 Â

Cotati	 Â has	 Â approved	 Â density	 Â bonuses	 Â for	 Â affordable	 Â housing	 Â projects	 Â and	 Â market-Â­â€rate	 Â developments	 Â that	 Â

Single	 Â Family	 Â Housing	 Â

Multifamily	 Â Housing	 Â

         â€¢      Height	 Â regulations	 Â â€“	 Â The	 Â NU	 Â zone	 Â allows	 Â maximum	 Â heights	 Â of	 Â 35	 Â feet,	 Â which	 Â will	 Â accommodate	 Â 
                two-Â­â€story	 Â  multifamily	 Â  structures.	 Â  	 Â  Mixed	 Â  use	 Â  structures	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  CE,	 Â  CG,	 Â  and	 Â  CD	 Â  zones	 Â  are	 Â  allowed	 Â 
                to	 Â have	 Â maximum	 Â heights	 Â of	 Â three	 Â stories/45	 Â feet.	 Â 	 Â Buildings	 Â in	 Â the	 Â SPD-Â­â€Northern	 Â Gateway	 Â are	 Â 
                allowed	 Â maximum	 Â heights	 Â of	 Â 50	 Â feet.	 Â 
         â€¢      Setbacks	 Â  â€“	 Â  Setbacks	 Â  vary	 Â  from	 Â  0	 Â to	 Â 15	 Â feet,	 Â depending	 Â on	 Â the	 Â district.	 Â 	 Â In	 Â the	 Â commercial	 Â  and	 Â

                                                	 Â                                                                               2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
         â€¢      Lot	 Â  coverage	 Â  and	 Â  open	 Â  space	 Â  â€“	 Â  Buildings,	 Â  roofed	 Â  areas,	 Â  and	 Â  parking	 Â  facilities	 Â  shall	 Â  not	 Â  cover	 Â 
                more	 Â than	 Â 60	 Â percent	 Â of	 Â the	 Â site	 Â in	 Â the	 Â NU	 Â zone	 Â and	 Â 80	 Â to	 Â 100	 Â percent	 Â in	 Â the	 Â commercial	 Â zones.	 Â

                square	 Â  feet	 Â  for	 Â  each	 Â  unit	 Â  in	 Â  excess	 Â  of	 Â  31.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  DSP	 Â  does	 Â  not	 Â  have	 Â  maximum	 Â  lot	 Â  coverage	 Â

                of	 Â open	 Â space	 Â per	 Â unit.	 Â 
         â€¢      Landscaping	 Â  -Â­â€	 Â  Open	 Â  space	 Â  areas	 Â  shall	 Â  be	 Â  landscaped,	 Â  with	 Â  an	 Â  emphasis	 Â  on	 Â  minimizing	 Â  water	 Â

	 Â 

                                                      	 Â                                                               2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
eligible	 Â  for	 Â  a	 Â  density	 Â  bonus	 Â  can	 Â  be	 Â  constructed	 Â  at	 Â  20.25	 Â  dwelling	 Â  units	 Â  per	 Â  acre.	 Â  	 Â  In	 Â  the	 Â  commercial	 Â

mixed	 Â use	 Â component.	 Â 	 Â In	 Â the	 Â SPD	 Â zone,	 Â maximum	 Â building	 Â heights	 Â are	 Â 35	 Â to	 Â 50	 Â feet	 Â and	 Â no	 Â minimum	 Â 
lot	 Â coverage	 Â requirements	 Â are	 Â established.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â floor	 Â area	 Â ratio	 Â of	 Â 2.15,	 Â combined	 Â with	 Â minimal	 Â setback	 Â 
requirements,	 Â and	 Â an	 Â allowance	 Â for	 Â tuck	 Â under	 Â or	 Â off-Â­â€site/in-Â­â€lieu	 Â parking	 Â readily	 Â accommodate	 Â densities	 Â 
of	 Â 25	 Â dwelling	 Â units	 Â per	 Â acre	 Â and	 Â higher.	 Â 
Government	 Â  Code	 Â  Section	 Â  65583.2(c)(3)(B)(ii)	 Â  indicates	 Â  densities	 Â  of	 Â  20	 Â  units	 Â  per	 Â  acre	 Â  in	 Â  suburban	 Â 
jurisdictions,	 Â  including	 Â  Cotati,	 Â  are	 Â  appropriate	 Â  to	 Â  accommodate	 Â  low	 Â  income	 Â  housing.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  SPD	 Â  zone	 Â

         â€¢       Size,	 Â Style.	 Â The	 Â size,	 Â location,	 Â and	 Â appearance	 Â must	 Â be	 Â subordinate	 Â to	 Â the	 Â primary	 Â single-Â­â€family	 Â

         â€¢       Design	 Â Standards:	 Â 
                 1. Location:	 Â 	 Â To	 Â the	 Â rear	 Â of	 Â the	 Â rear	 Â faÃ§ade	 Â line	 Â of	 Â the	 Â primary	 Â dwelling;	 Â unless	 Â on	 Â a	 Â parcel	 Â of	 Â

                 2. Height	 Â Limit:	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 20	 Â feet;	 Â higher	 Â in	 Â the	 Â RR	 Â and	 Â RVL	 Â zones	 Â if	 Â specific	 Â criteria	 Â are	 Â met	 Â

	 Â 

                                                   	 Â                                                                     2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
The	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  Land	 Â  Use	 Â  Code	 Â  allows	 Â  small	 Â  residential	 Â  care	 Â  homes	 Â  (limited	 Â  to	 Â  6	 Â  or	 Â  fewer	 Â  persons)	 Â  in	 Â  all	 Â

constraints	 Â or	 Â additional	 Â requirements	 Â imposed	 Â for	 Â developments	 Â that	 Â assist	 Â disabled	 Â households.	 Â The	 Â 
City	 Â requires	 Â no	 Â minimum	 Â distance	 Â between	 Â residential	 Â care	 Â homes	 Â and	 Â the	 Â conditions	 Â of	 Â the	 Â use	 Â permit	 Â

The	 Â City	 Â does	 Â not	 Â have	 Â any	 Â occupancy	 Â standards	 Â that	 Â apply	 Â specifically	 Â to	 Â unrelated	 Â adults	 Â and	 Â the	 Â Land	 Â 
Use	 Â Code	 Â does	 Â not	 Â provide	 Â a	 Â definition	 Â of	 Â family.	 Â State	 Â statutes	 Â give	 Â groups	 Â of	 Â up	 Â to	 Â six	 Â persons	 Â the	 Â right	 Â 
to	 Â  live	 Â  in	 Â  residential	 Â  neighborhoods	 Â  without	 Â  conditional	 Â  or	 Â  special	 Â  use	 Â  permits.	 Â  Government	 Â  Code	 Â 
Section	 Â  15955(l)	 Â  prohibits	 Â  discrimination	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  basis	 Â  of	 Â  familial	 Â  status.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  Housing	 Â  Plan	 Â  includes	 Â  a	 Â 
program	 Â to	 Â define	 Â â€œfamilyâ€	 Â consistent	 Â with	 Â State	 Â housing	 Â law	 Â and	 Â remove	 Â this	 Â potential	 Â constraint.	 Â 	 Â 
Parking	 Â  standards	 Â  for	 Â  small	 Â  residential	 Â  care	 Â  homes	 Â  are	 Â  the	 Â  same	 Â  as	 Â  for	 Â  a	 Â  single	 Â  family	 Â  home;	 Â  these	 Â 
standards	 Â  to	 Â  not	 Â  pose	 Â  a	 Â  constraint	 Â  on	 Â  development	 Â  of	 Â  small	 Â  group	 Â  homes,	 Â  which	 Â  would	 Â  require	 Â  two	 Â 
parking	 Â  spaces	 Â  to	 Â  accommodate	 Â  the	 Â  occupants	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  group	 Â  home	 Â  as	 Â  well	 Â  as	 Â  any	 Â  employees.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â 
parking	 Â  requirements	 Â  for	 Â  a	 Â  large	 Â  residential	 Â  care	 Â  home	 Â  require	 Â  0.75	 Â  spaces	 Â  per	 Â  bed,	 Â  except	 Â  for	 Â  senior	 Â 
housing	 Â  projects	 Â  which	 Â  require	 Â  0.6	 Â  parking	 Â  spaces	 Â  per	 Â  unit.	 Â  The	 Â  Land	 Â  Use	 Â  Code	 Â  allows	 Â  for	 Â  a	 Â  reduction	 Â  in	 Â 
the	 Â  parking	 Â  requirement,	 Â  if	 Â  the	 Â  project	 Â  applicant	 Â  can	 Â  demonstrate	 Â  that	 Â  the	 Â  project	 Â  would	 Â  have	 Â  less	 Â 
demand	 Â for	 Â parking.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
Cotati	 Â  follows	 Â  the	 Â  requirements	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  Americans	 Â  with	 Â  Disabilities	 Â  Act	 Â  (ADA)	 Â  in	 Â  regard	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â 
development	 Â  of	 Â  accessible	 Â  housing.	 Â  The	 Â  Fair	 Â  Housing	 Â  Act	 Â  and	 Â  ADA	 Â require	 Â  that	 Â  all	 Â  ground	 Â  floor	 Â  dwelling	 Â 
units	 Â in	 Â buildings	 Â of	 Â four	 Â or	 Â more	 Â units	 Â without	 Â elevators	 Â and	 Â all	 Â dwelling	 Â units	 Â in	 Â elevator	 Â buildings	 Â of	 Â 
four	 Â or	 Â more	 Â units	 Â include	 Â basic	 Â features	 Â of	 Â accessible	 Â and	 Â adaptive	 Â design.	 Â Furthermore,	 Â the	 Â Land	 Â Use	 Â 
Code	 Â requires	 Â multifamily	 Â developments	 Â and	 Â single	 Â family	 Â subdivisions	 Â of	 Â five	 Â units	 Â or	 Â more	 Â to	 Â provide	 Â 
at	 Â  least	 Â  10	 Â  percent	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  units	 Â  as	 Â  single	 Â  story	 Â  units	 Â  accessible	 Â  to	 Â  disabled	 Â  persons.	 Â  	 Â  Each	 Â  accessible	 Â 
multifamily	 Â unit	 Â must	 Â include	 Â features	 Â to	 Â ensure	 Â accessibility	 Â for	 Â disabled	 Â persons,	 Â including	 Â wide	 Â doors,	 Â 
grab	 Â  bars,	 Â  etc.,	 Â  and	 Â  each	 Â  accessible	 Â  single	 Â  family	 Â  unit	 Â  must	 Â  either	 Â  be	 Â  constructed	 Â  with	 Â  accessibility	 Â 
features	 Â or	 Â offer	 Â the	 Â installation	 Â of	 Â such	 Â features	 Â to	 Â prospective	 Â buyers	 Â at	 Â no	 Â charge.	 Â 
Second	 Â units	 Â are	 Â allowed	 Â by	 Â right	 Â in	 Â residential	 Â zones,	 Â which	 Â would	 Â allow	 Â a	 Â disabled	 Â person	 Â to	 Â have	 Â an	 Â

Housing	 Â  rehabilitation	 Â  assistance	 Â  and	 Â  accessibility	 Â  improvements	 Â  are	 Â  provided	 Â  to	 Â  eligible	 Â  households,	 Â  to	 Â

development	 Â requirements	 Â that	 Â can	 Â be	 Â approved	 Â at	 Â the	 Â Community	 Â Development	 Â Director	 Â level.	 Â 	 Â This	 Â

Farm	 Â Labor	 Â and	 Â Employee	 Â Housing	 Â

State	 Â  law	 Â  requires	 Â  that	 Â  employee	 Â  housing	 Â  providing	 Â  accommodations	 Â  for	 Â  six	 Â  or	 Â  fewer	 Â  employees	 Â  shall	 Â

Housing	 Â Element.	 Â 
Facilities	 Â for	 Â Homeless	 Â and	 Â Households	 Â At-Â­Risk	 Â of	 Â Homelessness	 Â 
Facilities	 Â  and	 Â  housing	 Â  for	 Â  homeless	 Â  persons	 Â  and	 Â  those	 Â  at-Â­â€risk	 Â  of	 Â  homelessness	 Â  fall	 Â  into	 Â  three	 Â  categories:	 Â

Supportive	 Â and	 Â Transitional	 Â Housing	 Â 
"Supportive	 Â  housing"	 Â  means	 Â  housing	 Â  with	 Â  no	 Â  limit	 Â  on	 Â  length	 Â  of	 Â  stay,	 Â  that	 Â  is	 Â  occupied	 Â  by	 Â  the	 Â  target	 Â

when	 Â possible,	 Â work	 Â in	 Â the	 Â community	 Â (Health	 Â and	 Â Safety	 Â Code	 Â Section	 Â 50675.14).	 Â 
"Transitional	 Â  housing"	 Â  and	 Â  "transitional	 Â  housing	 Â  development"	 Â  mean	 Â  buildings	 Â  configured	 Â  as	 Â  rental	 Â

assistance	 Â  and	 Â  recirculation	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  assisted	 Â  unit	 Â  to	 Â  another	 Â  eligible	 Â  program	 Â  recipient	 Â  at	 Â  some	 Â 
predetermined	 Â  future	 Â  point	 Â  in	 Â  time,	 Â  which	 Â  shall	 Â  be	 Â  no	 Â  less	 Â  than	 Â  six	 Â  months	 Â  (Health	 Â  and	 Â  Safety	 Â  Code	 Â

State	 Â  law	 Â  requires	 Â  the	 Â  consideration	 Â  of	 Â  both	 Â  supportive	 Â  and	 Â  transitional	 Â  housing	 Â  as	 Â  residential	 Â  uses	 Â  that	 Â 
must	 Â only	 Â be	 Â subject	 Â to	 Â the	 Â same	 Â restrictions	 Â that	 Â apply	 Â to	 Â similar	 Â housing	 Â types	 Â in	 Â the	 Â same	 Â zone.	 Â While	 Â

to	 Â  those	 Â  restrictions	 Â  that	 Â  apply	 Â  to	 Â  other	 Â  residential	 Â  uses	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  same	 Â  type	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  same	 Â  zone.	 Â  The	 Â

	 Â 
implementation	 Â program	 Â will	 Â result	 Â in	 Â a	 Â revision	 Â to	 Â the	 Â Land	 Â Use	 Â Code	 Â to	 Â bring	 Â it	 Â into	 Â consistency	 Â with	 Â

â€œEmergency	 Â  shelterâ€	 Â  means	 Â  housing	 Â  with	 Â  minimal	 Â  supportive	 Â  services	 Â  for	 Â  homeless	 Â  persons	 Â  that	 Â  is	 Â

use	 Â to	 Â specific	 Â sites	 Â identified	 Â in	 Â the	 Â 2002	 Â Housing	 Â Element.	 Â 	 Â There	 Â are	 Â no	 Â additional	 Â standards	 Â identified	 Â 
for	 Â  an	 Â  emergency	 Â  shelter	 Â  â€“	 Â  the	 Â  use	 Â  is	 Â  subject	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  same	 Â  zoning	 Â  clearance	 Â  and	 Â  design	 Â  review	 Â

acres	 Â  in	 Â  size.	 Â  	 Â  These	 Â  sites	 Â  have	 Â  more	 Â  than	 Â  enough	 Â  potential	 Â  capacity	 Â  to	 Â  accommodate	 Â  the	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â

Housing	 Â Opportunities	 Â for	 Â Extremely	 Â Low	 Â Income	 Â Households	 Â

     2-Â­â€20	 Â      Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report|	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â

                                                	 Â                                                                        2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
discussed	 Â in	 Â Chapter	 Â 3,	 Â there	 Â are	 Â sites	 Â with	 Â these	 Â land	 Â use	 Â designations	 Â that	 Â accommodate	 Â  multifamily,	 Â 
group	 Â residential,	 Â and	 Â rooming	 Â house	 Â uses.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
Summary	 Â 
The	 Â Cityâ€™s	 Â General	 Â Plan	 Â and	 Â Land	 Â Use	 Â Code	 Â provides	 Â for	 Â a	 Â range	 Â of	 Â housing	 Â types	 Â to	 Â meet	 Â the	 Â housing	 Â 
needs	 Â  of	 Â  families,	 Â  households,	 Â  and	 Â  special	 Â  needs	 Â  groups	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  County.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  Housing	 Â  Plan	 Â  includes	 Â 
programs	 Â  to	 Â  expand	 Â  the	 Â  range	 Â  of	 Â  housing	 Â  types	 Â  allowed	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  and	 Â  remove	 Â  governmental	 Â 
constraints	 Â associated	 Â with	 Â permitting	 Â and	 Â land	 Â use	 Â standards,	 Â as	 Â described	 Â above.	 Â 	 Â 
AFFORDABLE	 Â HOUSING	 Â REQUIREMENT	 Â 
The	 Â Affordable	 Â Housing	 Â Requirement	 Â is	 Â a	 Â critical	 Â component	 Â of	 Â the	 Â Cityâ€™s	 Â housing	 Â program	 Â and	 Â an	 Â active	 Â 
means	 Â  of	 Â  providing	 Â  housing	 Â  affordable	 Â  to	 Â  a	 Â  broad	 Â  range	 Â  of	 Â  income	 Â  levels.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  requirement	 Â  ensures	 Â 
development	 Â  of	 Â  units	 Â  affordable	 Â  to	 Â  households	 Â  that	 Â  often	 Â  have	 Â  difficulty	 Â  finding	 Â  safe	 Â  and	 Â  decent	 Â 
housing	 Â  and	 Â  typically	 Â  end	 Â  up	 Â  severely	 Â  overpaying	 Â  for	 Â  housing,	 Â  living	 Â  in	 Â  overcrowded	 Â  conditions,	 Â  or	 Â  living	 Â 
in	 Â  unsafe	 Â  conditions.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  requirement	 Â  is	 Â  also	 Â  intended	 Â  to	 Â  promote	 Â  the	 Â  socio-Â­â€economic	 Â  integration	 Â  of	 Â 
lower-Â­â€income	 Â households	 Â in	 Â neighborhoods	 Â and	 Â to	 Â disperse	 Â such	 Â units	 Â throughout	 Â the	 Â City.	 Â 	 Â 
The	 Â Affordable	 Â Housing	 Â Requirement	 Â is	 Â also	 Â intended	 Â to	 Â offset	 Â the	 Â negative	 Â effects	 Â of	 Â new	 Â market-Â­â€rate	 Â 
housing	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  provision	 Â  of	 Â  non-Â­â€market	 Â  rate	 Â  housing.	 Â  The	 Â  construction	 Â  of	 Â  above-Â­â€moderate	 Â  income	 Â 
housing	 Â  depletes	 Â  the	 Â  amount	 Â  of	 Â  available	 Â  residential	 Â  land,	 Â  while	 Â  contributing	 Â  to	 Â  rising	 Â  land	 Â  prices	 Â 
because	 Â  of	 Â  a	 Â  greater	 Â  scarcity	 Â  of	 Â  developable	 Â  sites.	 Â  Market-Â­â€rate	 Â  housing	 Â  development	 Â  also	 Â  exacerbates	 Â 
the	 Â affordable	 Â housing	 Â problem	 Â by	 Â creating	 Â greater	 Â needs	 Â for	 Â goods	 Â and	 Â services	 Â typically	 Â provided	 Â by	 Â 
employees	 Â earning	 Â lower	 Â wages.	 Â 
In	 Â Cotati,	 Â developers	 Â of	 Â residential	 Â projects	 Â are	 Â required	 Â to	 Â rent	 Â or	 Â sell	 Â 20	 Â percent	 Â of	 Â the	 Â units	 Â at	 Â prices	 Â 
or	 Â rents	 Â affordable	 Â to	 Â very	 Â low,	 Â low,	 Â and	 Â moderate	 Â income	 Â households,	 Â with	 Â affordable	 Â units	 Â allocated	 Â 
evenly	 Â between	 Â these	 Â three	 Â income	 Â groups.	 Â 	 Â Developments	 Â of	 Â nine	 Â units	 Â or	 Â less	 Â may	 Â pay	 Â an	 Â in-Â­â€lieu	 Â fee	 Â 
rather	 Â  than	 Â  constructing	 Â  the	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â  units.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  in-Â­â€lieu	 Â  fee	 Â  is	 Â  established	 Â  by	 Â  resolution	 Â  and	 Â  is	 Â 
based	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  sales	 Â  price	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  units	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  development,	 Â  ranging	 Â  from	 Â  $150	 Â  per	 Â  unit	 Â  priced	 Â  under	 Â 
$75,000	 Â  to	 Â  $2,400	 Â  for	 Â  units	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  $120,000	 Â  to	 Â  $124,999	 Â  price	 Â  range	 Â  and	 Â  increasing	 Â  by	 Â  $200	 Â  for	 Â  each	 Â 
$5,000	 Â  increment	 Â  over	 Â  $124,999.	 Â  	 Â  For	 Â  example,	 Â  a	 Â  $240,000	 Â  home	 Â  would	 Â  have	 Â  a	 Â  $7,200	 Â  fee	 Â  and	 Â  a	 Â 
$450,000	 Â home	 Â would	 Â have	 Â a	 Â $14,600	 Â fee.	 Â 	 Â While	 Â fees	 Â are	 Â calculated	 Â differently	 Â by	 Â each	 Â jurisdiction	 Â in	 Â 
the	 Â region,	 Â Cotatiâ€™s	 Â fees	 Â are	 Â generally	 Â on	 Â par	 Â or	 Â less	 Â than	 Â fees	 Â of	 Â other	 Â jurisdictions	 Â (e.g.,	 Â in	 Â Petaluma,	 Â a	 Â 
1,700	 Â sq.	 Â ft.	 Â home	 Â would	 Â have	 Â a	 Â fee	 Â of	 Â $7,384	 Â and	 Â a	 Â 2,400	 Â sq.	 Â ft.	 Â home	 Â would	 Â have	 Â a	 Â fee	 Â of	 Â $11,364,	 Â in	 Â 
Sebastopol,	 Â a	 Â 1,700	 Â sq.	 Â ft.	 Â home	 Â would	 Â have	 Â a	 Â fee	 Â of	 Â $9,522	 Â and	 Â a	 Â 2,400	 Â sq.	 Â ft.	 Â home	 Â would	 Â have	 Â a	 Â fee	 Â of	 Â 
$17,000,	 Â  in	 Â  Santa	 Â  Rosa	 Â  the	 Â  fee	 Â  is	 Â  based	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  sales	 Â  price	 Â  of	 Â  a	 Â  single	 Â  family	 Â  home	 Â  and	 Â  would	 Â  be	 Â 
approximately	 Â $11,250,	 Â and	 Â in	 Â Windsor,	 Â a	 Â 1,700	 Â sq.	 Â ft.	 Â home	 Â would	 Â have	 Â a	 Â fee	 Â of	 Â $2,827.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â fee	 Â has	 Â 
not	 Â  been	 Â  updated	 Â  since	 Â  it	 Â  was	 Â  adopted	 Â  in	 Â  1985,	 Â  however,	 Â  the	 Â  ordinance	 Â  provides	 Â  for	 Â  annual	 Â  fee	 Â 
adjustment	 Â  by	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  Council	 Â  or	 Â  by	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  Manager,	 Â  based	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  Construction	 Â  Cost	 Â  Index.	 Â 	 Â 
Developments	 Â of	 Â ten	 Â or	 Â more	 Â units	 Â also	 Â have	 Â alternatives	 Â to	 Â on-Â­â€site	 Â construction.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
Developers	 Â  of	 Â  10	 Â  or	 Â  more	 Â  units	 Â  may	 Â  propose	 Â  to	 Â  construct	 Â  the	 Â  units	 Â  off-Â­â€site	 Â  at	 Â  an	 Â  acceptable	 Â  location,	 Â 
dedicate	 Â land,	 Â or	 Â a	 Â combination	 Â of	 Â on-Â­â€	 Â or	 Â off-Â­â€site	 Â construction,	 Â land	 Â dedication,	 Â and	 Â payment	 Â of	 Â in-Â­â€lieu	 Â 
fees.	 Â  	 Â  If	 Â  a	 Â  developer	 Â  demonstrates	 Â  that	 Â  the	 Â  Affordable	 Â  Housing	 Â  Requirement	 Â  would	 Â  result	 Â  in	 Â  a	 Â  taking	 Â 
(e.g.,	 Â  that	 Â  the	 Â  requirement	 Â  would	 Â  deprive	 Â  the	 Â  property	 Â  owner	 Â  of	 Â  all	 Â  reasonable	 Â  use	 Â  or	 Â  value	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â 
property),	 Â the	 Â requirement	 Â may	 Â be	 Â adjusted	 Â or	 Â waived.	 Â 	 Â 
     2-Â­â€21	 Â              Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report|	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â 
	 Â 

                                                 	 Â                                                                    2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
In	 Â  the	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â  and	 Â  development	 Â  communities,	 Â  there	 Â  has	 Â  been	 Â  much	 Â  discussion	 Â  regarding	 Â 
who	 Â bears	 Â the	 Â cost	 Â of	 Â an	 Â inclusionary	 Â requirement.	 Â 	 Â Depending	 Â on	 Â the	 Â relative	 Â strength	 Â of	 Â the	 Â housing	 Â 
market,	 Â the	 Â costs	 Â may	 Â be	 Â incurred	 Â by:	 Â 
         â€¢      Land	 Â owners,	 Â who	 Â may	 Â receive	 Â a	 Â lower	 Â price	 Â for	 Â their	 Â land	 Â if	 Â developers	 Â are	 Â expecting	 Â a	 Â lower	 Â 
                profit	 Â margin	 Â from	 Â the	 Â inclusionary	 Â requirement;	 Â 
         â€¢      Developers,	 Â who	 Â may	 Â have	 Â to	 Â accept	 Â lower	 Â profits	 Â if	 Â housing	 Â prices	 Â cannot	 Â be	 Â raised;	 Â and/or	 Â 
         â€¢      The	 Â  purchasers	 Â  of	 Â  market-Â­â€rate	 Â  units,	 Â  who	 Â  may	 Â  have	 Â  to	 Â  pay	 Â  higher	 Â  housing	 Â  prices	 Â  if	 Â  the	 Â  local	 Â  and	 Â 
                regional	 Â housing	 Â supply	 Â is	 Â limited	 Â and	 Â prices	 Â are	 Â at	 Â least	 Â as	 Â high	 Â in	 Â areas	 Â outside	 Â the	 Â City.	 Â 
The	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  Affordable	 Â  Housing	 Â  Requirement	 Â  has	 Â  resulted	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  construction	 Â  of	 Â  affordable	 Â  inclusionary	 Â 
units	 Â over	 Â the	 Â past	 Â 10	 Â years,	 Â see	 Â Table	 Â 1-Â­â€30,	 Â and	 Â has	 Â also	 Â resulted	 Â in	 Â the	 Â collection	 Â of	 Â in-Â­â€lieu	 Â fees	 Â that	 Â 
are	 Â programmed	 Â for	 Â the	 Â construction	 Â of	 Â housing	 Â projects	 Â serving	 Â very	 Â low	 Â and	 Â low	 Â income	 Â households.	 Â 	 Â 
During	 Â these	 Â years,	 Â market-Â­â€rate	 Â housing	 Â has	 Â been	 Â affordable	 Â to	 Â moderate	 Â and	 Â above	 Â moderate	 Â income	 Â 
households,	 Â  depending	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  size	 Â  and	 Â  type	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  housing	 Â  unit,	 Â  so	 Â  it	 Â  does	 Â  not	 Â  appear	 Â  that	 Â  the	 Â 
requirement	 Â  has	 Â  resulted	 Â  in	 Â  pricing	 Â  moderate	 Â  income	 Â  households	 Â  out	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  housing	 Â  market.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â 
requirement	 Â  may	 Â  also	 Â  serve	 Â  as	 Â  an	 Â  incentive	 Â  for	 Â  developers	 Â  to	 Â  take	 Â  the	 Â  next	 Â  step	 Â  and	 Â  increase	 Â  their	 Â 
projectâ€™s	 Â share	 Â of	 Â affordable	 Â units	 Â in	 Â order	 Â to	 Â be	 Â eligible	 Â for	 Â an	 Â increased	 Â density	 Â bonus.	 Â 
Inclusionary	 Â requirements	 Â have	 Â been	 Â adopted	 Â by	 Â other	 Â jurisdictions	 Â in	 Â Sonoma	 Â County,	 Â including	 Â Santa	 Â 
Rosa,	 Â  Petaluma,	 Â  Healdsburg,	 Â  Sonoma,	 Â  Sebastopol,	 Â  and	 Â  Windsor.	 Â  	 Â  Jurisdictions	 Â  	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  vicinity	 Â  of	 Â  Cotati	 Â 
have	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â  requirements	 Â  ranging	 Â  from	 Â  10	 Â  to	 Â  20	 Â  percent	 Â  of	 Â  units.	 Â  However,	 Â  most	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â 
other	 Â  jurisdictions	 Â  only	 Â  require	 Â  low	 Â  and/or	 Â  moderate	 Â  income	 Â  units	 Â  be	 Â  provided.	 Â  While	 Â  the	 Â  Affordable	 Â 
Housing	 Â Requirement	 Â does	 Â not	 Â appear	 Â to	 Â price	 Â households	 Â out	 Â of	 Â the	 Â market,	 Â it	 Â may	 Â reduce	 Â the	 Â amount	 Â 
of	 Â  residential	 Â  development	 Â  that	 Â  occurs	 Â  in	 Â  Cotati	 Â  relative	 Â  to	 Â  other	 Â  jurisdictions	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  County	 Â since	 Â  the	 Â 
Cityâ€™s	 Â  overall	 Â  requirement	 Â  is	 Â  higher	 Â  than	 Â  most	 Â  other	 Â  jurisdictions	 Â  and	 Â  its	 Â  requirement	 Â  for	 Â  very	 Â  low	 Â 
income	 Â units	 Â is	 Â also	 Â higher	 Â than	 Â other	 Â jurisdictions..	 Â 
The	 Â Cityâ€™s	 Â Inclusionary	 Â Housing	 Â Fund	 Â includes	 Â in-Â­â€lieu	 Â fees	 Â collected	 Â from	 Â residential	 Â projects	 Â to	 Â meet	 Â the	 Â 
Affordable	 Â  Housing	 Â  Requirement	 Â  and	 Â  non-Â­â€residential	 Â  projects	 Â  consistent	 Â  with	 Â  the	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  Affordable	 Â 
Housing	 Â Linkage	 Â Requirements.	 Â 	 Â At	 Â the	 Â beginning	 Â of	 Â the	 Â 2014/15	 Â fiscal	 Â year,	 Â the	 Â fund	 Â had	 Â a	 Â balance	 Â of	 Â 
$3,370,514.	 Â  	 Â  In	 Â  2014,	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  allocated	 Â  $414,965	 Â  from	 Â  the	 Â  fund	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  5-Â­â€unit	 Â  Habitat	 Â  for	 Â  Humanity	 Â 
project.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
The	 Â  Affordable	 Â  Housing	 Â  Requirement	 Â  does	 Â  not	 Â  appear	 Â  to	 Â  be	 Â  an	 Â  obstacle	 Â  to	 Â  development,	 Â  but	 Â  may	 Â 
constrain	 Â  the	 Â  viability	 Â  of	 Â  some	 Â  projects	 Â  due	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  increased	 Â  costs	 Â  and	 Â  decreased	 Â  profits.	 Â  	 Â  Affordable	 Â 
housing	 Â  projects	 Â  are	 Â  eligible	 Â  for	 Â  density	 Â  bonuses	 Â  and	 Â  incentives,	 Â  as	 Â  previously	 Â  described,	 Â  which	 Â  would	 Â 
off-Â­â€set	 Â  some	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  cost	 Â  of	 Â  providing	 Â  affordable	 Â  units.	 Â  	 Â  Further,	 Â  the	 Â  requirement	 Â  may	 Â  be	 Â  adjusted	 Â  in	 Â 
cases	 Â  where	 Â  the	 Â  developer	 Â  can	 Â  demonstrate	 Â  that	 Â  the	 Â  requirement	 Â  results	 Â  in	 Â  a	 Â  taking.	 Â  	 Â  While	 Â  the	 Â 
Affordable	 Â  Housing	 Â  Requirement	 Â  provides	 Â  flexibility	 Â  in	 Â  how	 Â  the	 Â  requirement	 Â  is	 Â  met	 Â  and	 Â  allows	 Â  for	 Â  a	 Â 
reduction	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  requirement	 Â  for	 Â  projects	 Â  that	 Â  cannot	 Â  viably	 Â  provide	 Â  the	 Â  affordable	 Â  units,	 Â  the	 Â 
requirement	 Â  may	 Â  encourage	 Â  developers	 Â  to	 Â  seek	 Â  to	 Â  develop	 Â  in	 Â  outlying	 Â  jurisdictions	 Â  with	 Â  lower	 Â 
requirements.	 Â  	 Â  This	 Â  may	 Â  result	 Â  in	 Â  a	 Â  decrease	 Â  in	 Â  housing	 Â  production	 Â  in	 Â  Cotati	 Â  relative	 Â  to	 Â  other	 Â 
jurisdictions	 Â  and	 Â  may	 Â  constrain	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  from	 Â  accommodating	 Â  its	 Â  fair	 Â  share	 Â  of	 Â  regional	 Â  housing	 Â  needs.	 Â 	 Â 
The	 Â  Housing	 Â  Plan	 Â  includes	 Â  a	 Â  program	 Â (Program	 Â  2-Â­â€2)	 Â  to	 Â  reduce	 Â  the	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â  requirement	 Â  to	 Â  be	 Â 
comparable	 Â  to	 Â  other	 Â  jurisdictions	 Â  in	 Â  Sonoma	 Â  County,	 Â  which	 Â  will	 Â  remove	 Â  the	 Â  potential	 Â  constraint	 Â  of	 Â 
diverting	 Â  residential	 Â  development	 Â  away	 Â  from	 Â  Cotati.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  reduction	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â 
requirement	 Â  may	 Â  result	 Â  in	 Â  a	 Â  15	 Â  percent	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â  requirement,	 Â  evenly	 Â  allocated	 Â  between	 Â 
lower	 Â  and	 Â  moderate	 Â  income	 Â  households	 Â  or	 Â  a	 Â  12	 Â  percent	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â  requirement,	 Â  evenly	 Â 
allocated	 Â between	 Â very	 Â low,	 Â low,	 Â and	 Â moderate	 Â income	 Â households.	 Â 	 Â While	 Â the	 Â change	 Â to	 Â the	 Â affordable	 Â 
     2-Â­â€22	 Â       Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report|	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â 
	 Â 

                                                   	 Â                                                                   2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
housing	 Â requirement	 Â would	 Â reduce	 Â the	 Â number	 Â of	 Â affordable	 Â housing	 Â units	 Â constructed	 Â by	 Â an	 Â individual	 Â 
project,	 Â it	 Â may	 Â result	 Â in	 Â increased	 Â residential	 Â development	 Â in	 Â Cotati,	 Â which	 Â would	 Â ultimately	 Â yield	 Â more	 Â 
inclusionary,	 Â affordable	 Â units.	 Â 	 Â This	 Â is	 Â particularly	 Â meaningful	 Â as	 Â housing	 Â development	 Â is	 Â occurring	 Â at	 Â a	 Â 
minimal	 Â pace	 Â with	 Â zero	 Â to	 Â two	 Â residential	 Â construction	 Â permits	 Â issued	 Â annually	 Â over	 Â the	 Â past	 Â five	 Â years.	 Â 
SUBDIVISION	 Â ORDINANCE	 Â 
The	 Â  Subdivision	 Â  Ordinance	 Â  (Article	 Â  7	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  Land	 Â  Use	 Â  Code)	 Â  regulates	 Â  the	 Â  subdivision	 Â  of	 Â  land	 Â  and	 Â  real	 Â 
property.	 Â The	 Â purpose	 Â of	 Â the	 Â Subdivision	 Â Ordinance	 Â is	 Â to	 Â adopt	 Â procedures	 Â and	 Â establish	 Â standards	 Â for	 Â 
the	 Â  design	 Â  and	 Â  layout	 Â  of	 Â  subdivisions,	 Â  and	 Â  the	 Â  design,	 Â  construction	 Â  or	 Â  installation	 Â  of	 Â  public	 Â 
improvements	 Â  within	 Â  subdivisions.	 Â  The	 Â  Subdivision	 Â  Ordinance	 Â  implements	 Â  and	 Â  works	 Â  with	 Â  the	 Â 
Subdivision	 Â Map	 Â Act	 Â of	 Â the	 Â Government	 Â Code	 Â and	 Â does	 Â not	 Â create	 Â any	 Â undue	 Â obstacles	 Â or	 Â constraints	 Â to	 Â 
the	 Â provision	 Â of	 Â any	 Â housing	 Â type.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
BUILDING	 Â CODES	 Â 
Building	 Â  Codes	 Â  regulate	 Â  the	 Â  erection,	 Â  construction,	 Â  enlargement,	 Â  alteration,	 Â  repair,	 Â  moving,	 Â  removal,	 Â 
demolition,	 Â conversion,	 Â occupancy,	 Â equipment,	 Â wiring,	 Â plumbing,	 Â height,	 Â area,	 Â use	 Â and	 Â maintenance	 Â of	 Â 
all	 Â buildings	 Â and/or	 Â structures.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â City	 Â has	 Â adopted	 Â the	 Â current	 Â State	 Â building	 Â and	 Â fire	 Â codes	 Â contained	 Â 
in	 Â  the	 Â  2013	 Â  California	 Â  Building	 Â  Standards	 Â  Code,	 Â  Title	 Â  24,	 Â  including	 Â  the	 Â  California	 Â  Green	 Â  Building	 Â 
Standards	 Â  Code	 Â  (CalGreen),	 Â  and	 Â  other	 Â  uniform	 Â  codes,	 Â  including	 Â  the	 Â  California	 Â  Electric	 Â  Code,	 Â  California	 Â 
Mechanical	 Â Code,	 Â California	 Â Plumbing	 Â Code,	 Â California	 Â Energy	 Â Code,	 Â California	 Â Historical	 Â Building	 Â Code,	 Â 
and	 Â  California	 Â  Fire	 Â  Code,	 Â  with	 Â  amendments	 Â  necessary	 Â  to	 Â  address	 Â  the	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  climatic,	 Â  geological,	 Â 
topographical,	 Â  and	 Â  health	 Â  and	 Â  safety	 Â  conditions.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  amendments	 Â  address	 Â  size	 Â  and	 Â  height	 Â  of	 Â  accessory	 Â 
structures;	 Â  maximum	 Â  height	 Â  of	 Â  driveways	 Â  and	 Â  sidewalks	 Â  above	 Â  grade;	 Â  penalties	 Â  associated	 Â  with	 Â 
commencing	 Â  work	 Â  without	 Â  permit	 Â  issuance;	 Â  re-Â­â€inspection	 Â  provisions;	 Â  and	 Â  the	 Â  requirement	 Â  that	 Â 
additions	 Â to	 Â existing	 Â residential	 Â buildings	 Â that	 Â increase	 Â the	 Â square	 Â footage	 Â by	 Â 50%	 Â or	 Â greater	 Â or	 Â increase	 Â 
the	 Â  value	 Â  beyond	 Â  a	 Â  specified	 Â  level	 Â  shall	 Â  meet	 Â  the	 Â  requirements	 Â  for	 Â  a	 Â  newly	 Â  constructed	 Â  building.	 Â  	 Â  In	 Â 
order	 Â to	 Â ensure	 Â that	 Â buildings	 Â and	 Â structures	 Â may	 Â be	 Â maintained	 Â and	 Â upgraded	 Â without	 Â undue	 Â costs,	 Â the	 Â 
City	 Â does	 Â not	 Â require	 Â renovations	 Â constituting	 Â 50	 Â percent	 Â or	 Â less	 Â of	 Â the	 Â assessed	 Â value	 Â of	 Â the	 Â building	 Â 
and	 Â  50	 Â  percent	 Â  or	 Â  less	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  building	 Â  area	 Â  to	 Â  meet	 Â  current	 Â  building	 Â  codes.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  amendments	 Â  do	 Â  not	 Â 
constrain	 Â  housing	 Â  development	 Â  and	 Â  are	 Â  comparable	 Â  to	 Â  those	 Â  adopted	 Â  by	 Â  other	 Â  jurisdictions	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â 
County.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
With	 Â  adoption	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  CalGreen	 Â  code,	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  discontinued	 Â  its	 Â  Sustainable	 Â  Building	 Â  Program.	 Â  	 Â  New	 Â 
development	 Â  projects	 Â  are	 Â  required	 Â  to	 Â  comply	 Â  with	 Â  the	 Â  Tier	 Â  1	 Â  CalGreen	 Â  requirements.	 Â  	 Â  These	 Â 
requirements	 Â  include	 Â  mandatory	 Â  requirements	 Â  as	 Â  well	 Â  as	 Â  a	 Â  list	 Â  of	 Â  alternatives	 Â  that	 Â  a	 Â  developer	 Â  may	 Â 
choose.	 Â  	 Â  This	 Â  uniform	 Â  State-Â­â€wide	 Â  green	 Â  building	 Â  code	 Â  provides	 Â  developers	 Â  with	 Â  consistency	 Â  from	 Â 
jurisdiction	 Â to	 Â jurisdiction	 Â in	 Â addressing	 Â green	 Â and	 Â sustainable	 Â development	 Â practices.	 Â 	 Â 
Code	 Â enforcement	 Â is	 Â conducted	 Â by	 Â the	 Â City	 Â first	 Â through	 Â the	 Â plan-Â­â€check	 Â process	 Â for	 Â new	 Â construction,	 Â 
remodeling,	 Â  and	 Â  rehabilitation	 Â  projects.	 Â  The	 Â  plan	 Â  check	 Â  process	 Â  ensures	 Â  that	 Â  the	 Â  plan	 Â  and	 Â  specifications	 Â 
are	 Â  designed	 Â  according	 Â  to	 Â  code.	 Â  The	 Â  second	 Â  step	 Â  is	 Â  scheduled	 Â  inspections	 Â  during	 Â  construction	 Â  to	 Â  ensure	 Â 
that	 Â the	 Â structure	 Â is	 Â built	 Â to	 Â the	 Â plan	 Â specifications.	 Â Inspections	 Â are	 Â also	 Â conducted	 Â in	 Â response	 Â to	 Â public	 Â 
complaints	 Â  or	 Â  an	 Â  inspectorâ€™s	 Â  observation	 Â  that	 Â  construction	 Â  is	 Â  occurring	 Â  without	 Â  proper	 Â  permits.	 Â  Local	 Â 
enforcement	 Â  of	 Â  these	 Â  codes	 Â  does	 Â  not	 Â  add	 Â  significantly	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  cost	 Â  of	 Â  housing	 Â  in	 Â Cotati	 Â  and	 Â  maintains	 Â  an	 Â 
acceptable	 Â standard	 Â of	 Â health	 Â and	 Â safety	 Â for	 Â all	 Â inhabitants.	 Â 
     2-Â­â€23	 Â      Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report|	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â 
	 Â 

                                                   	 Â                                                                           2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
ON-Â­SITE	 Â AND	 Â OFF-Â­SITE	 Â IMPROVEMENTS	 Â 
Subdivisions	 Â and	 Â multi-Â­â€family	 Â residential	 Â projects	 Â require	 Â on-Â­â€site	 Â and	 Â off-Â­â€site	 Â improvements	 Â necessary	 Â to	 Â 
provide	 Â  services	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  project.	 Â  	 Â  These	 Â  requirements	 Â  include	 Â  constructing	 Â  streets	 Â  with	 Â  curbs,	 Â  gutters,	 Â 
and	 Â sidewalks,	 Â water	 Â and	 Â sewer	 Â lines	 Â in	 Â areas	 Â with	 Â these	 Â services,	 Â electrical	 Â and	 Â gas	 Â lines,	 Â fire	 Â hydrants,	 Â 
street	 Â lights,	 Â and	 Â drainage	 Â structures,	 Â where	 Â necessary.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
Subdivisions	 Â  are	 Â  required	 Â  to	 Â  provide	 Â  adequate	 Â  access	 Â  and	 Â  streets,	 Â  including	 Â  paved	 Â  access	 Â  roads	 Â  to	 Â  all	 Â 
parcels.	 Â Neighborhood	 Â streets,	 Â which	 Â include	 Â curb,	 Â gutter,	 Â and	 Â sidewalk,	 Â are	 Â required	 Â to	 Â provide	 Â a	 Â total	 Â 
right-Â­â€of-Â­â€way	 Â of	 Â 56	 Â feet,	 Â which	 Â includes	 Â 30	 Â feet	 Â of	 Â pavement	 Â (two	 Â 8-Â­â€foot	 Â vehicle	 Â traffic	 Â lanes	 Â with	 Â seven	 Â 
feet	 Â of	 Â curbside	 Â parking	 Â on	 Â each	 Â side)	 Â and	 Â a	 Â planting	 Â strip	 Â on	 Â either	 Â side	 Â of	 Â the	 Â pavement.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
Residential	 Â  developments	 Â  that	 Â  are	 Â  included	 Â  in	 Â  a	 Â  mixed-Â­â€use	 Â  project	 Â  in	 Â  a	 Â  commercial	 Â  area	 Â  are	 Â  required	 Â  to	 Â 
provide	 Â streets	 Â to	 Â commercial	 Â street	 Â design	 Â standards.	 Â 	 Â Commercial	 Â streets,	 Â which	 Â include	 Â curb,	 Â gutter,	 Â 
and	 Â  sidewalk,	 Â  are	 Â  required	 Â  to	 Â  provide	 Â  a	 Â  total	 Â  right-Â­â€of-Â­â€way	 Â  of	 Â  68	 Â  to	 Â  80	 Â  feet,	 Â  which	 Â  includes	 Â  48	 Â  feet	 Â  of	 Â 
pavement	 Â (two	 Â or	 Â four	 Â 11-Â­â€foot	 Â vehicle	 Â traffic	 Â lanes	 Â with	 Â a	 Â 4-Â­â€	 Â to	 Â 6-Â­â€foot	 Â bike	 Â lane	 Â and	 Â 7	 Â feet	 Â of	 Â on-Â­â€street	 Â 
parking	 Â on	 Â each	 Â side	 Â of	 Â the	 Â street)	 Â and	 Â a	 Â planting	 Â strip	 Â on	 Â either	 Â side	 Â of	 Â the	 Â pavement.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
Sites	 Â appropriate	 Â for	 Â subdivisions	 Â and	 Â multi-Â­â€family	 Â developments	 Â are	 Â typically	 Â located	 Â in	 Â or	 Â adjacent	 Â to	 Â 
areas	 Â  served	 Â  by	 Â  public	 Â  water	 Â  and	 Â  sewer.	 Â  	 Â  Subdivisions	 Â  and	 Â  multi-Â­â€family	 Â  developments	 Â  serviced	 Â  by	 Â  public	 Â 
infrastructure	 Â  must	 Â  provide	 Â  on-Â­â€site	 Â  water,	 Â  sewer,	 Â  and	 Â  drainage	 Â  improvements,	 Â  and	 Â  also	 Â  construct	 Â 
connections	 Â to	 Â the	 Â existing	 Â water	 Â and	 Â sewer	 Â lines.	 Â 	 Â 
Development	 Â  of	 Â  single	 Â  family	 Â  homes	 Â  on	 Â  existing	 Â  lots	 Â  requires	 Â  connection	 Â  to	 Â  an	 Â  existing	 Â  road,	 Â  water	 Â 
service,	 Â sanitary	 Â sewer	 Â service,	 Â and	 Â gas	 Â and	 Â electric	 Â utilities.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â Cityâ€™s	 Â on-Â­â€site	 Â and	 Â off-Â­â€site	 Â improvement	 Â 
requirements	 Â are	 Â appropriate	 Â for	 Â public	 Â health	 Â and	 Â safety	 Â needs,	 Â including	 Â adequate	 Â circulation,	 Â water	 Â 
service,	 Â  and	 Â  sewer	 Â  service,	 Â  and	 Â  do	 Â  not	 Â  create	 Â  any	 Â  undue	 Â  obstacles	 Â  or	 Â  constraints	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  provision	 Â  of	 Â  any	 Â 
housing	 Â type.	 Â 	 Â 
URBAN	 Â GROWTH	 Â BOUNDARY	 Â 
The	 Â  Cotati	 Â  Urban	 Â  Growth	 Â  Boundary	 Â  (UGB)	 Â  was	 Â  adopted	 Â  by	 Â  City	 Â  voters	 Â  in	 Â  1991	 Â  and	 Â  amended	 Â  in	 Â  1998.	 Â 	 Â 
The	 Â  UGB	 Â  generally	 Â  follows	 Â  the	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  Sphere	 Â  of	 Â  Influence	 Â  (SOI)	 Â  boundary,	 Â  with	 Â  the	 Â  exception	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â 
westernmost	 Â  and	 Â  northernmost	 Â  sections	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  UGB,	 Â  which	 Â  go	 Â  beyond	 Â  the	 Â  SOI.	 Â  The	 Â  UGB	 Â  promotes	 Â  a	 Â 
compact	 Â  urban	 Â  form	 Â  that	 Â  ensures	 Â  the	 Â  efficient	 Â  provision	 Â  of	 Â  services	 Â  while	 Â  preserving	 Â  agricultural	 Â  and	 Â 
open	 Â  space	 Â  outside	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  boundary.	 Â  The	 Â  boundary	 Â  can	 Â  only	 Â  be	 Â  amended	 Â  by	 Â  a	 Â  majority	 Â  vote	 Â  of	 Â  City	 Â 
voters	 Â  or	 Â  to	 Â  accommodate	 Â  additional	 Â  lands	 Â  for	 Â  residential	 Â  use	 Â  to	 Â  comply	 Â  with	 Â  State	 Â  Housing	 Â  Element	 Â 
law.	 Â  	 Â  Although	 Â  the	 Â  UGB	 Â  contains	 Â  properties	 Â  outside	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  current	 Â  city	 Â  limits	 Â  that	 Â  could	 Â  be	 Â  used	 Â  for	 Â 
future	 Â housing	 Â development,	 Â  neither	 Â annexation	 Â of	 Â these	 Â areas,	 Â nor	 Â expansion	 Â of	 Â the	 Â UGB,	 Â is	 Â needed	 Â to	 Â 
provide	 Â  adequate	 Â  sites	 Â  for	 Â  accommodating	 Â  the	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  regional	 Â  housing	 Â  needs	 Â  during	 Â  this	 Â  Housing	 Â 
Element	 Â planning	 Â period	 Â (see	 Â Chapter	 Â 3).	 Â 
GROWTH	 Â MANAGEMENT	 Â 	 Â 
The	 Â City	 Â adopted	 Â Chapter	 Â 17.52,	 Â Growth	 Â Management,	 Â of	 Â the	 Â Land	 Â Use	 Â Code	 Â to	 Â phase	 Â development	 Â so	 Â 
that	 Â  it	 Â  does	 Â  not	 Â  exceed	 Â  the	 Â  resource,	 Â  infrastructure,	 Â  and	 Â  public	 Â  service	 Â  capabilities	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  and	 Â  so	 Â 
that	 Â the	 Â rate	 Â of	 Â development	 Â is	 Â compatible	 Â with	 Â the	 Â character	 Â of	 Â the	 Â City.	 Â The	 Â stated	 Â intent	 Â of	 Â this	 Â policy	 Â 
is	 Â  not	 Â  to	 Â  stop	 Â  or	 Â  discourage	 Â  growth,	 Â  but	 Â  to	 Â  limit	 Â  the	 Â  rate	 Â  of	 Â  expansion	 Â  to	 Â  an	 Â  amount	 Â  in	 Â  keeping	 Â  with	 Â  the	 Â 
financial	 Â limitations,	 Â resource	 Â constraints,	 Â and	 Â aesthetic	 Â goals	 Â of	 Â the	 Â community.	 Â 
     2-Â­â€24	 Â          Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report|	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â 
	 Â 

                                                            	 Â                                                                     2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
         	 Â 
         The	 Â Growth	 Â Management	 Â ordinance	 Â allocates	 Â 100	 Â residential	 Â units	 Â to	 Â be	 Â permitted	 Â each	 Â calendar	 Â year,	 Â 
         with	 Â  a	 Â  minimum	 Â  of	 Â  25	 Â  units	 Â  reserved	 Â  exclusively	 Â  for	 Â  housing	 Â  affordable	 Â  very	 Â  low	 Â  and	 Â  low	 Â  income	 Â 
         households.	 Â  	 Â  Second	 Â  units	 Â  are	 Â  exempt	 Â  and	 Â  do	 Â  not	 Â  require	 Â  an	 Â  allocation.	 Â  	 Â  Allocations	 Â  that	 Â  are	 Â  unassigned	 Â 
         at	 Â the	 Â end	 Â of	 Â a	 Â calendar	 Â year	 Â are	 Â carried	 Â over	 Â and	 Â added	 Â to	 Â the	 Â number	 Â of	 Â dwelling	 Â units	 Â allocated	 Â for	 Â 
         the	 Â following	 Â year,	 Â unless	 Â the	 Â City	 Â Council	 Â determines	 Â that	 Â water	 Â or	 Â sewer	 Â capacity	 Â will	 Â be	 Â insufficient	 Â to	 Â 
         serve	 Â the	 Â additional	 Â units.	 Â 	 Â An	 Â unassigned	 Â unit	 Â allocation	 Â that	 Â is	 Â carried	 Â over	 Â from	 Â one	 Â year	 Â to	 Â the	 Â next	 Â 
         shall	 Â  expire	 Â  if	 Â  not	 Â  assigned	 Â  during	 Â  the	 Â  third	 Â  year	 Â  after	 Â  it	 Â  was	 Â  originally	 Â  allocated.	 Â  	 Â  Prior	 Â  to	 Â  2004,	 Â  there	 Â 
         was	 Â no	 Â carryover	 Â of	 Â affordable	 Â units	 Â and	 Â growth	 Â allocations	 Â were	 Â allocated	 Â by	 Â the	 Â Planning	 Â Commission.	 Â 	 Â 
         As	 Â  part	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  Land	 Â  Use	 Â  Code	 Â  update	 Â  in	 Â  2004,	 Â  the	 Â  Growth	 Â  Management	 Â  program	 Â  was	 Â  streamlined	 Â  to:	 Â  1)	 Â 
         allow	 Â  carryover	 Â  of	 Â  all	 Â  allocations	 Â  (market	 Â  rate	 Â  plus	 Â  affordable),	 Â  2)	 Â  to	 Â  remove	 Â  the	 Â  limitation	 Â  of	 Â  units	 Â 
         allocated	 Â to	 Â small	 Â projects	 Â versus	 Â large	 Â projects,	 Â and	 Â 3)	 Â to	 Â simplify	 Â the	 Â allocation	 Â process	 Â by	 Â giving	 Â the	 Â 
         Community	 Â Development	 Â Director	 Â rather	 Â than	 Â the	 Â Planning	 Â Commission	 Â the	 Â authority	 Â to	 Â allocate	 Â units.	 Â 
         Allocations	 Â  are	 Â  issued	 Â  to	 Â  development	 Â  projects	 Â  by	 Â  the	 Â  Community	 Â  Development	 Â  Director	 Â  on	 Â  a	 Â  first-Â­â€
         come-Â­â€first-Â­â€served	 Â  basis	 Â  as	 Â  part	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  building	 Â  permit	 Â  process.	 Â  	 Â  There	 Â  is	 Â  no	 Â  separate	 Â  application	 Â  and	 Â 
         there	 Â is	 Â no	 Â grading	 Â or	 Â points	 Â system.	 Â 	 Â Once	 Â all	 Â available	 Â allocations	 Â (carryover	 Â allocations	 Â plus	 Â allocations	 Â 
         for	 Â the	 Â current	 Â year)	 Â for	 Â a	 Â year	 Â have	 Â been	 Â distributed,	 Â no	 Â more	 Â allocations	 Â will	 Â be	 Â issued	 Â until	 Â the	 Â next	 Â 
         annual	 Â allocation.	 Â 	 Â It	 Â is	 Â noted	 Â that	 Â there	 Â have	 Â been	 Â unused	 Â allocations	 Â remaining	 Â every	 Â year	 Â and	 Â Cotati	 Â 
         has	 Â never	 Â had	 Â development	 Â requests	 Â that	 Â would	 Â equal	 Â or	 Â exceed	 Â the	 Â number	 Â of	 Â available	 Â allocations.	 Â 	 Â 
         The	 Â Growth	 Â Management	 Â ordinance	 Â has	 Â  not	 Â  affected	 Â  the	 Â  amount	 Â  of	 Â  residential	 Â  development	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â 
         since	 Â  it	 Â  was	 Â  adopted	 Â  in	 Â  1994,	 Â  as	 Â  the	 Â  number	 Â  of	 Â  units	 Â  requested	 Â  has	 Â  never	 Â  exceeded	 Â  the	 Â  amount	 Â 
         available.	 Â Indeed,	 Â the	 Â City	 Â has	 Â averaged	 Â only	 Â 49	 Â units	 Â per	 Â year	 Â for	 Â the	 Â past	 Â eleven	 Â years	 Â (2000	 Â through	 Â 
         2010).	 Â 	 Â While	 Â building	 Â permits	 Â reached	 Â highs	 Â of	 Â 168	 Â in	 Â 2003	 Â and	 Â 107	 Â in	 Â 2000,	 Â the	 Â residential	 Â applications	 Â 
         did	 Â not	 Â exceed	 Â the	 Â established	 Â threshold,	 Â including	 Â carryovers	 Â and	 Â exemptions	 Â for	 Â second	 Â units.	 Â 	 Â Table	 Â 
         2-Â­â€5	 Â summarizes	 Â the	 Â growth	 Â management	 Â allocation	 Â history	 Â from	 Â 2000	 Â through	 Â 2015.	 Â 	 Â Please	 Â note	 Â that	 Â a	 Â 
         very	 Â low	 Â or	 Â low	 Â income	 Â unit	 Â can	 Â be	 Â processed	 Â as	 Â a	 Â â€œgeneralâ€	 Â or	 Â market	 Â rate	 Â allocation,	 Â but	 Â a	 Â market	 Â rate	 Â 
         or	 Â moderate	 Â income	 Â unit	 Â cannot	 Â be	 Â processed	 Â as	 Â an	 Â affordable	 Â unit.	 Â 
                                                            TABLE	 Â 2-Â­5:	 Â 	 Â GROWTH	 Â MANAGEMENT	 Â ALLOCATIONS	 Â

              1A	 Â  â€œGENERALâ€	 Â ALLOCATION	 Â CAN	 Â BE	 Â USED	 Â FOR	 Â A	 Â MARKET	 Â RATE	 Â OR	 Â AFFORDABLE	 Â UNIT,	 Â AN	 Â  â€œAFFORDABLEâ€	 Â ALLOCATION	 Â IS	 Â LIMITED	 Â TO	 Â VERY	 Â LOW	 Â AND	 Â

              2PRIOR	 Â TO	 Â 2005,	 Â THE	 Â AFFORDABLE	 Â UNITS	 Â DID	 Â NOT	 Â CARRY	 Â OVER.	 Â 
         The	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  2014-Â­â€2023	 Â  RHNA	 Â  is	 Â  137	 Â  units.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  entire	 Â  RHNA	 Â  can	 Â  be	 Â  accommodated	 Â  with	 Â  the	 Â 
         allocations	 Â available	 Â in	 Â a	 Â single	 Â year.	 Â Due	 Â to	 Â the	 Â low	 Â amount	 Â of	 Â development	 Â in	 Â recent	 Â years,	 Â there	 Â are	 Â

         remaining	 Â RHNA.	 Â 	 Â Given	 Â Cotatiâ€™s	 Â historical	 Â growth	 Â trends	 Â and	 Â the	 Â continued	 Â effects	 Â of	 Â the	 Â recession,	 Â it	 Â is	 Â

         ordinance	 Â  provides	 Â  adequate	 Â  capacity	 Â  to	 Â  accommodate	 Â  the	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  remaining	 Â  share	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  regional	 Â 
         housing	 Â needs	 Â allocation	 Â and,	 Â thus,	 Â does	 Â not	 Â pose	 Â a	 Â constraint.	 Â 
         DEVELOPMENT	 Â REVIEW	 Â AND	 Â APPROVAL	 Â PROCEDURES	 Â 
         Developers	 Â  must	 Â  secure	 Â  necessary	 Â  approvals	 Â  to	 Â  build	 Â  housing	 Â  in	 Â  Cotati.	 Â  From	 Â  the	 Â  standpoint	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  City,	 Â

         standpoint,	 Â  this	 Â  process	 Â  can	 Â  complicate	 Â  and	 Â  lengthen	 Â  the	 Â  development	 Â  process,	 Â  increasing	 Â  the	 Â  difficulty	 Â 
         and	 Â cost	 Â to	 Â develop	 Â new	 Â housing.	 Â The	 Â following	 Â is	 Â a	 Â brief	 Â description	 Â of	 Â the	 Â process	 Â to	 Â obtain	 Â permits	 Â to	 Â

Zoning	 Â  clearance	 Â  is	 Â  the	 Â  procedure	 Â  used	 Â  by	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  to	 Â  verify	 Â  that	 Â  a	 Â  proposed	 Â  structure	 Â  or	 Â  land	 Â  use	 Â  is	 Â

of	 Â  the	 Â  Land	 Â  Use	 Â  Code.	 Â  	 Â  A	 Â  zoning	 Â  clearance	 Â  is	 Â  the	 Â  minimum	 Â  level	 Â  of	 Â  approval	 Â  required	 Â  for	 Â  a	 Â  development	 Â 
project.	 Â 
Design	 Â Review	 Â 
Design	 Â  review	 Â  approval	 Â  is	 Â  required	 Â  for	 Â  each	 Â  project	 Â  requiring	 Â  the	 Â  approval	 Â  of	 Â  a	 Â  building	 Â  permit,	 Â

signs,	 Â and	 Â trash	 Â enclosures	 Â are	 Â considered	 Â in	 Â the	 Â design	 Â review	 Â process.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â Community	 Â Development	 Â

without	 Â  a	 Â  public	 Â  hearing.	 Â  	 Â  For	 Â  all	 Â  other	 Â  projects,	 Â  the	 Â  Planning	 Â  Commission	 Â  has	 Â  design	 Â  review	 Â  approval	 Â 
authority.	 Â

         â€¢ Provides	 Â architectural	 Â design,	 Â building	 Â massing	 Â and	 Â scale	 Â appropriate	 Â to	 Â and	 Â compatible	 Â with	 Â the	 Â

         â€¢ Provides	 Â attractive	 Â and	 Â desirable	 Â site	 Â layout	 Â and	 Â design,	 Â including	 Â building	 Â arrangement,	 Â exterior	 Â 
                appearance	 Â and	 Â setbacks,	 Â drainage,	 Â fences	 Â and	 Â walls,	 Â grading,	 Â landscaping,	 Â lighting,	 Â signs,	 Â etc.;	 Â 
         â€¢ Provides	 Â efficient,	 Â safe,	 Â and	 Â visually	 Â attractive	 Â public	 Â access,	 Â circulation	 Â and	 Â parking;	 Â 
         â€¢ Provides	 Â  appropriate	 Â  open	 Â  space	 Â  and	 Â  landscaping,	 Â  including	 Â  the	 Â  use	 Â  of	 Â  water-Â­â€efficient	 Â 
                landscaping,	 Â and	 Â native	 Â plants	 Â where	 Â appropriate;	 Â 
         â€¢ Addresses	 Â impacts	 Â on	 Â city	 Â services,	 Â traffic	 Â flows	 Â and	 Â patterns,	 Â and	 Â environmental	 Â considerations	 Â

                policies.	 Â 
The	 Â  Downtown	 Â  Specific	 Â  Plan	 Â  and	 Â  Santero	 Â  Way	 Â  Specific	 Â  Plan	 Â  provide	 Â  specific	 Â  guidance	 Â  regarding	 Â  the	 Â

	 Â 

                                                   	 Â                                                                   2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
proposed	 Â  development	 Â  and	 Â  new	 Â  land	 Â  uses	 Â  assists	 Â  in	 Â  maintaining	 Â  and	 Â  enhancing	 Â  the	 Â  city's	 Â  small-Â­â€town	 Â 
character;	 Â new	 Â uses	 Â and	 Â structures	 Â enhance	 Â their	 Â sites	 Â and	 Â are	 Â compatible	 Â with	 Â the	 Â highest	 Â standards	 Â of	 Â 
improvement	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  surrounding	 Â  neighborhood;	 Â  development	 Â  retains	 Â  and	 Â  strengthens	 Â  the	 Â  visual	 Â  quality	 Â 
and	 Â  attractive	 Â  character	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  community;	 Â  new	 Â  structures	 Â  and	 Â  site	 Â  planning	 Â  promote	 Â  energy	 Â 
conservation;	 Â  proposed	 Â  landscaping	 Â  emphasizes	 Â  native	 Â  species;	 Â  the	 Â  interdependence	 Â  of	 Â  land	 Â  uses	 Â  and	 Â 
circulation	 Â  is	 Â  recognized,	 Â  and	 Â  provide	 Â  for	 Â  an	 Â  efficient	 Â  and	 Â  interconnected	 Â  system	 Â  of	 Â  streets	 Â  and	 Â

standards	 Â and	 Â guidelines,	 Â and	 Â does	 Â not	 Â adversely	 Â affect	 Â community	 Â health,	 Â safety,	 Â aesthetics,	 Â or	 Â natural	 Â 
resources.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
The	 Â  design	 Â  review	 Â  standards	 Â  are	 Â  compatible	 Â  with	 Â  a	 Â  range	 Â  of	 Â  housing	 Â  types	 Â  and	 Â  will	 Â  not	 Â  constrain	 Â 
developers	 Â  from	 Â  providing	 Â  single	 Â  family,	 Â  multifamily,	 Â  mobile	 Â  home,	 Â  or	 Â  other	 Â  housing	 Â  types	 Â  at	 Â  a	 Â  range	 Â  of	 Â 
affordability	 Â  levels	 Â  suitable	 Â  for	 Â  a	 Â  variety	 Â  of	 Â  households.	 Â  	 Â  Design	 Â  review	 Â  is	 Â  typically	 Â  performed	 Â 
concurrently	 Â with	 Â other	 Â planning	 Â and	 Â development	 Â permits.	 Â 
Subdivision	 Â or	 Â Parcel	 Â Map	 Â Approval	 Â 
The	 Â  subdivision	 Â  or	 Â  parcel	 Â  map	 Â  approval	 Â  process	 Â  includes	 Â  the	 Â  filing	 Â  of	 Â  an	 Â  application,	 Â  payment	 Â  of	 Â  a	 Â 
deposit	 Â for	 Â application	 Â processing,	 Â staff	 Â review	 Â for	 Â completeness	 Â and	 Â public	 Â hearings	 Â before	 Â the	 Â Design	 Â 
Review	 Â Committee,	 Â Planning	 Â Commission,	 Â and	 Â City	 Â Council.	 Â The	 Â Planning	 Â Commission	 Â recommendation	 Â 
is	 Â  advisory	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  Council,	 Â  which	 Â  has	 Â  final	 Â  authority	 Â  over	 Â  subdivision	 Â  maps	 Â  and	 Â  parcel	 Â  maps.	 Â 
Depending	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  size	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  subdivision	 Â  and	 Â  specific	 Â  site	 Â  development	 Â  issues,	 Â  varying	 Â  levels	 Â  of	 Â 
environmental	 Â review	 Â are	 Â also	 Â required.	 Â Small	 Â subdivisions	 Â are	 Â generally	 Â exempt	 Â from	 Â the	 Â CEQA	 Â process	 Â 
under	 Â an	 Â infill	 Â development	 Â exemption;	 Â larger	 Â subdivisions	 Â typically	 Â require	 Â an	 Â initial	 Â study	 Â and	 Â negative	 Â 
declaration	 Â  or	 Â  environmental	 Â  impact	 Â  report.	 Â  For	 Â  projects	 Â  processed	 Â  with	 Â  a	 Â  mitigated	 Â  negative	 Â 
declaration,	 Â a	 Â typical	 Â small	 Â lot	 Â subdivision	 Â takes	 Â about	 Â  sic	 Â months	 Â to	 Â process	 Â from	 Â complete	 Â application	 Â 
to	 Â approval.	 Â 
Use	 Â Permit	 Â 
The	 Â  findings	 Â  required	 Â  for	 Â  a	 Â  use	 Â  permit	 Â  are	 Â  the	 Â  same	 Â  for	 Â  all	 Â  uses	 Â  and	 Â  address	 Â  compliance	 Â  with	 Â  the	 Â 
General	 Â  Plan,	 Â  Land	 Â  Use	 Â  Code,	 Â  and	 Â  any	 Â  applicable	 Â  specific	 Â  plan;	 Â  compatibility	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  project	 Â  with	 Â  land	 Â 
uses	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  vicinity;	 Â  physical	 Â  suitability	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  site	 Â  for	 Â  the	 Â  type,	 Â  density,	 Â  and	 Â  intensity	 Â  of	 Â  use	 Â  being	 Â 
proposed;	 Â and	 Â the	 Â health,	 Â safety,	 Â and	 Â welfare	 Â of	 Â the	 Â public.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â findings	 Â criteria	 Â are	 Â the	 Â same	 Â for	 Â any	 Â 
use	 Â  requesting	 Â  a	 Â  use	 Â  permit,	 Â  and	 Â  are	 Â  similar	 Â  or	 Â  less	 Â  restrictive	 Â  than	 Â  the	 Â  conditions	 Â  required	 Â  for	 Â  a	 Â  use	 Â 
permit	 Â in	 Â many	 Â communities.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â findings	 Â required	 Â for	 Â a	 Â use	 Â permit	 Â are	 Â straight-Â­â€forward	 Â and	 Â are	 Â not	 Â 
subjective,	 Â  which	 Â  provides	 Â  for	 Â  certainty	 Â  and	 Â  streamlined	 Â  review	 Â  and	 Â  processing.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  requirements	 Â  for	 Â  a	 Â 
use	 Â permit	 Â for	 Â specific	 Â uses	 Â are	 Â straight-Â­â€forward	 Â and	 Â do	 Â not	 Â unduly	 Â constrain	 Â the	 Â production	 Â of	 Â housing,	 Â 
nor	 Â do	 Â they	 Â increase	 Â the	 Â cost	 Â of	 Â housing	 Â nor	 Â cause	 Â delays	 Â in	 Â the	 Â development	 Â process.	 Â 
Processing	 Â T imes	 Â 
The	 Â  residential	 Â  development	 Â  process	 Â  has	 Â  various	 Â  stages,	 Â  each	 Â  of	 Â  which	 Â  requires	 Â  some	 Â  form	 Â  of	 Â  City	 Â 
approval.	 Â 	 Â Initial	 Â processing	 Â of	 Â a	 Â development	 Â application	 Â depends	 Â on	 Â the	 Â type	 Â of	 Â project	 Â proposed	 Â (e.g.,	 Â 
apartment	 Â  complex,	 Â  mixed	 Â  use	 Â  development,	 Â  subdivision,	 Â  single	 Â  family	 Â  unit,	 Â  etc.)	 Â  as	 Â  well	 Â  as	 Â  whether	 Â 
additional	 Â  requirements	 Â  will	 Â  need	 Â  to	 Â  be	 Â  met	 Â  (e.g.,	 Â  rezoning	 Â  of	 Â  land,	 Â  environmental	 Â  review,	 Â  etc.).	 Â 	 Â 
Therefore,	 Â processing	 Â review	 Â times	 Â can	 Â vary	 Â depending	 Â on	 Â many	 Â different	 Â factors.	 Â 	 Â 
	 Â An	 Â  application	 Â  for	 Â  a	 Â  single	 Â  family	 Â  housing	 Â  on	 Â  a	 Â  lot	 Â  is	 Â  approved	 Â  administratively;	 Â  administrative	 Â  design	 Â 
review/zoning	 Â  clearance	 Â  is	 Â  performed	 Â  by	 Â  planning	 Â  staff	 Â  and	 Â  a	 Â  plan	 Â  check/building	 Â  permit	 Â  review	 Â  is	 Â 
performed	 Â  by	 Â  building	 Â  staff.	 Â  	 Â  Similarly,	 Â  second	 Â  units	 Â  only	 Â  require	 Â  ministerial	 Â  approval	 Â  with	 Â  zoning	 Â 
     2-Â­â€28	 Â    Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report|	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â 
	 Â 

                                                     	 Â                                                                   2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
clearance	 Â performed	 Â by	 Â planning	 Â staff	 Â and	 Â a	 Â plan	 Â check/building	 Â permit	 Â review	 Â performed	 Â by	 Â building	 Â 
staff.	 Â 	 Â A	 Â permit	 Â for	 Â a	 Â single	 Â family	 Â home	 Â or	 Â second	 Â unit	 Â can	 Â typically	 Â be	 Â processed	 Â in	 Â 2	 Â to	 Â 4	 Â months.	 Â 
A	 Â  single	 Â  family	 Â  subdivision	 Â  would	 Â  require	 Â  zoning	 Â  clearance,	 Â  design	 Â  review,	 Â  a	 Â  tentative	 Â  and	 Â  final	 Â 
subdivision	 Â  map,	 Â  and	 Â  building	 Â  permits.	 Â  	 Â  A	 Â  single	 Â  family	 Â  subdivision	 Â  is	 Â  typically	 Â  processed	 Â  in	 Â  24	 Â  to	 Â  48	 Â 
months.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â An	 Â affordable	 Â multifamily	 Â project	 Â in	 Â the	 Â NU,	 Â SPD,	 Â CG,	 Â CD,	 Â and	 Â CE	 Â zones	 Â would	 Â require	 Â zoning	 Â 
clearance,	 Â design	 Â review,	 Â and	 Â building	 Â permits	 Â and	 Â can	 Â be	 Â processed	 Â in	 Â 12	 Â to	 Â 24	 Â months.	 Â 	 Â 
A	 Â  complex	 Â  development	 Â  project,	 Â  such	 Â  as	 Â  a	 Â  large	 Â  project	 Â  that	 Â  would	 Â  require	 Â  a	 Â  rezone	 Â  or	 Â  General	 Â  Plan	 Â 
amendment,	 Â may	 Â require	 Â around	 Â 52	 Â weeks	 Â if	 Â an	 Â environmental	 Â impact	 Â report	 Â is	 Â required	 Â under	 Â CEQA.	 Â 
The	 Â processing	 Â time	 Â frames	 Â are	 Â consistent	 Â with	 Â those	 Â in	 Â other	 Â communities	 Â within	 Â California	 Â and	 Â are	 Â not	 Â 
considered	 Â excessive.	 Â Tables	 Â 2-Â­â€6	 Â presents	 Â the	 Â typical	 Â processing	 Â time	 Â for	 Â a	 Â variety	 Â of	 Â residential	 Â project	 Â 
types	 Â  with	 Â  typical	 Â  planning	 Â  approvals,	 Â  assuming	 Â  that	 Â  the	 Â  project	 Â  does	 Â  not	 Â  require	 Â  a	 Â  zone	 Â  change	 Â  or	 Â 
General	 Â  Plan	 Â  amendment	 Â  and	 Â  that	 Â  the	 Â  project	 Â  does	 Â  not	 Â  have	 Â  significant	 Â  environmental	 Â  issues.	 Â  	 Â  	 Â  Table	 Â  2-Â­â€

	 Â 
                                                                                         TABLE	 Â 2-Â­7:	 Â 	 Â APPLICATION	 Â PROCESSING	 Â TIMES	 Â

     CEQA	 Â Analysis*	 Â                                                                                                        3	 Â â€“	 Â 8:	 Â Initial	 Â Study/Negative	 Â Declaration	 Â 
                                                                                                                                    8	 Â â€“	 Â 12:	 Â Environmental	 Â Impact	 Â Report	 Â 
*The	 Â CEQA	 Â analysis	 Â occurs	 Â concurrently	 Â with	 Â the	 Â primary	 Â entitlement	 Â requested	 Â (Conditional	 Â Use	 Â Permit,	 Â Parcel	 Â Map,	 Â Zone	 Â 
Change,	 Â etc.)	 Â but	 Â depending	 Â on	 Â the	 Â issues	 Â specific	 Â to	 Â the	 Â project,	 Â the	 Â CEQA	 Â process	 Â may	 Â take	 Â longer	 Â than	 Â the	 Â review	 Â for	 Â the	 Â 
primary	 Â entitlement	 Â and	 Â thus	 Â may	 Â extend	 Â the	 Â overall	 Â processing	 Â time.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â processing	 Â times	 Â include	 Â state-Â­mandated	 Â public	 Â 
review	 Â periods.	 Â 
The	 Â  permit	 Â  and	 Â  processing	 Â  requirements	 Â  for	 Â  projects	 Â  in	 Â  Cotati	 Â  are	 Â  straight-Â­â€forward	 Â  and	 Â  do	 Â  not	 Â  pose	 Â 
constraints	 Â  to	 Â  residential	 Â  development	 Â  or	 Â  special	 Â  needs	 Â  housing.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  permit	 Â  and	 Â  processing	 Â 
requirements	 Â  do	 Â  not	 Â  unduly	 Â  increase	 Â  the	 Â  cost	 Â  of	 Â  development	 Â  nor	 Â  cause	 Â  unnecessary	 Â  delays.	 Â 	 Â 
Development	 Â  standards	 Â  are	 Â  clearly	 Â  stated	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  Land	 Â  Use	 Â  Code	 Â  and	 Â  application	 Â  processes,	 Â  such	 Â  as	 Â 
review	 Â for	 Â consistency	 Â with	 Â zoning	 Â clearance	 Â and	 Â design	 Â review	 Â requirements,	 Â are	 Â performed	 Â promptly.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
GOVERNMENTAL	 Â FEES	 Â 
Although	 Â  governmental	 Â  fees	 Â  do	 Â  contribute	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  total	 Â  cost	 Â  of	 Â  housing	 Â  development,	 Â  the	 Â  extent	 Â  to	 Â 
which	 Â  these	 Â  costs	 Â  are	 Â  passed	 Â  on	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  consumer	 Â  depends	 Â  on	 Â  price	 Â  sensitivity	 Â  of	 Â  each	 Â  housing	 Â  type	 Â  and	 Â 
the	 Â  ability	 Â  of	 Â  housing	 Â  developers	 Â  to	 Â  absorb	 Â  such	 Â  cost	 Â  increases	 Â  and	 Â  still	 Â  maintain	 Â  acceptable	 Â  profit	 Â 
margins.	 Â Cotatiâ€™s	 Â fees	 Â are	 Â in	 Â line	 Â with	 Â the	 Â range	 Â of	 Â development	 Â fees	 Â collected	 Â by	 Â other	 Â jurisdictions	 Â in	 Â 
Sonoma	 Â County	 Â and	 Â are	 Â not	 Â considered	 Â high	 Â in	 Â comparison	 Â with	 Â other	 Â local	 Â jurisdictions.	 Â 	 Â 
Government	 Â Code	 Â Section	 Â 66020	 Â requires	 Â that	 Â planning	 Â and	 Â permit	 Â processing	 Â fees	 Â do	 Â not	 Â exceed	 Â the	 Â 
reasonable	 Â  cost	 Â  of	 Â  providing	 Â  the	 Â  service,	 Â  unless	 Â  approved	 Â  by	 Â  the	 Â  voters;	 Â  agencies	 Â  collecting	 Â  fees	 Â  must	 Â 
provide	 Â  project	 Â  applicants	 Â  with	 Â  a	 Â  statement	 Â  of	 Â  amounts	 Â  and	 Â  purposes	 Â  of	 Â  all	 Â  fees	 Â  at	 Â  the	 Â  time	 Â  of	 Â  fee	 Â 
imposition	 Â  or	 Â  project	 Â  approval.	 Â  Table	 Â  2-Â­â€8	 Â  presents	 Â  the	 Â  permit	 Â  processing	 Â  and	 Â  planning/zoning	 Â  fees	 Â  for	 Â

1REQUIRED	 Â DEPOSIT,	 Â APPLICANT	 Â IS	 Â CHARGED	 Â ACTUAL	 Â COSTS	 Â BASED	 Â ON	 Â HOURLY	 Â STAFF	 Â COSTS.	 Â 
Government	 Â  Code	 Â  Section	 Â  66000	 Â  et.	 Â  seq.	 Â  (Mitigation	 Â  Fee	 Â  Act)	 Â  sets	 Â  forth	 Â  procedural	 Â  requirements	 Â  for	 Â 
adopting,	 Â  and	 Â  collecting	 Â  capital	 Â  facilities	 Â  fees	 Â  and	 Â  exactions,	 Â  and	 Â  requires	 Â  they	 Â  be	 Â  supported	 Â  by	 Â  a	 Â  report	 Â 
establishing	 Â the	 Â relationship	 Â between	 Â the	 Â amount	 Â of	 Â any	 Â capital	 Â facilities	 Â fee	 Â and	 Â the	 Â use	 Â for	 Â which	 Â it	 Â is	 Â 
collected.	 Â  Government	 Â  fees	 Â  in	 Â  Cotati	 Â  include	 Â  charges	 Â  from	 Â  the	 Â  City,	 Â  Rancho	 Â  Adobe	 Â  Fire	 Â  Protection	 Â 
District,	 Â and	 Â Cotati-Â­â€Rohnert	 Â Park	 Â Unified	 Â School	 Â District,	 Â as	 Â shown	 Â in	 Â Table	 Â 2-Â­â€9.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
	 Â 
The	 Â  City	 Â  adopted	 Â  these	 Â  fees	 Â  in	 Â  accordance	 Â  with	 Â  the	 Â  nexus	 Â  requirements	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  Government	 Â  Code	 Â  which	 Â 
requires	 Â  that	 Â  any	 Â  city	 Â  which	 Â  establishes,	 Â  imposes,	 Â  or	 Â  increases	 Â  a	 Â  fee	 Â  as	 Â  a	 Â  condition	 Â  of	 Â  development	 Â 
approval	 Â  do	 Â  all	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  following:	 Â  (1)	 Â  identify	 Â  the	 Â  purpose	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  fee;	 Â  (2)	 Â  identify	 Â  the	 Â  use	 Â  to	 Â  which	 Â  the	 Â  fee	 Â 
is	 Â to	 Â be	 Â put;	 Â (3)	 Â determine	 Â how	 Â there	 Â is	 Â a	 Â reasonable	 Â relationship	 Â between	 Â the	 Â feeâ€™s	 Â use	 Â and	 Â the	 Â type	 Â of	 Â 
development	 Â  project	 Â  on	 Â  which	 Â  the	 Â  fee	 Â  is	 Â  imposed;	 Â  and,	 Â  (4)	 Â  determine	 Â  how	 Â  there	 Â  is	 Â  a	 Â  reasonable	 Â 
relationship	 Â between	 Â the	 Â need	 Â for	 Â the	 Â public	 Â facility	 Â and	 Â the	 Â type	 Â of	 Â development	 Â project	 Â upon	 Â which	 Â 
the	 Â fee	 Â is	 Â imposed.	 Â These	 Â fees	 Â were	 Â established	 Â through	 Â the	 Â preparation	 Â of	 Â a	 Â Development	 Â Impact	 Â Fee	 Â 
Justification	 Â Study,	 Â which	 Â includes	 Â an	 Â evaluation	 Â of	 Â the	 Â public	 Â facility	 Â needs	 Â and	 Â the	 Â corresponding	 Â costs.	 Â 
These	 Â fees	 Â are	 Â not	 Â excessive	 Â compared	 Â to	 Â other	 Â fees	 Â collected	 Â within	 Â other	 Â communities	 Â in	 Â California.	 Â

                                                	 Â                                                                            2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
nesting	 Â  and	 Â  foraging	 Â  habitats	 Â  for	 Â  special-Â­â€status	 Â  species,	 Â  are	 Â  located	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  City.	 Â 	 Â  Development	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â

including	 Â  the	 Â  California	 Â  Environmental	 Â  Protection	 Â  Act,	 Â  the	 Â  Federal	 Â  Clean	 Â  Water	 Â  Act,	 Â  the	 Â  Federal	 Â

status	 Â species	 Â and	 Â protected	 Â habitats	 Â can	 Â increase	 Â the	 Â cost	 Â of	 Â the	 Â project,	 Â due	 Â to	 Â mitigation	 Â measures,	 Â

Potential	 Â  hazards	 Â  affecting	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  are	 Â  described	 Â  in	 Â  detail	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  General	 Â  Plan	 Â  Update	 Â  Background	 Â 
Report.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â primary	 Â hazards	 Â that	 Â may	 Â affect	 Â future	 Â development	 Â in	 Â Cotati	 Â involve	 Â flooding,	 Â geological	 Â

units	 Â  built	 Â  to	 Â  flood-Â­â€safe	 Â  standards.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  City	 Â  reviews	 Â  new	 Â  development	 Â  to	 Â  identify	 Â  potential	 Â  flooding	 Â 
concerns	 Â  and,	 Â  if	 Â  necessary,	 Â  requires	 Â  new	 Â  development	 Â  to	 Â  construct	 Â  appropriate	 Â  storm	 Â  drainage	 Â  and	 Â

Development	 Â in	 Â flood	 Â hazard	 Â areas	 Â is	 Â required	 Â to	 Â either:	 Â 1)	 Â obtain	 Â a	 Â letter	 Â of	 Â map	 Â amendment	 Â or	 Â a	 Â letter	 Â

     2-Â­â€34	 Â      Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report|	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â

                                                       	 Â                                                                           2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
While	 Â  the	 Â  approach	 Â  varies	 Â  based	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  BFE,	 Â  it	 Â  is	 Â  most	 Â  common	 Â  for	 Â  a	 Â  site	 Â  to	 Â  be	 Â  developed	 Â  by	 Â  importing	 Â 
fill	 Â  to	 Â  raise	 Â  the	 Â  site	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  level	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  BFE.	 Â  	 Â  This	 Â  approach	 Â  does	 Â  not	 Â  require	 Â  special	 Â  construction	 Â

the	 Â  BFE	 Â  and	 Â  providing	 Â  parking	 Â  at	 Â  lower	 Â  levels.	 Â  	 Â  While	 Â  development	 Â  of	 Â  sites	 Â  within	 Â  a	 Â  special	 Â  flood	 Â  hazard	 Â

Geological	 Â  hazards	 Â  in	 Â  Cotati	 Â  regional	 Â  seismic	 Â  activity,	 Â  liquefaction,	 Â  and	 Â  shrink-Â­â€swell	 Â  of	 Â  soils.	 Â  	 Â  Given	 Â 
Cotatiâ€™s	 Â relatively	 Â level	 Â topography,	 Â landslide	 Â risks	 Â are	 Â low.	 Â 	 Â While	 Â no	 Â active	 Â faults	 Â are	 Â located	 Â within	 Â its	 Â

Andreas	 Â Fault,	 Â Rodgers	 Â Creek	 Â Fault,	 Â Healdsburg	 Â Fault,	 Â and	 Â Mayacama	 Â Fault	 Â are	 Â active	 Â faults	 Â located	 Â in	 Â

in	 Â  specific	 Â  areas	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  event	 Â  of	 Â  a	 Â  seismic	 Â  event	 Â  of	 Â  an	 Â  adequate	 Â  magnitude.	 Â  The	 Â  City	 Â  does	 Â  not	 Â

along	 Â  and	 Â  east	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  Laguna	 Â  de	 Â  Santa	 Â  Rosa	 Â  as	 Â  well	 Â  as	 Â  a	 Â  small	 Â  area	 Â  south	 Â  of	 Â  Highway	 Â  116	 Â  in	 Â  western	 Â 
Cotati	 Â that	 Â are	 Â designated	 Â as	 Â having	 Â a	 Â moderate	 Â liquefaction	 Â susceptibility.	 Â 	 Â These	 Â areas	 Â with	 Â moderate	 Â 
liquefaction	 Â susceptibility	 Â are	 Â generally	 Â associated	 Â with	 Â a	 Â high	 Â shrink-Â­â€swell	 Â potential	 Â in	 Â the	 Â eastern	 Â area	 Â

Local	 Â and	 Â state	 Â regulations,	 Â including	 Â the	 Â General	 Â Plan,	 Â Land	 Â Use	 Â Code,	 Â Building	 Â Code	 Â (2010	 Â California	 Â

N O N -Â­â€G O V E R N M E N T A L 	 Â  C O N S T R A IN T S 	 Â 
Non-Â­â€governmental	 Â constraints	 Â are	 Â those	 Â which	 Â are	 Â generated	 Â by	 Â the	 Â economic	 Â and	 Â social	 Â environment	 Â 
which	 Â  are	 Â  beyond	 Â  the	 Â  control	 Â  of	 Â  local	 Â  governments.	 Â  Some	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  impacts	 Â  of	 Â  non-Â­â€governmental	 Â 
constraints	 Â can	 Â be	 Â offset	 Â to	 Â a	 Â minimal	 Â extent	 Â by	 Â local	 Â governmental	 Â actions,	 Â but	 Â usually	 Â the	 Â effects	 Â are	 Â 
localized	 Â  and	 Â  have	 Â  little	 Â  influence	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  housing	 Â  need	 Â  within	 Â  the	 Â  jurisdiction	 Â  or	 Â  market	 Â  area.	 Â  Non-Â­â€
governmental	 Â  constraints	 Â  to	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â  consist	 Â  of	 Â  three	 Â  major	 Â  factors:	 Â  land	 Â  costs,	 Â  cost	 Â  of	 Â 
construction,	 Â and	 Â availability	 Â of	 Â financing.	 Â 	 Â 
The	 Â  availability	 Â  of	 Â  financing	 Â  is	 Â  affected	 Â  by	 Â  factors	 Â  that	 Â  the	 Â  local	 Â  government	 Â  cannot	 Â  control,	 Â  including	 Â 
capital	 Â levels	 Â of	 Â banks	 Â and	 Â investors,	 Â credit	 Â worthiness	 Â of	 Â borrowers,	 Â and	 Â the	 Â willingness	 Â of	 Â investors	 Â to	 Â 
supply	 Â capital	 Â for	 Â real	 Â estate.	 Â Regional	 Â demand	 Â for	 Â housing	 Â has	 Â a	 Â direct	 Â impact	 Â on	 Â the	 Â cost	 Â of	 Â land.	 Â The	 Â 
local	 Â  government	 Â  can	 Â  either	 Â  limit	 Â  or	 Â  provide	 Â  an	 Â  adequate	 Â  supply	 Â  of	 Â  entitled	 Â  land	 Â  for	 Â  development	 Â  in	 Â 
order	 Â to	 Â meet	 Â the	 Â regional	 Â demand.	 Â Construction	 Â costs	 Â are	 Â affected	 Â by	 Â a	 Â variety	 Â of	 Â factors,	 Â including	 Â the	 Â 
national	 Â demand	 Â for	 Â materials	 Â and	 Â commodities,	 Â and	 Â the	 Â supply	 Â of	 Â local	 Â construction	 Â labor.	 Â The	 Â state	 Â of	 Â 
the	 Â housing	 Â market,	 Â including	 Â land	 Â costs,	 Â cost	 Â of	 Â construction,	 Â and	 Â availability	 Â of	 Â financing,	 Â can	 Â affect	 Â the	 Â 
potential	 Â to	 Â develop	 Â housing	 Â projects.	 Â 	 Â 
California	 Â Housing	 Â Market	 Â Overview	 Â 2001	 Â -Â­	 Â 2014	 Â 
National	 Â headlines	 Â from	 Â 2001	 Â through	 Â 2005	 Â spoke	 Â very	 Â positively	 Â toward	 Â the	 Â housing	 Â market.	 Â It	 Â was	 Â a	 Â 
time	 Â  of	 Â  rapid	 Â  home	 Â  value	 Â  appreciation,	 Â  which	 Â  was	 Â  spurred	 Â  by	 Â  an	 Â  increase	 Â  in	 Â  demand	 Â  for	 Â  housing	 Â  that	 Â 
appeared	 Â to	 Â not	 Â maintain	 Â pace	 Â with	 Â the	 Â supply.	 Â The	 Â increase	 Â in	 Â demand	 Â for	 Â housing	 Â during	 Â this	 Â period	 Â 
     2-Â­â€35	 Â      Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report|	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â 
	 Â 

                                                     	 Â                                                                    2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
was	 Â  fueled	 Â  in	 Â  part	 Â  by	 Â  loose	 Â  lending	 Â  standards,	 Â  population	 Â  growth,	 Â  job	 Â  growth,	 Â  and	 Â  increased	 Â  non-Â­â€owner	 Â 
occupied	 Â  purchases	 Â  (investor	 Â  speculation).	 Â  During	 Â  this	 Â  period	 Â  many	 Â  existing	 Â  homeowners	 Â  refinanced	 Â 
their	 Â  homes	 Â  to	 Â  pull	 Â  out	 Â  equity,	 Â  causing	 Â  their	 Â  true	 Â  debt	 Â  to	 Â  income	 Â  ratios	 Â  to	 Â  reach	 Â  unsustainable	 Â  levels.	 Â 
Additionally,	 Â loose	 Â lending	 Â standards	 Â allowed	 Â many	 Â borrowers	 Â to	 Â purchase	 Â a	 Â home	 Â when	 Â they	 Â would	 Â not	 Â 
normally	 Â be	 Â qualified.	 Â 	 Â 
Home	 Â sale	 Â volume	 Â peaked	 Â in	 Â most	 Â parts	 Â of	 Â California	 Â in	 Â 2005,	 Â while	 Â sale	 Â prices	 Â didnâ€™t	 Â peak	 Â until	 Â later	 Â in	 Â 
2006.	 Â  The	 Â  sentiment	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  national	 Â  headlines	 Â  turned	 Â  negative	 Â  in	 Â  2007	 Â  and	 Â  dramatically	 Â  worsened	 Â  in	 Â 
2008	 Â  as	 Â  a	 Â  result	 Â  of	 Â  high	 Â  foreclosure	 Â  rates,	 Â  low	 Â  sales	 Â  rates,	 Â  home	 Â  value	 Â  depreciation,	 Â  tighter	 Â  lending	 Â 
standards,	 Â high	 Â unemployment,	 Â and	 Â an	 Â increasing	 Â threat	 Â of	 Â a	 Â long-Â­â€term	 Â recession	 Â with	 Â high	 Â inflationary	 Â 
risks.	 Â  Sale	 Â  volume	 Â  and	 Â  prices	 Â  began	 Â  to	 Â  decline	 Â  rapidly	 Â  in	 Â  2007	 Â  and	 Â  2008.	 Â 	 Â  In	 Â  recent	 Â  years,	 Â  the	 Â  housing	 Â 
market	 Â has	 Â shown	 Â signs	 Â of	 Â recovery	 Â with	 Â average	 Â monthly	 Â sales	 Â prices	 Â in	 Â 2014	 Â and	 Â 2015	 Â comparatively	 Â 
higher	 Â to	 Â those	 Â prices	 Â experienced	 Â during	 Â the	 Â low	 Â points	 Â of	 Â the	 Â recession.	 Â 
FORECLOSURES	 Â 
During	 Â  the	 Â  first	 Â  quarter	 Â  of	 Â  2009	 Â  it	 Â  was	 Â  estimated	 Â  that	 Â  30	 Â  percent	 Â  of	 Â  Californians	 Â  have	 Â  negative	 Â  equity	 Â  in	 Â 
their	 Â  home.	 Â  Foreclosures	 Â  and	 Â  short	 Â  sales	 Â  are	 Â  currently	 Â  the	 Â  dominant	 Â  mechanism	 Â  working	 Â  to	 Â  eliminate	 Â 
the	 Â  negative	 Â  equity	 Â  now	 Â  plaguing	 Â  many	 Â  homeowners.	 Â  Homeowners	 Â  that	 Â  sell	 Â  short	 Â  or	 Â  are	 Â  foreclosed	 Â 
upon,	 Â  generally	 Â  receive	 Â  a	 Â  discharge	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  negative	 Â  equity	 Â  in	 Â  their	 Â  home.	 Â  As	 Â  home	 Â  prices	 Â  continue	 Â  to	 Â 
correct	 Â  with	 Â  each	 Â  foreclosure	 Â  and	 Â  short	 Â  sale,	 Â  homes	 Â  become	 Â  more	 Â  affordable	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  overall	 Â  market.	 Â 
Prices	 Â  will	 Â  generally	 Â  continue	 Â  to	 Â  correct	 Â  until	 Â  equilibrium	 Â  is	 Â  created	 Â  between	 Â  housing	 Â  supply	 Â  and	 Â 
demand.	 Â 	 Â 
Notice	 Â  of	 Â  Defaults,	 Â  the	 Â  first	 Â  step	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  foreclosure	 Â  process,	 Â  increased	 Â  steadily	 Â  from	 Â  the	 Â  peak	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â 
market	 Â  through	 Â  2008.	 Â  In	 Â  the	 Â  first	 Â  quarter	 Â  of	 Â  2009,	 Â  Notices	 Â  of	 Â  Default	 Â  stayed	 Â  at	 Â  their	 Â  historically	 Â  high	 Â 
levels,	 Â  while	 Â  Notice	 Â  of	 Â  Trusteeâ€™s	 Â  Sale	 Â  increased	 Â  only	 Â  modestly.	 Â  This	 Â  is	 Â  believed	 Â  to	 Â  be	 Â  in	 Â  part	 Â  from	 Â  the	 Â 
passage	 Â of	 Â SB	 Â 1137,	 Â which	 Â requires	 Â lenders	 Â to	 Â make	 Â contact	 Â with	 Â troubled	 Â borrowers	 Â and	 Â explore	 Â their	 Â 
financial	 Â options	 Â before	 Â foreclosing.	 Â While	 Â data	 Â released	 Â by	 Â the	 Â State	 Â indicate	 Â loan	 Â modifications	 Â have	 Â 
trended	 Â  upward	 Â  significantly	 Â  toward	 Â  the	 Â  end	 Â  of	 Â  2008,	 Â  some	 Â  view	 Â  this	 Â  law	 Â  as	 Â  merely	 Â  a	 Â  delay	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â 
foreclosure	 Â process,	 Â which	 Â is	 Â confirmed	 Â by	 Â a	 Â recent	 Â government	 Â study	 Â indicating	 Â more	 Â than	 Â one-Â­â€third	 Â of	 Â 
modified	 Â loans	 Â were	 Â in	 Â default	 Â within	 Â six	 Â months	 Â of	 Â being	 Â modified.	 Â 
Data	 Â collected	 Â since	 Â April	 Â 2008	 Â indicates	 Â that	 Â the	 Â rate	 Â of	 Â pre-Â­â€foreclosure	 Â activity	 Â and	 Â foreclosure	 Â activity	 Â 
has	 Â  slowed	 Â  in	 Â  Cotati	 Â  over	 Â  the	 Â  past	 Â  several	 Â  years.	 Â  	 Â  From	 Â  August	 Â  2014	 Â  through	 Â  February	 Â  2015,	 Â  there	 Â  were	 Â 
an	 Â  average	 Â  of	 Â  2.9	 Â  pre-Â­â€foreclosures/Notices	 Â  of	 Â  Default	 Â  monthly	 Â  and	 Â  2.4	 Â  foreclosures/bank-Â­â€owned	 Â 
properties	 Â  monthly.	 Â  	 Â  This	 Â  is	 Â  a	 Â  significant	 Â  decrease	 Â  from	 Â  the	 Â  pre-Â­â€foreclosure	 Â  and	 Â  foreclosure	 Â  activity	 Â 
experienced	 Â  in	 Â  2008,	 Â  2009,	 Â  and	 Â  2010,	 Â  which	 Â  experienced	 Â  a	 Â  high	 Â  of	 Â  7.9	 Â  pre-Â­â€foreclosures/Notices	 Â  of	 Â 
Default	 Â monthly	 Â and	 Â 7.2	 Â foreclosures/bank-Â­â€owned	 Â properties	 Â monthly.	 Â

foreclosure	 Â activity	 Â (0.22%	 Â percent	 Â of	 Â units	 Â in	 Â Cotati	 Â compared	 Â to	 Â 0.07%	 Â of	 Â units	 Â County-Â­â€wide)	 Â in	 Â terms.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â
