MORTGAGE	 Â LENDING	 Â 
The	 Â  mortgage	 Â  lending	 Â  market	 Â  also	 Â  enjoyed	 Â  a	 Â  boom	 Â  from	 Â  2000	 Â  through	 Â  2006.	 Â  During	 Â  this	 Â  period	 Â 
refinancing	 Â  hit	 Â  its	 Â  highest	 Â  point	 Â  since	 Â  the	 Â  1990s,	 Â  and	 Â  new	 Â  loan	 Â  products	 Â  such	 Â  as	 Â  the	 Â  interest-Â­â€only,	 Â 
adjustable	 Â  rates,	 Â  negative	 Â  amortization,	 Â  40-Â­â€year	 Â  fixed,	 Â  50-Â­â€year	 Â  fixed,	 Â  and	 Â  subprime	 Â  mortgages	 Â  were	 Â 
created	 Â and	 Â offered	 Â to	 Â borrowers	 Â as	 Â an	 Â alternative	 Â to	 Â the	 Â traditional	 Â 30	 Â year	 Â fixed	 Â prime	 Â rate	 Â mortgages.	 Â 	 Â 
Following	 Â  the	 Â  boom	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  mortgage	 Â  lending	 Â  markets,	 Â  a	 Â  financial	 Â  crisis	 Â  began	 Â  in	 Â  2007.	 Â  Its	 Â  proximate	 Â 
cause	 Â was	 Â the	 Â end	 Â of	 Â the	 Â U.S.	 Â housing	 Â boom,	 Â which	 Â revealed	 Â serious	 Â deficiencies	 Â in	 Â securitized	 Â mortgage	 Â 
products	 Â that	 Â were	 Â offered	 Â leading	 Â up	 Â to	 Â 2006,	 Â particularly	 Â subprime	 Â mortgages	 Â with	 Â adjustable	 Â interest	 Â 
rates.	 Â  Mortgage	 Â  markets	 Â  have	 Â  been	 Â  deeply	 Â  affected	 Â  by	 Â  the	 Â  financial	 Â  crisis,	 Â  with	 Â  a	 Â  historically	 Â  high	 Â 
number	 Â  of	 Â  bank	 Â  failures.	 Â  Some	 Â  banks	 Â  and	 Â  thrifts	 Â  are	 Â  still	 Â  making	 Â  new	 Â  mortgage	 Â  loans,	 Â  but	 Â  they	 Â  have	 Â 
tightened	 Â  terms	 Â  considerably,	 Â  essentially	 Â  closing	 Â  the	 Â  private	 Â  market	 Â  to	 Â  borrowers	 Â  with	 Â  weaker	 Â  credit	 Â 
histories.	 Â 
Fannie	 Â Mae,	 Â Freddie	 Â Mac,	 Â and	 Â Ginnie	 Â Mae	 Â currently	 Â are	 Â the	 Â only	 Â conduits	 Â through	 Â which	 Â mortgages	 Â can	 Â 
be	 Â securitized	 Â and	 Â sold	 Â to	 Â investors.	 Â By	 Â contrast,	 Â in	 Â 2005,	 Â these	 Â three	 Â entities	 Â represented	 Â only	 Â about	 Â 50	 Â 
percent	 Â of	 Â the	 Â securitization	 Â market.	 Â The	 Â ability	 Â of	 Â Fannie,	 Â Freddie,	 Â and	 Â Ginnie	 Â to	 Â continue	 Â to	 Â securitize	 Â 
mortgages	 Â  has	 Â  largely	 Â  depended	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  confidence	 Â  of	 Â  investors	 Â  that	 Â  the	 Â  government	 Â  stands	 Â  behind	 Â 
these	 Â  organizations.	 Â  During	 Â  the	 Â  summer	 Â  of	 Â  2008	 Â  signs	 Â  emerged	 Â  that	 Â  investors	 Â  were	 Â  beginning	 Â  to	 Â  lose	 Â 
confidence	 Â  in	 Â  Fannie	 Â  and	 Â  Freddie	 Â  and	 Â  the	 Â  US	 Â  Government	 Â  began	 Â  purchasing	 Â  debt	 Â  from	 Â  these	 Â  entities	 Â  to	 Â 
help	 Â them	 Â and	 Â the	 Â overall	 Â mortgage	 Â market	 Â maintain	 Â solvency.	 Â 
Until	 Â mid-Â­â€2008,	 Â home	 Â mortgage	 Â financing	 Â was	 Â readily	 Â available	 Â at	 Â attractive	 Â rates	 Â throughout	 Â Sonoma	 Â 
County	 Â  and	 Â  California.	 Â  Starting	 Â  in	 Â  late	 Â  2008,	 Â  it	 Â  became	 Â  harder	 Â  to	 Â  get	 Â  a	 Â  home	 Â  purchase	 Â  loan,	 Â  but	 Â  the	 Â 
average	 Â  interest	 Â  rate	 Â  has	 Â  fallen	 Â  to	 Â  around	 Â  five	 Â  percent.	 Â  In	 Â  particular,	 Â  people	 Â  with	 Â  short	 Â  credit	 Â  history,	 Â 
lower	 Â  incomes	 Â  or	 Â  self-Â­â€employment	 Â  incomes,	 Â  or	 Â  those	 Â  with	 Â  other	 Â  unusual	 Â  circumstances,	 Â  have	 Â  had	 Â 
trouble	 Â qualifying	 Â for	 Â a	 Â loan	 Â or	 Â were	 Â charged	 Â higher	 Â rates.	 Â  	 Â  In	 Â 2015,	 Â the	 Â underwriting	 Â process	 Â continues	 Â 
to	 Â require	 Â a	 Â greater	 Â level	 Â of	 Â scrutiny	 Â than	 Â in	 Â 2000	 Â through	 Â 2005;	 Â however,	 Â mortgage	 Â rates	 Â remain	 Â low	 Â 
(around	 Â or	 Â under	 Â four	 Â percent	 Â with	 Â an	 Â average	 Â rate	 Â of	 Â 3.71	 Â percent	 Â in	 Â February	 Â 2015).	 Â 
Construction	 Â loans	 Â for	 Â new	 Â housing	 Â are	 Â difficult	 Â to	 Â secure	 Â in	 Â the	 Â current	 Â market.	 Â In	 Â past	 Â years,	 Â lenders	 Â 
would	 Â provide	 Â up	 Â to	 Â 80	 Â percent	 Â of	 Â the	 Â cost	 Â of	 Â new	 Â construction	 Â (loan	 Â to	 Â value	 Â ratio).	 Â In	 Â recent	 Â years,	 Â due	 Â 
to	 Â market	 Â conditions	 Â and	 Â government	 Â regulations,	 Â banks	 Â may	 Â require	 Â larger	 Â investments	 Â by	 Â the	 Â builder.	 Â 	 Â 
      2-Â­â€37	 Â     Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report|	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â

                                                    	 Â                                                                     2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
Financing	 Â Costs	 Â and	 Â Availability	 Â 
One	 Â of	 Â the	 Â most	 Â significant	 Â factors	 Â related	 Â to	 Â the	 Â provision	 Â of	 Â adequate	 Â housing	 Â for	 Â all	 Â segments	 Â of	 Â the	 Â 
population	 Â is	 Â the	 Â availability	 Â of	 Â financing.	 Â The	 Â average	 Â mortgage	 Â interest	 Â rates	 Â from	 Â 2000	 Â through	 Â 2014	 Â 
are	 Â  shown	 Â  on	 Â  a	 Â  biennial	 Â  basis	 Â  in	 Â  Table	 Â  2-Â­â€12.	 Â  In	 Â  2000,	 Â  interest	 Â  rates	 Â  for	 Â  a	 Â  30-Â­â€year	 Â  fixed	 Â  rate	 Â  mortgage	 Â 
were	 Â just	 Â over	 Â 8	 Â percent.	 Â The	 Â rates	 Â fell	 Â by	 Â over	 Â a	 Â percent	 Â in	 Â 2001	 Â and	 Â by	 Â another	 Â by	 Â half	 Â a	 Â percent	 Â in	 Â 
2002.	 Â In	 Â 2003	 Â rates	 Â declined	 Â to	 Â 5.83	 Â percent	 Â and	 Â held	 Â under	 Â six	 Â percent	 Â for	 Â the	 Â following	 Â two	 Â years.	 Â In	 Â 
2006	 Â as	 Â home	 Â prices	 Â peaked,	 Â interest	 Â rates	 Â climbed	 Â by	 Â a	 Â half	 Â a	 Â percent	 Â to	 Â 6.41	 Â percent	 Â and	 Â held	 Â over	 Â 6	 Â 
percent	 Â  for	 Â  the	 Â  next	 Â  two	 Â  years.	 Â  Rates	 Â  dropped	 Â  to	 Â  5.04	 Â  in	 Â  2008	 Â  and	 Â  have	 Â  remained	 Â  below	 Â  5.0	 Â  percent	 Â 
from	 Â 2010	 Â through	 Â the	 Â present,	 Â with	 Â average	 Â monthly	 Â rates	 Â in	 Â 2015	 Â remaining	 Â below	 Â 3.75	 Â percent.	 Â

Generally	 Â speaking,	 Â households	 Â can	 Â afford	 Â to	 Â spend	 Â 30	 Â percent	 Â of	 Â their	 Â monthly	 Â income	 Â on	 Â housing.	 Â This	 Â 
figure	 Â  assumes	 Â  that	 Â  the	 Â  household	 Â  does	 Â  not	 Â  have	 Â  an	 Â  already	 Â  high	 Â  debt	 Â  to	 Â  income	 Â  ratio,	 Â  or	 Â  other	 Â  high	 Â 
monthly	 Â  expenses.	 Â  As	 Â  discussed	 Â  in	 Â  Chapter	 Â  1,	 Â  the	 Â  State	 Â  and	 Â  federal	 Â  median	 Â  income	 Â  levels	 Â  do	 Â  not	 Â  always	 Â 
match	 Â  current	 Â  actual	 Â  income	 Â  levels	 Â  in	 Â  a	 Â  jurisdiction.	 Â  A	 Â  moderate	 Â  income,	 Â  three-Â­â€person	 Â  household	 Â  can	 Â 
afford	 Â a	 Â home	 Â sales	 Â price	 Â of	 Â approximately	 Â $324,625	 Â at	 Â an	 Â interest	 Â rate	 Â of	 Â 4.5	 Â percent.	 Â 	 Â If	 Â the	 Â interest	 Â 
rates	 Â  were	 Â  to	 Â  rise	 Â  to	 Â  6	 Â  percent,	 Â  that	 Â  same	 Â  household	 Â  would	 Â  be	 Â  able	 Â  to	 Â  afford	 Â  a	 Â  less	 Â  expensive	 Â  home,	 Â 
$278,085.	 Â 
Land	 Â Costs	 Â 
According	 Â to	 Â the	 Â California	 Â Building	 Â Industry	 Â Association,	 Â the	 Â cost	 Â of	 Â land	 Â represents	 Â an	 Â ever-Â­â€increasing	 Â 
proportion	 Â of	 Â the	 Â total	 Â housing	 Â development	 Â cost.	 Â Since	 Â the	 Â mid-Â­â€1960â€™s,	 Â raw	 Â land	 Â has	 Â cost	 Â significantly	 Â 
more	 Â in	 Â California	 Â than	 Â in	 Â the	 Â rest	 Â of	 Â the	 Â United	 Â States.	 Â Vacant	 Â land	 Â in	 Â Cotati	 Â listed	 Â "for	 Â sale"	 Â is	 Â limited	 Â 
and	 Â  the	 Â  price	 Â  for	 Â  potential	 Â  residential	 Â  lots	 Â  varies	 Â  widely.	 Â  	 Â  Land	 Â  costs	 Â  are	 Â  based	 Â  on	 Â  a	 Â  review	 Â  of	 Â 
information	 Â  available	 Â  on	 Â zillow.com,	 Â  landandfarm.com,	 Â  and	 Â  realtor.com	 Â  in	 Â  February	 Â  2015.	 Â  	 Â  Single	 Â  family	 Â 
lots	 Â  ranged	 Â  from	 Â  $195,000	 Â  to	 Â  $246,000	 Â  per	 Â  lot.	 Â  Larger	 Â  parcels	 Â  designated	 Â  for	 Â  residential	 Â  or	 Â  mixed	 Â  use	 Â 
and	 Â appropriate	 Â for	 Â subdivision	 Â or	 Â multifamily	 Â development	 Â are	 Â priced	 Â from	 Â approximately	 Â $483,425	 Â 	 Â to	 Â 
$1	 Â  million	 Â  per	 Â  acre.	 Â  	 Â  A	 Â  1.81-Â­â€acre	 Â  parcel	 Â  with	 Â  a	 Â  previously	 Â  approved	 Â  6-Â­â€unit	 Â  subdivision	 Â  was	 Â  priced	 Â 
$875,000,	 Â which	 Â equates	 Â to	 Â $145,833	 Â per	 Â lot.	 Â 
Measures	 Â  to	 Â  reduce	 Â  land	 Â  costs,	 Â  which	 Â  are	 Â  traditionally	 Â  available	 Â  to	 Â  Cotati,	 Â  include	 Â  the	 Â  use	 Â  of	 Â  federal	 Â 
Community	 Â Development	 Â Block	 Â Grant	 Â (CDBG)	 Â and	 Â HOME	 Â funds,	 Â state	 Â CalHome	 Â funds,	 Â and	 Â local	 Â Housing	 Â 
Fund,	 Â  as	 Â  well	 Â  as	 Â  the	 Â  use	 Â  of	 Â  government-Â­â€owned	 Â  surplus	 Â  lands	 Â  for	 Â  housing	 Â  projects.	 Â  These	 Â  measures	 Â 
generally	 Â benefit	 Â the	 Â construction	 Â of	 Â assisted,	 Â low-Â­â€income	 Â housing.	 Â 	 Â 
     2-Â­â€38	 Â    Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report|	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â 
	 Â 

                                               	 Â                                                                          2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
Cost	 Â of	 Â Construction	 Â 
Construction	 Â  costs	 Â  include	 Â  both	 Â  hard	 Â  costs,	 Â  such	 Â  as	 Â  labor	 Â  and	 Â  materials,	 Â  and	 Â  soft	 Â  costs,	 Â  such	 Â  as	 Â 
architectural	 Â  and	 Â  engineering	 Â  services,	 Â  development	 Â  fees	 Â  and	 Â  insurance.	 Â  Rising	 Â  costs	 Â  of	 Â  labor	 Â  and	 Â 
materials	 Â  have	 Â  contributed	 Â  to	 Â  non-Â­â€governmental	 Â  constraints	 Â  on	 Â  housing	 Â  development	 Â  and	 Â 
improvements.	 Â  These	 Â  costs	 Â  were	 Â  a	 Â  substantial	 Â  part	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  increased	 Â  housing	 Â  costs	 Â  during	 Â  the	 Â  1990s	 Â 
through	 Â 2005.	 Â Builders	 Â passed	 Â those	 Â increases	 Â along	 Â to	 Â the	 Â homebuyer	 Â or	 Â renter.	 Â As	 Â the	 Â value	 Â of	 Â homes	 Â 
has	 Â turned	 Â downward	 Â over	 Â the	 Â past	 Â few	 Â years,	 Â construction	 Â costs	 Â have	 Â also	 Â begun	 Â to	 Â come	 Â back	 Â down.	 Â 
The	 Â  cost	 Â  of	 Â  residential	 Â  construction	 Â  varies	 Â  significantly.	 Â  A	 Â  large	 Â  production	 Â  homebuilder	 Â  can	 Â  currently	 Â 
build	 Â  a	 Â  very	 Â  modest	 Â  home	 Â  for	 Â  around	 Â  $75	 Â  per	 Â  square	 Â  foot.	 Â  The	 Â  larger	 Â  homebuilders	 Â  are	 Â  far	 Â  more	 Â 
competitive	 Â as	 Â a	 Â result	 Â of	 Â their	 Â larger	 Â national	 Â contracts	 Â for	 Â commodities	 Â and	 Â materials	 Â such	 Â as	 Â lumber,	 Â 
concrete,	 Â pipe,	 Â wire,	 Â windows,	 Â etc.	 Â 	 Â A	 Â smaller	 Â local	 Â contractor	 Â will	 Â likely	 Â incur	 Â costs	 Â of	 Â $100	 Â to	 Â $150	 Â per	 Â 
square	 Â foot	 Â for	 Â a	 Â modest	 Â home	 Â during	 Â 2015.	 Â 
Current	 Â  construction	 Â  cost	 Â  estimates	 Â  for	 Â  multifamily	 Â  homes	 Â  in	 Â Cotati,	 Â  show	 Â  that	 Â  hard	 Â  costs	 Â  account	 Â  for	 Â 
approximately	 Â  65	 Â  to	 Â  75	 Â  percent	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  building	 Â  cost	 Â  and	 Â  soft	 Â  costs	 Â  average	 Â  around	 Â  10	 Â  percent	 Â  (the	 Â 
remaining	 Â  15	 Â  to	 Â  25	 Â  percent	 Â  is	 Â  land	 Â  costs).	 Â  Estimates	 Â  for	 Â  single	 Â  family	 Â  homes,	 Â  hard	 Â  costs	 Â  currently	 Â 
account	 Â  for	 Â  roughly	 Â  65	 Â  to	 Â  70	 Â  percent	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  building	 Â  cost,	 Â  soft	 Â  costs	 Â  are	 Â  10	 Â  percent	 Â  and	 Â  land	 Â  is	 Â  the	 Â 
remainder.	 Â 	 Â 
One	 Â factor	 Â affecting	 Â costs	 Â is	 Â the	 Â use	 Â of	 Â prevailing	 Â wage	 Â labor.	 Â 	 Â Construction	 Â costs	 Â for	 Â a	 Â typical	 Â apartment	 Â 
complex	 Â  are	 Â  estimated	 Â  at	 Â  around	 Â  $200,000	 Â  a	 Â  unit	 Â  for	 Â  prevailing	 Â  wage	 Â  labor.	 Â  It	 Â  is	 Â  estimated	 Â  non-Â­â€
prevailing	 Â  wage	 Â  labor	 Â  could	 Â  decrease	 Â  construction	 Â  costs	 Â  by	 Â  10	 Â  to	 Â  20	 Â  percent.	 Â  Costs	 Â  can	 Â  change	 Â 
dramatically	 Â over	 Â time	 Â based	 Â on	 Â market	 Â conditions	 Â and	 Â inflation.	 Â 	 Â 
Consumer	 Â P reference	 Â 
The	 Â  increase	 Â  in	 Â  housing	 Â  costs	 Â  during	 Â  the	 Â  1990s	 Â  and	 Â  first	 Â  half	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  2000s	 Â  was	 Â  partially	 Â  due	 Â  to	 Â  consumer	 Â 
preference	 Â  and	 Â  lifestyle	 Â  expectations.	 Â  The	 Â  size	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  typical	 Â  single-Â­â€family	 Â  house	 Â  increased	 Â  and	 Â  the	 Â 
amenities	 Â  included	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  housing	 Â  package	 Â  changed,	 Â  as	 Â  well	 Â  as	 Â  the	 Â  number	 Â  of	 Â  bedrooms	 Â  and	 Â  size	 Â  of	 Â 
living	 Â areas.	 Â All	 Â of	 Â these	 Â lifestyle	 Â choices	 Â have	 Â costs	 Â associated	 Â with	 Â them.	 Â 
The	 Â  general	 Â  trend	 Â  in	 Â  consumer	 Â  preference	 Â  in	 Â  California	 Â  from	 Â  2000	 Â  through	 Â  2005	 Â  was	 Â  toward	 Â  larger	 Â 
homes,	 Â smaller	 Â lots,	 Â and	 Â more	 Â attached	 Â home	 Â products.	 Â As	 Â the	 Â real	 Â estate	 Â market	 Â began	 Â its	 Â downturn	 Â in	 Â 
2006,	 Â the	 Â general	 Â trend	 Â in	 Â consumer	 Â preference	 Â in	 Â California	 Â has	 Â shifted	 Â back	 Â to	 Â smaller	 Â homes,	 Â larger	 Â 
lots,	 Â  and	 Â  more	 Â  detached	 Â  home	 Â  products.	 Â  	 Â  With	 Â  the	 Â  market	 Â  showing	 Â  signs	 Â  of	 Â  recovery,	 Â  the	 Â  interest	 Â  in	 Â 
smaller	 Â homes,	 Â townhomes,	 Â and	 Â more	 Â attached	 Â home	 Â products	 Â may	 Â be	 Â renewed.	 Â 
A T 	 Â  R IS K 	 Â  H O U S IN G 	 Â  U N IT S 	 Â 
This	 Â  section	 Â  analyzes	 Â  existing	 Â  or	 Â  potential	 Â  â€œat-Â­â€riskâ€	 Â  assisted	 Â  rental	 Â  housing	 Â  developments,	 Â  which	 Â  are	 Â 
eligible	 Â to	 Â convert	 Â to	 Â market-Â­â€rate	 Â housing	 Â over	 Â the	 Â next	 Â ten	 Â years.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â conversion	 Â may	 Â be	 Â due	 Â to	 Â the	 Â 
termination	 Â  of	 Â  a	 Â  subsidy	 Â  contract,	 Â  mortgage	 Â  prepayment,	 Â  or	 Â  expiration	 Â  of	 Â  use	 Â  restrictions.	 Â  	 Â  â€œAssisted	 Â 
housing	 Â  developmentsâ€	 Â  are	 Â  multi-Â­â€family	 Â  rental	 Â  housing	 Â  projects	 Â  that	 Â  receive	 Â  or	 Â  have	 Â  received	 Â 
government	 Â assistance	 Â under	 Â federal	 Â programs	 Â listed	 Â in	 Â the	 Â Housing	 Â Element	 Â Law,	 Â state	 Â and	 Â local	 Â multi-Â­â€
family	 Â  revenue	 Â  bond	 Â  programs,	 Â  local	 Â  redevelopment	 Â  programs,	 Â  the	 Â  federal	 Â  Community	 Â  Development	 Â 
Block	 Â Grant	 Â Program,	 Â or	 Â local	 Â in-Â­â€lieu	 Â fees.	 Â 
AT	 Â RISK	 Â ASSESSMENT	 Â 
Each	 Â property	 Â is	 Â assigned	 Â a	 Â level	 Â of	 Â risk	 Â of	 Â conversion.	 Â There	 Â are	 Â three	 Â levels	 Â of	 Â risk:	 Â At-Â­â€Risk,	 Â Lower	 Â Risk	 Â 
and	 Â  Low	 Â  Risk.	 Â  At	 Â  Risk	 Â  properties	 Â  are	 Â  at-Â­â€risk	 Â  of	 Â  converting	 Â  to	 Â  market	 Â  rate	 Â  when	 Â  they	 Â  are	 Â  within	 Â  five	 Â  years	 Â 
     2-Â­â€39	 Â     Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report|	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â

                                                	 Â                                                                     2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
of	 Â the	 Â end	 Â date	 Â of	 Â the	 Â most	 Â valuable	 Â subsidy	 Â or	 Â rent	 Â restriction.	 Â Lower	 Â Risk	 Â properties	 Â are	 Â at	 Â lower	 Â risk	 Â 
of	 Â conversion	 Â when	 Â their	 Â most	 Â valuable	 Â subsidy	 Â or	 Â rent	 Â restriction	 Â is	 Â scheduled	 Â to	 Â terminate	 Â within	 Â six	 Â to	 Â 
ten	 Â  years	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  current	 Â  date.	 Â  Properties	 Â  are	 Â  designated	 Â  low	 Â  risk	 Â  when	 Â  their	 Â  subsidies	 Â  and/or	 Â  rent	 Â 
restrictions	 Â  will	 Â  expire	 Â  more	 Â  than	 Â  10	 Â  years	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  future.	 Â  If	 Â  a	 Â  property	 Â  is	 Â  owned	 Â  by	 Â  a	 Â  nonprofit	 Â 
organization,	 Â the	 Â risk	 Â of	 Â conversion	 Â to	 Â market	 Â is	 Â one	 Â level	 Â lower	 Â than	 Â it	 Â otherwise	 Â would	 Â be.	 Â While	 Â this	 Â is	 Â 
not	 Â always	 Â accurate,	 Â on	 Â average	 Â the	 Â risk	 Â of	 Â conversion	 Â is	 Â lower	 Â when	 Â a	 Â property	 Â is	 Â owned	 Â by	 Â a	 Â nonprofit	 Â 
whose	 Â mission	 Â is	 Â typically	 Â to	 Â maintain	 Â the	 Â affordability	 Â of	 Â apartments	 Â for	 Â lower	 Â income	 Â households.	 Â 
Databases	 Â  of	 Â  federal	 Â  and	 Â  state	 Â  agencies	 Â  and	 Â  the	 Â  California	 Â  Housing	 Â  Partnership	 Â  Corporation	 Â  (CHPC)	 Â 
database	 Â  were	 Â  reviewed	 Â  and	 Â  CHPC	 Â  was	 Â  contacted	 Â  to	 Â  ensure	 Â  up-Â­â€to-Â­â€date	 Â  information.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  City	 Â  also	 Â 
reviewed	 Â  its	 Â  records	 Â  for	 Â  assisted	 Â  multi-Â­â€family	 Â  rental	 Â  units	 Â  constructed	 Â  through	 Â  its	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â 
program.	 Â 	 Â Seven	 Â assisted	 Â multifamily	 Â affordable	 Â housing	 Â projects	 Â were	 Â identified	 Â in	 Â Cotati	 Â (see	 Â Table	 Â 1-Â­â€
30).	 Â Four	 Â of	 Â the	 Â assisted	 Â multifamily	 Â projects	 Â have	 Â received	 Â federal	 Â and/or	 Â state	 Â subsidies.	 Â 	 Â One	 Â of	 Â these	 Â 
projects,	 Â Marvin	 Â Gardens,	 Â is	 Â at	 Â risk	 Â of	 Â losing	 Â affordability	 Â as	 Â its	 Â Section	 Â 8	 Â contract	 Â expires	 Â annually.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â 
other	 Â  three	 Â  federal/state	 Â  assisted	 Â  projects	 Â  have	 Â  affordability	 Â  requirements	 Â  through	 Â  2030	 Â  or	 Â  longer.	 Â 	 Â 
Three	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  assisted	 Â  multifamily	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â  projects	 Â  were	 Â  constructed	 Â  through	 Â  the	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â 
Affordable	 Â  Housing	 Â  Requirement.	 Â  	 Â  Of	 Â  these,	 Â  none	 Â  are	 Â  at-Â­â€risk	 Â  of	 Â  expiring	 Â  as	 Â  all	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  projects	 Â  have	 Â 
affordability	 Â  requirements	 Â  through	 Â  2030	 Â  or	 Â  longer.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  at-Â­â€risk	 Â  project,	 Â  Marvin	 Â  Gardens,	 Â  is	 Â  a	 Â  family	 Â 
complex	 Â  with	 Â  37	 Â  units	 Â  (28	 Â  2-Â­â€bedroom	 Â  and	 Â  9	 Â  3-Â­â€bedroom)	 Â  and	 Â  all	 Â  units	 Â  are	 Â  affordable	 Â  to	 Â  lower	 Â  income	 Â 
households.	 Â 
Costs	 Â Analysis	 Â 
State	 Â Housing	 Â Element	 Â law	 Â requires	 Â that	 Â all	 Â Housing	 Â Elements	 Â include	 Â additional	 Â information	 Â regarding	 Â 
the	 Â  conversion	 Â  of	 Â  existing,	 Â  assisted	 Â  housing	 Â  developments	 Â  to	 Â  other	 Â  non-Â­â€low	 Â  income	 Â  uses	 Â  (Statutes	 Â  of	 Â 
1989,	 Â  Chapter	 Â  1452).	 Â  This	 Â  was	 Â  the	 Â  result	 Â  of	 Â  concern	 Â  that	 Â  many	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â  developments	 Â 
throughout	 Â  the	 Â  country	 Â  were	 Â  going	 Â  to	 Â  have	 Â  affordability	 Â  restrictions	 Â  lifted	 Â  because	 Â  their	 Â  government	 Â 
financing	 Â  was	 Â  soon	 Â  to	 Â  expire	 Â  or	 Â  could	 Â  be	 Â  pre-Â­â€paid.	 Â  Without	 Â  the	 Â  sanctions	 Â  imposed	 Â  due	 Â  to	 Â  financing	 Â 
restrictions,	 Â affordability	 Â of	 Â the	 Â units	 Â could	 Â no	 Â longer	 Â be	 Â assured.	 Â 
In	 Â  order	 Â  to	 Â  provide	 Â  a	 Â  cost	 Â  analysis	 Â  of	 Â  preserving	 Â  â€œat-Â­â€riskâ€	 Â  units,	 Â  costs	 Â  must	 Â  be	 Â  determined	 Â  for	 Â 
rehabilitation,	 Â new	 Â construction	 Â or	 Â tenant-Â­â€based	 Â rental	 Â assistance.	 Â 
         1. Acquisition	 Â and	 Â Rehabilitation	 Â â€“	 Â The	 Â primary	 Â factors	 Â used	 Â to	 Â analyze	 Â the	 Â cost	 Â of	 Â preserving	 Â low-Â­â€
                income	 Â  housing	 Â  include:	 Â  acquisition,	 Â  rehabilitation	 Â  and	 Â  financing.	 Â  Actual	 Â  acquisition	 Â  costs	 Â 
                depend	 Â on	 Â several	 Â variables	 Â such	 Â as	 Â condition,	 Â size,	 Â location,	 Â existing	 Â financing	 Â and	 Â availability	 Â of	 Â 
                financing	 Â  (governmental	 Â  and	 Â  market).	 Â  	 Â  There	 Â  is	 Â  currently	 Â  one	 Â  apartment	 Â  complex	 Â  in	 Â  Cotati	 Â  for	 Â 
                sale	 Â that	 Â can	 Â be	 Â used	 Â to	 Â estimate	 Â the	 Â cost	 Â of	 Â acquisition;	 Â a	 Â four-Â­â€unit	 Â complex	 Â on	 Â Lund	 Â Hill	 Â Drive	 Â 
                has	 Â  4,	 Â  2-Â­â€bedroom	 Â  units	 Â  and	 Â  is	 Â  listed	 Â  for	 Â  $775,900,	 Â  an	 Â  average	 Â  unit	 Â  price	 Â  of	 Â  $193,975.	 Â  	 Â  It	 Â  is	 Â 
                anticipated	 Â that	 Â the	 Â per-Â­â€unit	 Â acquisition	 Â and	 Â rehabilitation	 Â cost	 Â for	 Â a	 Â complex	 Â with	 Â a	 Â mix	 Â of	 Â two	 Â 
                and	 Â three	 Â bedroom	 Â units,	 Â similar	 Â to	 Â the	 Â at-Â­â€risk	 Â projects	 Â may	 Â have	 Â a	 Â per	 Â unit	 Â cost	 Â of	 Â $215,000.	 Â 	 Â 
         2. New	 Â Construction/Replacement	 Â â€“	 Â New	 Â construction	 Â implies	 Â construction	 Â of	 Â a	 Â new	 Â property	 Â with	 Â 
                the	 Â  same	 Â  number	 Â  of	 Â  units	 Â  and	 Â  similar	 Â  amenities	 Â  as	 Â  the	 Â  one	 Â  removed	 Â  from	 Â  the	 Â  affordable	 Â 
                housing	 Â  stock.	 Â  Burbank	 Â  Housing,	 Â  a	 Â  local	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â  provider,	 Â  was	 Â  contacted	 Â  to	 Â 
                determine	 Â new	 Â construction	 Â costs.	 Â 	 Â Based	 Â on	 Â recent	 Â project	 Â pro-Â­â€formas,	 Â it	 Â was	 Â estimated	 Â that	 Â 
                the	 Â  cost	 Â  to	 Â  develop	 Â  new	 Â  units,	 Â  including	 Â  land,	 Â  soft	 Â  costs,	 Â  and	 Â  construction,	 Â  would	 Â  range	 Â  from	 Â 
                $300,000	 Â to	 Â $375,000	 Â per	 Â unit.	 Â 	 Â 
     2-Â­â€40	 Â     Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report|	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â 
	 Â 

                                                      	 Â                                                             2.	 Â 	 Â CONSTRAINTS	 Â 
	 Â 
         3. Tenant-Â­â€Based	 Â  Rental	 Â  Assistance	 Â  â€“	 Â  This	 Â  type	 Â  of	 Â  preservation	 Â  largely	 Â  depends	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  income	 Â  of	 Â 
                the	 Â  family,	 Â  the	 Â  shelter	 Â  costs	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  apartment	 Â  and	 Â  the	 Â  number	 Â  of	 Â  years	 Â  the	 Â  assistance	 Â  is	 Â 
                provided.	 Â  If	 Â  the	 Â  average	 Â  household	 Â  living	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  at-Â­â€risk	 Â  complexes	 Â  is	 Â  a	 Â  very	 Â  low	 Â  income	 Â 
                household,	 Â the	 Â affordable	 Â rent	 Â for	 Â a	 Â three-Â­â€person	 Â  household	 Â  in	 Â  a	 Â  two	 Â  bedroom	 Â  unit	 Â  would	 Â  be	 Â 
                $930	 Â per	 Â month	 Â and	 Â the	 Â affordable	 Â rent	 Â for	 Â a	 Â four-Â­â€person	 Â household	 Â in	 Â a	 Â three-Â­â€bedroom	 Â unit	 Â 
                would	 Â be	 Â $1,032	 Â per	 Â month.	 Â HUD	 Â fair	 Â market	 Â rents	 Â for	 Â Cotati	 Â are	 Â $1,370	 Â for	 Â a	 Â two	 Â bedroom	 Â unit	 Â 
                and	 Â $2,109	 Â for	 Â a	 Â three	 Â bedroom	 Â unit.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â difference	 Â between	 Â the	 Â affordable	 Â housing	 Â cost	 Â and	 Â 
                fair	 Â market	 Â rents	 Â would	 Â require	 Â a	 Â monthly	 Â subsidy	 Â of	 Â $440	 Â for	 Â a	 Â two-Â­â€bedroom	 Â unit	 Â and	 Â $1,077	 Â 
                for	 Â  a	 Â  three	 Â  bedroom	 Â  unit.	 Â  The	 Â  subsidy	 Â  necessary	 Â  to	 Â  ensure	 Â  that	 Â  the	 Â  units	 Â  would	 Â  remain	 Â 
                affordable	 Â for	 Â a	 Â 30-Â­â€year	 Â period	 Â would	 Â be	 Â $158,400	 Â for	 Â a	 Â two-Â­â€bedroom	 Â unit	 Â and	 Â $387,220	 Â for	 Â a	 Â 
                three-Â­â€bedroom	 Â unit.	 Â 
Summary.	 Â  The	 Â  acquisition	 Â  and	 Â  rehabilitation	 Â  of	 Â  existing	 Â  units	 Â  instead	 Â  of	 Â  new	 Â  construction	 Â  is	 Â  the	 Â  most	 Â 
cost	 Â effective	 Â approach	 Â toward	 Â the	 Â preservation	 Â of	 Â â€œat-Â­â€riskâ€	 Â units,	 Â as	 Â shown	 Â in	 Â Table	 Â 2-Â­â€13.	 Â The	 Â cost	 Â to	 Â 
provide	 Â a	 Â form	 Â of	 Â tenant-Â­â€based	 Â rental	 Â assistance	 Â is	 Â similar	 Â to	 Â the	 Â cost	 Â to	 Â acquire	 Â the	 Â units.	 Â 
                                                  TABLE	 Â 	 Â 2-Â­13:	 Â 	 Â COST	 Â OF	 Â PRESERVING	 Â AT-Â­RISK	 Â HOUSING	 Â 
                                                                	 Â                                      Marvin	 Â Gardens	 Â 
                                 Acquisition	 Â and	 Â Rehabilitation	 Â                                    $7,955,000	 Â 
                                 New	 Â Construction/Replacement	 Â                              $11,100,000	 Â to	 Â $13,986,000	 Â 
                                 Tenant-Â­â€Based	 Â Rental	 Â Assistance	 Â                                  $7,924,680	 Â 
                               SOURCE:	 Â 	 Â DE	 Â NOVO	 Â PLANNING	 Â GROUP,	 Â 2015	 Â 
Termination	 Â Notice	 Â Requirements	 Â 
State	 Â law	 Â (Â§65863.10	 Â of	 Â the	 Â Government	 Â Code)	 Â requires	 Â notice	 Â by	 Â owners	 Â who	 Â want	 Â to	 Â terminate	 Â their	 Â 
rental	 Â  restrictions	 Â  (Section	 Â  8	 Â  and	 Â  federally	 Â  assisted	 Â  mortgages),	 Â  whose	 Â  restrictions	 Â  expire	 Â  (tax	 Â  credit	 Â 
projects),	 Â or	 Â who	 Â want	 Â to	 Â sell	 Â an	 Â assisted	 Â property.	 Â The	 Â law	 Â applies	 Â to	 Â projects	 Â with	 Â low-Â­â€income	 Â rental	 Â 
restrictions,	 Â including:	 Â 1)	 Â all	 Â types	 Â of	 Â project-Â­â€based	 Â Section	 Â 8	 Â developments;	 Â 2)	 Â projects	 Â with	 Â mortgages	 Â 
financed	 Â through	 Â the	 Â Section	 Â 221	 Â (d)	 Â (3)	 Â BMIR,	 Â Section	 Â 236,	 Â Section	 Â 202	 Â programs	 Â or	 Â Section	 Â 515;	 Â and	 Â 3)	 Â 
projects	 Â that	 Â have	 Â received	 Â an	 Â allocation	 Â of	 Â tax	 Â credits	 Â under	 Â Section	 Â 42.	 Â 
Two	 Â  notices	 Â  are	 Â  required:	 Â  one	 Â  at	 Â  twelve	 Â  months	 Â  prior	 Â  to	 Â  termination	 Â  or	 Â  expiration	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  restrictions,	 Â 
and	 Â a	 Â second	 Â notice	 Â at	 Â six	 Â months.	 Â The	 Â purpose	 Â of	 Â these	 Â notices	 Â is	 Â to	 Â inform	 Â tenants,	 Â local	 Â governments,	 Â 
local	 Â housing	 Â authorities,	 Â and	 Â the	 Â California	 Â Department	 Â of	 Â Housing	 Â and	 Â Community	 Â Development	 Â (HCD)	 Â 
of	 Â the	 Â ownerâ€™s	 Â intention	 Â to	 Â terminate	 Â restrictions.	 Â 
California	 Â  law	 Â  also	 Â  contains	 Â  an	 Â  â€œoption	 Â  to	 Â  make	 Â  an	 Â  offer	 Â  to	 Â  purchaseâ€	 Â  (Section	 Â  65863.11	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â 
Government	 Â  Code).	 Â  The	 Â  purpose	 Â  of	 Â  this	 Â  provision	 Â  is	 Â  to	 Â  provide	 Â  buyers	 Â  willing	 Â  to	 Â  preserve	 Â  an	 Â  assisted	 Â 
project	 Â  with	 Â  an	 Â  opportunity	 Â  to	 Â  try	 Â  to	 Â  purchase	 Â  the	 Â  development	 Â  from	 Â  the	 Â  seller.	 Â  An	 Â  owner	 Â  who	 Â  chooses	 Â 
to	 Â  terminate	 Â  rental	 Â  restrictions	 Â  or	 Â  whose	 Â  restrictions	 Â  are	 Â  expiring	 Â  is	 Â  required	 Â  to	 Â  provide	 Â  a	 Â  notice	 Â  to	 Â 
potential	 Â  qualified	 Â  buyers.	 Â  An	 Â  owner	 Â  with	 Â  an	 Â  assisted	 Â  project	 Â  also	 Â  must	 Â  provide	 Â  notice	 Â  if	 Â  selling	 Â  the	 Â 
project	 Â would	 Â result	 Â in	 Â discontinuance	 Â of	 Â the	 Â use	 Â restrictions.	 Â 
A	 Â  notice	 Â  must	 Â  be	 Â  sent	 Â  to	 Â  all	 Â  qualified	 Â  entities	 Â  who	 Â  register	 Â  with	 Â  the	 Â  State	 Â  Housing	 Â  and	 Â  Community	 Â 
Development	 Â Department	 Â (HCD)	 Â on	 Â their	 Â website	 Â or	 Â who	 Â contact	 Â the	 Â owner	 Â directly.	 Â This	 Â notice	 Â must	 Â 
be	 Â sent	 Â 12	 Â months	 Â prior	 Â to	 Â sale	 Â or	 Â termination	 Â by	 Â registered	 Â or	 Â certified	 Â mail,	 Â as	 Â well	 Â as	 Â posted	 Â in	 Â the	 Â 
project.	 Â 
     2-Â­â€41	 Â     Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report|	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â 
	 Â

	 Â 
Active	 Â Termination	 Â Notices	 Â

Resources	 Â

3.	 Â               RESOURCES	 Â 
This	 Â section	 Â discusses	 Â resources	 Â available	 Â for	 Â the	 Â accommodation	 Â and	 Â development	 Â of	 Â the	 Â Cityâ€™s	 Â housing	 Â 
needs.	 Â 	 Â One	 Â of	 Â the	 Â most	 Â important	 Â resources	 Â is	 Â adequate	 Â land	 Â to	 Â accommodate	 Â future	 Â housing.	 Â 	 Â Other	 Â

H O U S IN G 	 Â  S IT E 	 Â  I N V E N T O R Y 	 Â 
Regional	 Â Housing	 Â Needs	 Â Allocation	 Â

been	 Â  approved,	 Â  and	 Â  an	 Â  additional	 Â  177	 Â  units	 Â  are	 Â  planned.	 Â  	 Â  After	 Â  considering	 Â  the	 Â  units	 Â  that	 Â  have	 Â  been	 Â 
constructed	 Â  or	 Â  planned,	 Â  23	 Â  very	 Â  low	 Â  income	 Â  units	 Â  remain	 Â  to	 Â  be	 Â  accommodated,	 Â  while	 Â  all	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  low,	 Â 
moderate,	 Â  and	 Â  above	 Â  moderate	 Â  income	 Â  units	 Â  have	 Â  been	 Â  accommodated.	 Â  Table	 Â  3-Â­â€1	 Â  identifies	 Â  the	 Â

remaining	 Â allocation.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â

L A N D 	 Â  A V A IL A B IL IT Y 	 Â

	 Â 

                                                                                                    	 Â                   3.	 Â 	 Â RESOURCES	 Â 
	 Â 
Park	 Â Meadows,	 Â and	 Â mixed	 Â use	 Â projects,	 Â such	 Â as	 Â Cotati	 Â Co	 Â Housing,	 Â Myrring/Jinks,	 Â and	 Â Avila/Young,	 Â have	 Â 
also	 Â  contributed	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â  stock.	 Â  	 Â  Consistent	 Â  with	 Â  the	 Â  requirements	 Â  of	 Â 
Government	 Â  Code	 Â  Section	 Â  65583.2,	 Â  Chapter	 Â  2	 Â  of	 Â  this	 Â  Housing	 Â  Element	 Â  analyzes	 Â  how	 Â  the	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  (adopted	 Â 
land	 Â  use	 Â  regulations,	 Â  including	 Â  zoning,	 Â  density,	 Â  and	 Â  other	 Â  requirements,	 Â  have	 Â  successfully	 Â 
accommodated	 Â  affordable	 Â  projects	 Â  (see	 Â  all	 Â  of	 Â  Chapter	 Â  2,	 Â  with	 Â  an	 Â  emphasis	 Â  on	 Â  Table	 Â  2-Â­â€4	 Â  and	 Â  related	 Â 
discussion).	 Â 	 Â 
The	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  General	 Â  Plan,	 Â  Land	 Â  Use	 Â  Code,	 Â  and	 Â  the	 Â  programs	 Â  in	 Â  this	 Â  Housing	 Â  Element	 Â  will	 Â  ensure	 Â  that	 Â 
affordable	 Â lower	 Â income	 Â housing	 Â will	 Â be	 Â constructed	 Â by:	 Â 
        â€¢       Ensuring	 Â  that	 Â  development	 Â  projects	 Â  provide	 Â  a	 Â  portion	 Â  of	 Â  housing	 Â  units	 Â  that	 Â  are	 Â  affordable	 Â  to	 Â 
                lower	 Â and	 Â moderate	 Â income	 Â households;	 Â 
        â€¢       Providing	 Â a	 Â density	 Â bonus	 Â of	 Â up	 Â to	 Â 35	 Â percent	 Â for	 Â affordable	 Â housing.	 Â 	 Â Rather	 Â than	 Â rezoning	 Â land	 Â 
                to	 Â  allow	 Â  higher	 Â  densities	 Â  which	 Â  would	 Â  immediately	 Â  drive	 Â  up	 Â  the	 Â  price	 Â  of	 Â  land	 Â  and	 Â  also	 Â  could	 Â 
                result	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  loss	 Â  of	 Â  affordable	 Â  sites	 Â  to	 Â  high	 Â  density	 Â  market-Â­â€rate	 Â  development,	 Â  this	 Â  approach	 Â 
                ensures	 Â  that	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â  developers	 Â  can	 Â  develop	 Â  at	 Â  higher	 Â  densities	 Â  without	 Â  paying	 Â 
                increased	 Â land	 Â costs	 Â commensurate	 Â with	 Â higher	 Â zoning.	 Â 
        â€¢       Continuing	 Â to	 Â encourage	 Â affordable	 Â housing	 Â on	 Â the	 Â NM,	 Â NU,	 Â SPD,	 Â and	 Â CE	 Â sites,	 Â which	 Â have	 Â been	 Â 
                successful	 Â in	 Â accommodating	 Â affordable	 Â units	 Â in	 Â the	 Â past.	 Â 
        â€¢       Ensuring	 Â  that	 Â  the	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  land	 Â  use	 Â  requirements	 Â  continue	 Â  to	 Â  reduce	 Â  sprawl,	 Â  encourage	 Â  a	 Â  mix	 Â  of	 Â 
                land	 Â uses,	 Â and	 Â prioritize	 Â affordable,	 Â higher	 Â density	 Â housing	 Â options.	 Â 
        â€¢       Ensuring	 Â that	 Â adequate	 Â sites	 Â are	 Â available	 Â to	 Â accommodate	 Â higher	 Â density	 Â multifamily	 Â projects	 Â 
                (see	 Â Table	 Â 3-Â­â€5)	 Â as	 Â well	 Â as	 Â mixed-Â­â€use	 Â projects	 Â that	 Â include	 Â a	 Â high	 Â density	 Â residential	 Â component	 Â 
                (see	 Â Table	 Â 3-Â­â€6).	 Â 
Realistic	 Â Development	 Â Capacity	 Â 
The	 Â  development	 Â  capacity	 Â  of	 Â  available	 Â  sites	 Â  was	 Â  determined	 Â  based	 Â  on:	 Â  1)	 Â  historical	 Â  and	 Â  recently	 Â 
approved	 Â  projects;	 Â  2)	 Â  densities	 Â  that	 Â  can	 Â  realistically	 Â  be	 Â  accommodated	 Â  based	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  development	 Â 
standards;	 Â and	 Â 3)	 Â input	 Â from	 Â several	 Â local	 Â affordable	 Â housing	 Â developers.	 Â 
Tables	 Â  2-Â­â€4	 Â  and	 Â  3-Â­â€4	 Â  demonstrate	 Â  that	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  can	 Â  accommodate	 Â  its	 Â  lower	 Â  income	 Â  and	 Â  special	 Â  needs	 Â 
housing	 Â using	 Â a	 Â range	 Â of	 Â densities	 Â (6.7	 Â to	 Â 23.7	 Â units	 Â per	 Â acre)	 Â and	 Â housing	 Â types,	 Â including	 Â multifamily,	 Â 
single	 Â  family,	 Â  and	 Â  mixed	 Â  use	 Â  units.	 Â  Affordable	 Â  units	 Â  constructed	 Â  at	 Â  lower	 Â  densities	 Â  were	 Â  often	 Â 
inclusionary	 Â  units,	 Â  provided	 Â  as	 Â  part	 Â  of	 Â  a	 Â  larger	 Â  project,	 Â  or	 Â  a	 Â  small	 Â  affordable	 Â  project	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  NL	 Â  or	 Â  NM	 Â 
zoning	 Â districts.	 Â The	 Â Cityâ€™s	 Â higher	 Â density	 Â NU	 Â sites	 Â were	 Â developed	 Â at	 Â 18	 Â and	 Â 23.7	 Â units	 Â per	 Â acre.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â 
Cityâ€™s	 Â  mixed	 Â  use	 Â  sites	 Â  were	 Â  developed	 Â  at	 Â  10.9	 Â  to	 Â  20.7	 Â  units,	 Â  with	 Â  two	 Â  projects	 Â  providing	 Â  low	 Â  and	 Â 
moderate	 Â income	 Â units	 Â at	 Â densities	 Â of	 Â 17	 Â and	 Â 20.7	 Â units	 Â per	 Â acre.	 Â 	 Â 
In	 Â  order	 Â  to	 Â  be	 Â  conservative,	 Â  this	 Â  analysis	 Â  anticipates	 Â  that	 Â  lower	 Â  income	 Â  units	 Â  will	 Â  be	 Â  accommodated	 Â 
primarily	 Â  on	 Â  sites	 Â  designated	 Â  NU	 Â  and	 Â  SPD,	 Â  with	 Â  additional	 Â  capacity	 Â  provided	 Â  by	 Â  zoning	 Â  designations	 Â  that	 Â 
accommodate	 Â  higher	 Â  density,	 Â  mixed-Â­â€use	 Â  developments.	 Â  Based	 Â  on	 Â  this	 Â  historical	 Â  data,	 Â  it	 Â  is	 Â  realistic	 Â  to	 Â 
anticipate	 Â  that	 Â  the	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  NU	 Â  sites	 Â  could	 Â  be	 Â  developed	 Â  at	 Â  20	 Â  units	 Â  per	 Â  acre	 Â  for	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â 
projects	 Â and	 Â that	 Â the	 Â Cityâ€™s	 Â mixed	 Â use	 Â and	 Â downtown	 Â specific	 Â plan	 Â sites	 Â would	 Â primarily	 Â be	 Â developed	 Â at	 Â 
15	 Â to	 Â 20	 Â units	 Â per	 Â acre.	 Â 
In	 Â  the	 Â  case	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  Downtown	 Â  Specific	 Â  Plan	 Â  (DSP),	 Â  the	 Â  DSP	 Â  was	 Â  approved	 Â  in	 Â  2009	 Â  during	 Â  the	 Â  current	 Â 
economic	 Â downturn	 Â and	 Â no	 Â new	 Â projects	 Â have	 Â been	 Â constructed	 Â in	 Â the	 Â DSP	 Â area	 Â using	 Â the	 Â development	 Â 
standards	 Â established	 Â by	 Â the	 Â DSP.	 Â 	 Â Therefore,	 Â realistic	 Â capacity	 Â for	 Â the	 Â DSP	 Â was	 Â based	 Â on	 Â a	 Â review	 Â of	 Â the	 Â 
     3-Â­â€5	 Â         Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report|	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â 
	 Â 

                             3.	 Â RESOURCES	 Â                                                                                           	 Â 
	 Â 
development	 Â standards	 Â provided	 Â for	 Â each	 Â district	 Â in	 Â the	 Â Downtown	 Â Specific	 Â Plan	 Â as	 Â well	 Â as	 Â discussions	 Â 
with	 Â an	 Â affordable	 Â housing	 Â developer,	 Â Burbank	 Â Housing,	 Â which	 Â is	 Â considering	 Â a	 Â project	 Â in	 Â the	 Â Downtown	 Â 
Specific	 Â Plan	 Â area.	 Â 	 Â 
Input	 Â  from	 Â  local	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â  developers,	 Â  including	 Â  Burbank	 Â  Housing	 Â  and	 Â  Petaluma	 Â  Ecumenical	 Â 
Properties	 Â (PEP),	 Â indicates	 Â that	 Â developers	 Â of	 Â lower	 Â income	 Â housing	 Â typically	 Â need	 Â to	 Â receive	 Â some	 Â sort	 Â

Extremely	 Â  low	 Â  income	 Â  households	 Â  are	 Â  most	 Â  likely	 Â  to	 Â  be	 Â  accommodated	 Â  by	 Â  lower	 Â  income	 Â  multi-Â­â€family	 Â 
developments	 Â with	 Â an	 Â extremely	 Â low	 Â income	 Â component	 Â in	 Â the	 Â NU	 Â zone	 Â and	 Â in	 Â the	 Â Northern	 Â Gateway	 Â 
district	 Â of	 Â the	 Â SPD	 Â zone.	 Â 	 Â Extremely	 Â low	 Â income	 Â units	 Â require	 Â deep	 Â subsidies	 Â in	 Â order	 Â to	 Â make	 Â the	 Â units	 Â 
financially	 Â feasible	 Â to	 Â construct	 Â and	 Â operate.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â smaller	 Â NU	 Â and	 Â SPD	 Â sites	 Â (sites	 Â accommodating	 Â up	 Â to	 Â 
25	 Â  units)	 Â  identified	 Â  in	 Â  Tables	 Â  3-Â­â€5	 Â  and	 Â  3-Â­â€6	 Â  may	 Â  be	 Â  appropriate	 Â  for	 Â  extremely	 Â  low	 Â  income	 Â  and	 Â  special	 Â 
needs	 Â housing.	 Â 	 Â Both	 Â of	 Â these	 Â housing	 Â types	 Â typically	 Â require	 Â deeper	 Â subsidies	 Â per	 Â unit	 Â and,	 Â as	 Â a	 Â result,	 Â 
are	 Â  often	 Â  developed	 Â  as	 Â  smaller	 Â  projects.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  sites	 Â  shown	 Â  in	 Â  Tables	 Â  3-Â­â€5	 Â  and	 Â  3-Â­â€6	 Â  that	 Â  would	 Â 
accommodate	 Â 2-Â­â€	 Â to	 Â 70	 Â unit	 Â multi-Â­â€family	 Â projects	 Â would	 Â also	 Â be	 Â appropriate	 Â for	 Â singe	 Â room	 Â occupancy,	 Â 
multi-Â­â€family	 Â  development	 Â  for	 Â  a	 Â  variety	 Â  of	 Â  household	 Â  sizes,	 Â  small	 Â  group	 Â  care	 Â  facilities,	 Â  transitional	 Â  and	 Â 
supportive	 Â housing,	 Â and	 Â large	 Â group	 Â homes;	 Â all	 Â of	 Â these	 Â project	 Â types	 Â can	 Â be	 Â appropriate	 Â for	 Â extremely	 Â 
low	 Â income	 Â and	 Â special	 Â needs	 Â households.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
Available	 Â  sites	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  NU,	 Â  SPD,	 Â  CG,	 Â  and	 Â  CD	 Â  designations	 Â  will	 Â  accommodate	 Â  extremely	 Â  low	 Â  income	 Â  and	 Â 
special	 Â needs	 Â households,	 Â including	 Â farmworkers,	 Â seniors,	 Â and	 Â large	 Â families.	 Â Farmworkers	 Â may	 Â also	 Â be	 Â 
accommodated	 Â on	 Â agricultural	 Â parcels.	 Â The	 Â Housing	 Â Plan	 Â includes	 Â programs	 Â to	 Â encourage	 Â development	 Â

the	 Â development	 Â of	 Â these	 Â housing	 Â types.	 Â 
     3-Â­â€11	 Â     Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report|	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â

                             3.	 Â RESOURCES	 Â                                                                                      	 Â

I N F R A S T R U C T U R E 	 Â 
The	 Â  ability	 Â  to	 Â  provide	 Â  adequate	 Â  infrastructure	 Â  and	 Â  services	 Â  (roads,	 Â  water,	 Â  sewer,	 Â  drainage,	 Â  etc.)	 Â  for	 Â  new	 Â 
housing	 Â  developments	 Â  is	 Â  an	 Â  essential	 Â  element	 Â  in	 Â  meeting	 Â  future	 Â  housing	 Â  needs.	 Â  The	 Â  cost	 Â  of	 Â  providing	 Â 
significant	 Â infrastructure,	 Â when	 Â weighed	 Â with	 Â other	 Â development	 Â costs	 Â such	 Â as	 Â property,	 Â construction,	 Â 
and	 Â carry	 Â costs,	 Â can	 Â prohibit	 Â the	 Â ability	 Â of	 Â a	 Â developer	 Â to	 Â achieve	 Â a	 Â profitable	 Â return	 Â on	 Â investment	 Â in	 Â 
todayâ€™s	 Â market	 Â climate.	 Â 	 Â 
An	 Â  assessment	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  utility	 Â  infrastructure	 Â  and	 Â  the	 Â  public	 Â  services	 Â  available	 Â  to	 Â  operate	 Â  and	 Â  maintain	 Â  the	 Â 
infrastructure	 Â  is	 Â  provided	 Â  below.	 Â  The	 Â  assessment	 Â  discusses	 Â  infrastructure/service	 Â  limitations	 Â  for	 Â  current	 Â 
and	 Â future	 Â development	 Â as	 Â well	 Â as	 Â infrastructure	 Â fees.	 Â This	 Â discussion	 Â is	 Â based	 Â on	 Â information	 Â that	 Â was	 Â 
obtained	 Â from	 Â the	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â 2010	 Â Urban	 Â Water	 Â Management	 Â Plan,	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â Water	 Â Distribution	 Â 
System	 Â  Master	 Â  Plan,	 Â  Sonoma	 Â  County	 Â  Water	 Â  Agency	 Â  2010	 Â  Urban	 Â  Water	 Â  Management	 Â  Plan,	 Â  City	 Â  of	 Â  Cotati	 Â 
Sewer	 Â Collection	 Â System	 Â Master	 Â Plan,	 Â and	 Â the	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â General	 Â Plan	 Â Update	 Â Background	 Â Report;	 Â all	 Â 
of	 Â  these	 Â  documents	 Â  were	 Â  published	 Â  in	 Â  2011.	 Â  	 Â  As	 Â  described	 Â  below,	 Â  there	 Â  is	 Â  adequate	 Â  existing	 Â  and	 Â 
planned	 Â  water	 Â  supply,	 Â  wastewater	 Â  disposal,	 Â  transportation	 Â  system,	 Â  and	 Â  public	 Â  services	 Â  capacity	 Â  to	 Â 
accommodate	 Â the	 Â Cityâ€™s	 Â fair	 Â share	 Â of	 Â regional	 Â housing	 Â needs.	 Â 
Water	 Â Services	 Â 
The	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â owns	 Â and	 Â operates	 Â a	 Â water	 Â supply	 Â and	 Â distribution	 Â system	 Â that	 Â supplies	 Â potable	 Â water	 Â 
to	 Â  residences	 Â  and	 Â  businesses	 Â  within	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  limits.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  potable	 Â  water	 Â  supply	 Â  comes	 Â  primarily	 Â 
from	 Â  water	 Â  purchased	 Â  from	 Â  the	 Â  Sonoma	 Â  County	 Â  Water	 Â  Agency	 Â  (SCWA)	 Â  and	 Â  water	 Â  pumped	 Â  from	 Â 
groundwater	 Â wells	 Â owned	 Â and	 Â operated	 Â by	 Â the	 Â City.	 Â 
WATER	 Â SUPPLIES	 Â 
The	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  main	 Â  water	 Â  supply	 Â  is	 Â  water	 Â  that	 Â  it	 Â  receives	 Â  from	 Â  the	 Â  SCWA.	 Â  The	 Â  SCWA	 Â  water	 Â  supply	 Â  is	 Â 
comprised	 Â of	 Â ground	 Â water	 Â from	 Â the	 Â Russian	 Â River	 Â permitted	 Â under	 Â a	 Â surface	 Â water	 Â diversion	 Â right	 Â for	 Â 
infiltration	 Â and	 Â groundwater	 Â from	 Â SCWA	 Â wells.	 Â In	 Â addition	 Â to	 Â the	 Â primary	 Â SCWA	 Â water	 Â supply,	 Â the	 Â City	 Â

1992,	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  used	 Â  groundwater	 Â  to	 Â  supply	 Â  more	 Â  than	 Â  half	 Â  of	 Â  its	 Â  demands.	 Â  More	 Â  recently,	 Â  the	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â

groundwater	 Â supplies	 Â to	 Â supplement	 Â its	 Â needs	 Â during	 Â peak	 Â periods	 Â and	 Â also	 Â during	 Â periods	 Â of	 Â drought.	 Â 
The	 Â Cityâ€™s	 Â local	 Â groundwater	 Â supply	 Â is	 Â a	 Â key	 Â element	 Â of	 Â its	 Â drought	 Â contingency	 Â plan	 Â and	 Â is	 Â planned	 Â to	 Â

The	 Â  City	 Â  actively	 Â  seeks	 Â  to	 Â  balance	 Â  the	 Â  use	 Â  of	 Â  its	 Â  SCWA	 Â  water	 Â  supplies	 Â  and	 Â  its	 Â  local	 Â  groundwater	 Â  supplies	 Â 
in	 Â a	 Â way	 Â that	 Â ensures	 Â a	 Â sustainable	 Â yield	 Â of	 Â local	 Â groundwater.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
Additionally,	 Â as	 Â described	 Â in	 Â the	 Â Cityâ€™s	 Â 2010	 Â UWMP,	 Â the	 Â City	 Â desires	 Â to	 Â implement	 Â a	 Â system	 Â that	 Â would	 Â

System.	 Â 	 Â Table	 Â 3-Â­â€8	 Â summarizes	 Â the	 Â Cityâ€™s	 Â current	 Â water	 Â supply	 Â as	 Â well	 Â as	 Â future	 Â (planned)	 Â water	 Â supplies	 Â

COTATI	 Â WASTEWATER	 Â COLLECTION	 Â SYSTEM	 Â

WASTEWATER	 Â TREATMENT	 Â 
The	 Â  City	 Â  of	 Â  Santa	 Â  Rosa	 Â  Utilities	 Â  Department	 Â  is	 Â  responsible	 Â  for	 Â  managing	 Â  the	 Â  Subregional	 Â  Wastewater	 Â 
Treatment	 Â  and	 Â  Reclamation	 Â  system,	 Â  which	 Â  handles	 Â  the	 Â  wastewater	 Â  treatment	 Â  for	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  of	 Â  Cotati.	 Â 	 Â 
Wastewater	 Â  generated	 Â  by	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  of	 Â  Cotati	 Â  is	 Â  treated	 Â  at	 Â  the	 Â  Laguna	 Â  Wastewater	 Â  Treatment	 Â  Plant,	 Â 
located	 Â at	 Â the	 Â south	 Â end	 Â of	 Â Santa	 Â Rosa.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
In	 Â 1975,	 Â the	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Santa	 Â Rosa	 Â executed	 Â an	 Â Agreement	 Â with	 Â the	 Â Cities	 Â of	 Â Rohnert	 Â Park,	 Â Sebastopol	 Â and	 Â 
the	 Â South	 Â Park	 Â County	 Â Sanitation	 Â District	 Â for	 Â treatment	 Â of	 Â wastewater	 Â at	 Â the	 Â Laguna	 Â Treatment	 Â Plant.	 Â At	 Â 
that	 Â time,	 Â Cotatiâ€™s	 Â wastewater	 Â flowed	 Â through	 Â Rohnert	 Â Parkâ€™s	 Â collection	 Â system	 Â and	 Â the	 Â combined	 Â flow	 Â 
continued	 Â to	 Â the	 Â Laguna	 Â Treatment	 Â Plant.	 Â In	 Â 2002,	 Â under	 Â the	 Â Fourth	 Â Amended	 Â Agreement,	 Â Cotatiâ€™s	 Â flow	 Â 
allocation	 Â  was	 Â  increased	 Â  to	 Â  0.76	 Â  mgd	 Â  to	 Â  incrementally	 Â  meet	 Â  treatment	 Â  capacity	 Â  needs	 Â  for	 Â  its	 Â  General	 Â 
Plan	 Â  buildout.	 Â  	 Â  This	 Â  available	 Â  capacity	 Â  will	 Â  accommodate	 Â  the	 Â  Cityâ€™s	 Â  remaining	 Â  RHNA,	 Â  approved	 Â  and	 Â 
pending	 Â  development	 Â  projects,	 Â  as	 Â  well	 Â  as	 Â  additional	 Â  residential,	 Â  commercial,	 Â  and	 Â  other	 Â  development	 Â 
envisioned	 Â in	 Â the	 Â General	 Â Plan.	 Â 
Circulation	 Â System	 Â 
Two	 Â  state	 Â  highways,	 Â  US	 Â  101	 Â  and	 Â  the	 Â  Gravenstein	 Â  Highway	 Â  (SR	 Â  116),	 Â  pass	 Â  through	 Â  Cotati	 Â  and	 Â  provide	 Â 
access	 Â to	 Â other	 Â parts	 Â of	 Â Sonoma	 Â County	 Â and	 Â the	 Â greater	 Â San	 Â Francisco	 Â Bay	 Â Area.	 Â 	 Â Three	 Â regional	 Â arterials	 Â 
pass	 Â  through	 Â  Cotati	 Â  into	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  of	 Â  Rohnert	 Â  Park	 Â  or	 Â  Sonoma	 Â  County:	 Â  Old	 Â  Redwood	 Â  Highway,	 Â  East	 Â  Cotati	 Â 
Avenue,	 Â and	 Â Commerce	 Â Boulevard.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â Cityâ€™s	 Â commercial	 Â areas	 Â are	 Â laid	 Â out	 Â in	 Â a	 Â linear	 Â fashion	 Â along	 Â the	 Â 
major	 Â  collectors	 Â  of	 Â  East	 Â  Cotati	 Â  Avenue,	 Â  Gravenstein	 Â  Highway	 Â  and	 Â  Old	 Â  Redwood	 Â  Highway.	 Â  	 Â  Housing	 Â 
closest	 Â  to	 Â  downtown	 Â  is	 Â  the	 Â  most	 Â  compact,	 Â  residential	 Â  neighborhoods	 Â  adjacent	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  hub	 Â  have	 Â  a	 Â  typical	 Â 
suburban	 Â form,	 Â and	 Â development	 Â west	 Â of	 Â US	 Â 101	 Â is	 Â appreciably	 Â less	 Â dense	 Â and	 Â rural	 Â in	 Â context.	 Â 	 Â Cotatiâ€™s	 Â 
relatively	 Â  small	 Â  land	 Â  area	 Â  and	 Â  flat	 Â  topography	 Â  create	 Â  many	 Â  opportunities	 Â  for	 Â  residents	 Â  to	 Â  walk	 Â  and	 Â

Local	 Â streets	 Â provide	 Â access	 Â to	 Â neighborhoods,	 Â parks,	 Â and	 Â shopping	 Â areas.	 Â 	 Â Public	 Â transit	 Â is	 Â provided	 Â by	 Â

traffic	 Â  seeks	 Â  alternatives	 Â  to	 Â  traditional	 Â  traffic	 Â  solutions	 Â  (e.g.,	 Â  road	 Â  widening	 Â  to	 Â  maintain	 Â  high	 Â  levels	 Â  of	 Â

City	 Â  collects	 Â  a	 Â  Traffic	 Â  Mitigation	 Â  fee	 Â  to	 Â  address	 Â  circulation	 Â  improvements	 Â  necessary	 Â  to	 Â  serve	 Â  planned	 Â 
growth.	 Â 	 Â Individual	 Â development	 Â projects	 Â are	 Â required	 Â to	 Â provide	 Â roadway	 Â improvements	 Â as	 Â described	 Â

The	 Â  City	 Â  is	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  process	 Â  of	 Â  developing	 Â  a	 Â  master	 Â  plan	 Â  for	 Â  traffic	 Â  improvements	 Â  along	 Â  Old	 Â  Redwood	 Â

Mitigation	 Â Fee	 Â ($250	 Â per	 Â unit)	 Â allows	 Â new	 Â development	 Â to	 Â pay	 Â its	 Â fair	 Â share	 Â toward	 Â needed	 Â new	 Â traffic	 Â

approach	 Â  relieves	 Â  individual	 Â  projects	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  cost-Â­â€burden	 Â  and	 Â  time	 Â  necessary	 Â  to	 Â  construct	 Â  individual	 Â

residential	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â  linkage.	 Â  	 Â  This	 Â  fund	 Â  may	 Â  be	 Â  used	 Â  to	 Â  fund	 Â  very	 Â  low,	 Â  low,	 Â  and	 Â  moderate	 Â

Successor	 Â  Agency	 Â  was	 Â  created	 Â  to	 Â  address	 Â  the	 Â  assets	 Â  and	 Â  obligations	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  Redevelopment	 Â  Agency.	 Â 	 Â

Urban	 Â County	 Â â€“	 Â CDBG,	 Â HOME,	 Â and	 Â ESG	 Â Funding.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â City	 Â of	 Â Cotati,	 Â along	 Â with	 Â six	 Â other	 Â cities	 Â and	 Â the	 Â

                            3.	 Â RESOURCES	 Â                                                                             	 Â 
	 Â 
funds	 Â  and	 Â  Emergency	 Â  Shelter	 Â  Grant	 Â  (ESG)	 Â  homeless	 Â  prevention	 Â  funds.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  Urban	 Â  County	 Â  is	 Â

Urban	 Â County	 Â and	 Â HOME	 Â Consortium.	 Â In	 Â fiscal	 Â year	 Â 2011/2012,	 Â the	 Â Urban	 Â County/Consortium	 Â received	 Â 
$1.79	 Â  million	 Â  in	 Â  CDBG	 Â  funds,	 Â  $121,916	 Â  in	 Â  Emergency	 Â  Shelter	 Â  Grants	 Â  (ESG),	 Â  and	 Â  $1.1	 Â  million	 Â  in	 Â  HOME	 Â 
funds.	 Â  	 Â  Cotati	 Â  must	 Â  compete	 Â  with	 Â  other	 Â  small	 Â  cities	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  County	 Â  each	 Â  year	 Â  to	 Â  receive	 Â  funding	 Â  for	 Â

CDBG	 Â funds.	 Â A	 Â program	 Â is	 Â included	 Â in	 Â the	 Â Housing	 Â Plan	 Â to	 Â seek	 Â annual	 Â funding	 Â from	 Â the	 Â Urban	 Â County	 Â to	 Â 
help	 Â  the	 Â  City	 Â  address	 Â  its	 Â  housing	 Â  needs.	 Â  	 Â  Consortium	 Â  funds	 Â  have	 Â  been	 Â  provided	 Â  to	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing	 Â 
developments	 Â in	 Â the	 Â City.	 Â 
The	 Â primary	 Â objective	 Â for	 Â CDBG	 Â funding	 Â is	 Â to	 Â develop	 Â viable	 Â urban	 Â communities,	 Â principally	 Â for	 Â low	 Â and	 Â 
moderate	 Â  income	 Â  persons.	 Â  	 Â  Eligible	 Â  CDBG	 Â  activities	 Â  include:	 Â  housing	 Â  assistance	 Â  programs;	 Â  public	 Â

that	 Â  promote	 Â  economic	 Â  development;	 Â  programs	 Â  that	 Â  support	 Â  community	 Â  organizations	 Â  that	 Â  work	 Â 
directly	 Â with	 Â low	 Â and	 Â moderate-Â­â€income	 Â residents;	 Â and	 Â planning	 Â and	 Â administration.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
The	 Â  ESG	 Â  program	 Â  is	 Â  authorized	 Â  under	 Â  subtitle	 Â  B	 Â  of	 Â  Title	 Â  IV	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  Stewart	 Â  B.	 Â  McKinney	 Â  Homeless	 Â 
Assistance	 Â  Act	 Â  of	 Â  1987.	 Â  This	 Â  program	 Â  is	 Â  designed	 Â  to	 Â  prevent	 Â  homelessness	 Â  and	 Â  to	 Â  enable	 Â  homeless	 Â 
individuals	 Â  and	 Â  families	 Â  to	 Â  move	 Â  toward	 Â  independent	 Â  living.	 Â  Funds	 Â  can	 Â  be	 Â  used	 Â  toward	 Â  essential	 Â 
services,	 Â homeless	 Â prevention,	 Â and	 Â operation	 Â of	 Â homeless	 Â shelters	 Â and	 Â the	 Â overall	 Â program.	 Â 
Federal	 Â Financial	 Â Resources	 Â 
Community	 Â Development	 Â Block	 Â Grant	 Â Program.	 Â 	 Â CDBG	 Â funds,	 Â received	 Â since	 Â FY	 Â 1982-Â­â€83	 Â and	 Â averaging	 Â 
approximately	 Â $2	 Â million	 Â annually,	 Â are	 Â administered	 Â by	 Â Sonoma	 Â County	 Â on	 Â behalf	 Â of	 Â the	 Â Urban	 Â County.	 Â 	 Â 
CDBG	 Â  funds	 Â  are	 Â  used	 Â  mainly	 Â  for	 Â  housing	 Â  or	 Â  housing	 Â  related	 Â  activities,	 Â  including	 Â  infrastructure	 Â 
improvements,	 Â  and	 Â  do	 Â  allow	 Â  a	 Â  small	 Â  portion	 Â  to	 Â  be	 Â  used	 Â  for	 Â  public	 Â  services.	 Â  The	 Â  most	 Â  current	 Â  annual	 Â 
allocation	 Â of	 Â funds	 Â is	 Â approximately	 Â $1.6	 Â million.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
Emergency	 Â  Shelter	 Â  Grants	 Â  Program.	 Â  ESG	 Â  funds	 Â  are	 Â  used	 Â  for	 Â  the	 Â  administration	 Â  and	 Â  operation	 Â  of	 Â 
emergency	 Â  shelters,	 Â  essential	 Â  services	 Â  for	 Â  homeless	 Â  persons,	 Â  and	 Â  homeless	 Â  prevention	 Â  programs.	 Â  The	 Â 
ESG	 Â allocation	 Â had	 Â been	 Â averaging	 Â $88,000	 Â annually	 Â and	 Â recently	 Â increased	 Â to	 Â $135,863.	 Â The	 Â County	 Â will	 Â 
continue	 Â  to	 Â  use	 Â  these	 Â  funds	 Â  for	 Â  shelter	 Â  operations	 Â  and	 Â  homelessness	 Â  prevention	 Â  activities	 Â  to	 Â  assist	 Â 
Urban	 Â County	 Â residents.	 Â 
Section	 Â  8	 Â  Housing	 Â  Choice	 Â  Voucher	 Â  Program.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  Section	 Â  8	 Â  Housing	 Â  Choice	 Â  Voucher	 Â  Program	 Â  provides	 Â 
monthly	 Â  rental	 Â  assistance	 Â  payments	 Â  to	 Â  private	 Â  landlords	 Â  on	 Â  behalf	 Â  of	 Â  low-Â­â€income	 Â  families	 Â  who	 Â  have	 Â 
been	 Â  determined	 Â  eligible	 Â  by	 Â  the	 Â  Housing	 Â  Authority.	 Â  The	 Â  program's	 Â  objective	 Â  is	 Â  to	 Â  assist	 Â  low-Â­â€income	 Â 
families	 Â by	 Â providing	 Â rental	 Â assistance	 Â so	 Â that	 Â families	 Â may	 Â lease	 Â safe,	 Â decent,	 Â and	 Â sanitary	 Â housing	 Â units	 Â 
in	 Â  the	 Â  private	 Â  rental	 Â  market.	 Â  The	 Â  program	 Â  is	 Â  designed	 Â  to	 Â  allow	 Â  families	 Â  to	 Â  move	 Â  without	 Â  the	 Â  loss	 Â  of	 Â 
housing	 Â assistance.	 Â Moves	 Â are	 Â permissible	 Â as	 Â long	 Â as	 Â the	 Â family	 Â notifies	 Â the	 Â Housing	 Â Authority	 Â ahead	 Â of	 Â 
time,	 Â  terminates	 Â  its	 Â  existing	 Â  lease	 Â  within	 Â  the	 Â  lease	 Â  provisions,	 Â  and	 Â  finds	 Â  acceptable	 Â  alternate	 Â  housing.	 Â  In	 Â 
Cotati,	 Â  30	 Â  households	 Â  are	 Â  assisted	 Â  through	 Â  the	 Â  Housing	 Â  Authority	 Â  Section	 Â  8	 Â  and	 Â  Shelter	 Â  Plus	 Â  Care	 Â 
Programs.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
Section	 Â  8	 Â  â€“	 Â  Project	 Â  Based	 Â  Assistance.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  Section	 Â  8	 Â  Project-Â­â€Based	 Â  program	 Â  is	 Â  a	 Â  component	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â 
Housing	 Â  Choice	 Â  Voucher	 Â  program.	 Â  The	 Â  program's	 Â  objective	 Â  is	 Â  to	 Â  induce	 Â  property	 Â  owners	 Â  to	 Â  make	 Â 
standard	 Â  housing	 Â  available	 Â  to	 Â  low-Â­â€income	 Â  families	 Â  at	 Â  rents	 Â  within	 Â  the	 Â  program	 Â  limits.	 Â  In	 Â  return,	 Â  the	 Â 
Housing	 Â Authority	 Â or	 Â HUD	 Â enters	 Â into	 Â a	 Â contract	 Â with	 Â the	 Â owner	 Â that	 Â guarantees	 Â a	 Â certain	 Â level	 Â of	 Â rents.	 Â 
There	 Â  are	 Â  two	 Â  Project-Â­â€Based	 Â  properties	 Â  located	 Â  within	 Â  Cotati.	 Â  Under	 Â  the	 Â  Project-Â­â€Based	 Â  program,	 Â  the	 Â 
                                                              City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â |	 Â Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report	 Â                    3-Â­â€16	 Â 
	 Â 

                                                                                               	 Â                         3.	 Â 	 Â RESOURCES	 Â 
	 Â 
assistance	 Â is	 Â tied	 Â to	 Â the	 Â unit.	 Â A	 Â family	 Â who	 Â moves	 Â from	 Â the	 Â Project-Â­â€Based	 Â unit	 Â does	 Â not	 Â have	 Â any	 Â right	 Â to	 Â 
continued	 Â housing	 Â assistance.	 Â 	 Â Section	 Â 8	 Â contracts	 Â may	 Â be	 Â renewed	 Â on	 Â an	 Â annual	 Â basis.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
Federal	 Â  Emergency	 Â  Management	 Â  Agency	 Â  (FEMA).	 Â  	 Â  Since	 Â  2000,	 Â  the	 Â  Commission	 Â  has	 Â  administered	 Â  the	 Â 
elevation	 Â  program,	 Â  prioritizing	 Â  assistance	 Â  to	 Â  properties	 Â  owned	 Â  and/or	 Â  occupied	 Â  by	 Â  lower-Â­â€income	 Â 
households.	 Â 	 Â 
Federal	 Â  Home	 Â  Loan	 Â  Bank	 Â  System.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  Federal	 Â  Home	 Â  Loan	 Â  Bank	 Â  System	 Â  facilitates	 Â  Affordable	 Â  Housing	 Â 
Programs	 Â  (AHP),	 Â  which	 Â  subsidize	 Â  the	 Â  interest	 Â  rates	 Â  for	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing.	 Â  The	 Â  San	 Â  Francisco	 Â  Federal	 Â 
Home	 Â Loan	 Â Bank	 Â District	 Â provides	 Â local	 Â service	 Â within	 Â California.	 Â Interest	 Â rate	 Â subsidies	 Â under	 Â the	 Â AHP	 Â 
can	 Â  be	 Â  used	 Â  to	 Â  finance	 Â  the	 Â  purchase,	 Â  construction,	 Â  and/or	 Â  rehabilitation	 Â  of	 Â  rental	 Â  housing.	 Â  Very	 Â  low	 Â 
income	 Â  households	 Â  must	 Â  occupy	 Â  at	 Â  least	 Â  20	 Â  percent	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  units	 Â  for	 Â  the	 Â  useful	 Â  life	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  housing	 Â  or	 Â  the	 Â 
mortgage	 Â term.	 Â 	 Â 
Housing	 Â  Investment	 Â  Partnerships	 Â  Program.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  HOME	 Â  program	 Â  is	 Â  authorized	 Â  under	 Â  Title	 Â  II	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â 
Cranston-Â­â€Gonzales	 Â  National	 Â  Affordable	 Â  Housing	 Â  Act	 Â  that	 Â  was	 Â  signed	 Â  into	 Â  law	 Â  on	 Â  November	 Â  28,	 Â  1990.	 Â 
The	 Â  intent	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  HOME	 Â  Program	 Â  is	 Â  to	 Â  expand	 Â  the	 Â  supply	 Â  of	 Â  decent,	 Â  safe,	 Â  sanitary	 Â  and	 Â  affordable	 Â 
housing	 Â for	 Â very	 Â low	 Â and	 Â low	 Â income	 Â households.	 Â 	 Â HOME	 Â Program	 Â funds	 Â are	 Â to	 Â be	 Â used	 Â for	 Â affordable	 Â 
rental	 Â  housing	 Â  projects,	 Â  through	 Â  funding	 Â  of	 Â  new	 Â  development,	 Â  acquisition/rehabilitation	 Â  of	 Â  existing	 Â 
developments,	 Â  or	 Â  through	 Â  tenant-Â­â€based	 Â  rental	 Â  assistance.	 Â  Historically,	 Â  the	 Â  Urban	 Â  County	 Â  receives	 Â 
approximately	 Â $1.2	 Â million	 Â each	 Â year	 Â and	 Â the	 Â program	 Â requires	 Â a	 Â 25	 Â percent	 Â local	 Â match	 Â of	 Â funds.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â 
most	 Â recent	 Â annual	 Â allocation	 Â is	 Â $677,686.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
HUD	 Â  Section	 Â  811/202	 Â  Programs.	 Â  	 Â  Through	 Â  the	 Â  Section	 Â  811/202	 Â  programs,	 Â  HUD	 Â  provides	 Â  long	 Â  term	 Â 
financing	 Â for	 Â disabled	 Â and	 Â elderly	 Â rental	 Â housing	 Â affordable	 Â to	 Â lower	 Â income	 Â households.	 Â 	 Â 
Low-Â­â€Income	 Â  Housing	 Â  Preservation	 Â  and	 Â  Residential	 Â  Home	 Â  Ownership	 Â  Act	 Â  (LIHPRHA).	 Â  LIHPRHA	 Â  requires	 Â 
that	 Â  all	 Â  eligible	 Â  HUD	 Â  Section	 Â  236	 Â  and	 Â  Section	 Â  221(d)	 Â  projects	 Â  â€œat-Â­â€riskâ€	 Â  of	 Â  conversion	 Â  to	 Â  market-Â­â€rate	 Â 
rental	 Â  housing	 Â  through	 Â  the	 Â  mortgage	 Â  prepayment	 Â  option	 Â  be	 Â  subject	 Â  to	 Â  LIHPRHA	 Â  Incentives.	 Â  The	 Â 
incentives	 Â to	 Â owners	 Â include	 Â HUD	 Â subsidies	 Â which	 Â guarantee	 Â owners	 Â an	 Â eight	 Â percent	 Â annual	 Â return	 Â on	 Â 
equity.	 Â Owners	 Â must	 Â file	 Â a	 Â Plan	 Â of	 Â Action	 Â to	 Â obtain	 Â incentives	 Â or	 Â offer	 Â the	 Â project	 Â for	 Â sale	 Â to	 Â a)	 Â non-Â­â€profit	 Â 
organizations,	 Â  b)	 Â  tenants,	 Â  or	 Â  c)	 Â  public	 Â  bodies	 Â  for	 Â  a	 Â  12	 Â  month	 Â  period	 Â  followed	 Â  by	 Â  an	 Â  additional	 Â  three-Â­â€
month	 Â sale	 Â to	 Â other	 Â purchasers.	 Â Only	 Â then	 Â are	 Â owners	 Â eligible	 Â to	 Â prepay	 Â the	 Â subsidized	 Â mortgages.	 Â 
McKinney	 Â  Vento	 Â  Homeless	 Â  Assistance.	 Â  	 Â  Since	 Â  1997,	 Â  Sonoma	 Â  Countyâ€™s	 Â  Housing	 Â  Authority	 Â  and	 Â  nonprofit	 Â 
agencies	 Â have	 Â received	 Â funding	 Â under	 Â the	 Â Supportive	 Â Housing	 Â and	 Â Shelter	 Â Plus	 Â Care	 Â programs.	 Â 	 Â

for	 Â  affordable	 Â  rental	 Â  projects	 Â  in	 Â  Cotati	 Â  over	 Â  the	 Â  past	 Â  decade.	 Â  Through	 Â  this	 Â  program,	 Â  private	 Â  investors	 Â

                            3.	 Â RESOURCES	 Â                                                                                	 Â

Building	 Â  Equity	 Â  and	 Â  Growth	 Â  in	 Â  Neighborhoods	 Â  (BEGIN).	 Â  	 Â  BEGIN,	 Â  administered	 Â  by	 Â  HCD,	 Â  provides	 Â  grants	 Â  to	 Â

CalHOME	 Â  Program.	 Â  	 Â  CalHome	 Â  provides	 Â  grants	 Â  to	 Â  local	 Â  public	 Â  agencies	 Â  and	 Â  non-Â­â€profit	 Â  developers	 Â  to	 Â

development,	 Â acquisition,	 Â and	 Â rehabilitation	 Â costs	 Â as	 Â well	 Â as	 Â downpayment	 Â assistance.	 Â 
California	 Â  Housing	 Â  Finance	 Â  Agency	 Â  (CalHFA).	 Â  	 Â  CalHFA	 Â  offers	 Â  multiple	 Â  financing	 Â  programs,	 Â  including	 Â 
permanent	 Â  financing	 Â  for	 Â  acquisition	 Â  and	 Â  rehabilitation	 Â  to	 Â  for-Â­â€profit,	 Â  non-Â­â€profit,	 Â  and	 Â  public	 Â  agency	 Â

that	 Â  also	 Â  receive	 Â  federal	 Â  4%	 Â  low	 Â  income	 Â  housing	 Â  tax	 Â  credits.	 Â  In	 Â  addition,	 Â  CalHFA	 Â  offers	 Â  low	 Â  interest	 Â

Department	 Â  of	 Â  Developmental	 Â  Services	 Â  uses	 Â  CPP	 Â  funds	 Â  to	 Â  develop	 Â  homes	 Â  as	 Â  an	 Â  alternative	 Â  for	 Â 
individuals	 Â with	 Â developmental	 Â disabilities	 Â to	 Â reside	 Â in	 Â the	 Â community	 Â instead	 Â of	 Â institutional	 Â settings.	 Â 	 Â 
Emergency	 Â Housing	 Â and	 Â Assistance	 Â Program	 Â (EHAP).	 Â 	 Â EHAP	 Â provides	 Â funds	 Â to	 Â local	 Â government	 Â agencies	 Â 
and	 Â  non-Â­â€profit	 Â  corporations	 Â  for	 Â  capital	 Â  development	 Â  activities	 Â  and	 Â  facility	 Â  operation	 Â  for	 Â  emergency	 Â 
shelters,	 Â  transitional	 Â  housing	 Â  and	 Â  safe	 Â  havens	 Â  that	 Â  provide	 Â  shelter	 Â  and	 Â  supportive	 Â  services	 Â  for	 Â  homeless	 Â 
individuals	 Â and	 Â families.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
Housing	 Â  Enabled	 Â  by	 Â  Local	 Â  Partnerships	 Â  (HELP).	 Â  	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  HELP	 Â  Program,	 Â  administered	 Â  by	 Â  CalHFA,	 Â  awards	 Â  10-Â­â€
year	 Â low-Â­â€interest	 Â rate	 Â loans	 Â to	 Â local	 Â jurisdictions	 Â to	 Â finance	 Â development	 Â of	 Â affordable	 Â housing.	 Â 	 Â 
Infill	 Â  Infrastructure	 Â  Grant	 Â  Program.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  program	 Â  funds	 Â  infrastructure	 Â  improvements	 Â  to	 Â  facilitate	 Â  new	 Â 
housing	 Â development	 Â with	 Â an	 Â affordable	 Â component	 Â in	 Â residential	 Â or	 Â mixed	 Â use	 Â infill	 Â projects	 Â and	 Â infill	 Â

Joe	 Â  Serna	 Â  Jr.	 Â  Farmworker	 Â  Housing	 Â  Grant	 Â  Program	 Â  (Serna).	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  Serna	 Â  program	 Â  finances	 Â  the	 Â  new	 Â 
construction,	 Â rehabilitation	 Â and	 Â acquisition	 Â of	 Â owner-Â­â€	 Â and	 Â renter-Â­â€occupied	 Â housing	 Â units	 Â for	 Â agricultural	 Â 
workers,	 Â with	 Â a	 Â priority	 Â for	 Â lower	 Â income	 Â households.	 Â 
Low	 Â  Income	 Â  Housing	 Â  Tax	 Â  Credits.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  California	 Â  Tax	 Â  Credit	 Â  Allocation	 Â  Committee	 Â  (CTCAC)	 Â  administers	 Â 
the	 Â  federal	 Â  and	 Â  state	 Â  Low-Â­â€Income	 Â  Housing	 Â  Tax	 Â  Credit	 Â  Programs.	 Â  Both	 Â  programs	 Â  were	 Â  created	 Â  to	 Â 
encourage	 Â  private	 Â  investment	 Â  in	 Â  affordable	 Â  rental	 Â  housing	 Â  for	 Â  households	 Â  meeting	 Â  certain	 Â  income	 Â 
requirements.	 Â  	 Â  Under	 Â  these	 Â  programs,	 Â  housing	 Â  tax	 Â  credits	 Â  are	 Â  awarded	 Â  to	 Â  developers	 Â  of	 Â  qualified	 Â 
projects.	 Â Twenty	 Â percent	 Â of	 Â federal	 Â credits	 Â are	 Â reserved	 Â for	 Â rural	 Â areas,	 Â and	 Â ten	 Â percent	 Â for	 Â non-Â­â€profit	 Â 
sponsors.	 Â  To	 Â  compete	 Â  for	 Â  the	 Â  credit,	 Â  rental	 Â  housing	 Â  developments	 Â  have	 Â  to	 Â  reserve	 Â  units	 Â  at	 Â  affordable	 Â 
rents	 Â to	 Â households	 Â at	 Â or	 Â below	 Â 46	 Â percent	 Â of	 Â area	 Â median	 Â income.	 Â The	 Â assisted	 Â units	 Â must	 Â be	 Â reserved	 Â 
for	 Â the	 Â target	 Â population	 Â for	 Â 55	 Â years.	 Â The	 Â federal	 Â tax	 Â credit	 Â provides	 Â a	 Â subsidy	 Â over	 Â ten	 Â years	 Â towards	 Â 
the	 Â  cost	 Â  of	 Â  producing	 Â  a	 Â  unit.	 Â  Developers	 Â  sell	 Â  these	 Â  tax	 Â  benefits	 Â  to	 Â  investors	 Â  for	 Â  their	 Â  present	 Â  market	 Â 
value	 Â to	 Â provide	 Â up-Â­â€front	 Â capital	 Â to	 Â build	 Â the	 Â units.	 Â Credits	 Â can	 Â be	 Â used	 Â to	 Â fund	 Â the	 Â hard	 Â and	 Â soft	 Â costs	 Â 
(excluding	 Â land	 Â costs)	 Â of	 Â the	 Â acquisition,	 Â rehabilitation,	 Â or	 Â new	 Â construction	 Â of	 Â rental	 Â housing.	 Â Projects	 Â 
not	 Â receiving	 Â other	 Â federal	 Â subsidy	 Â receive	 Â a	 Â federal	 Â credit	 Â of	 Â nine	 Â percent	 Â per	 Â year	 Â for	 Â ten	 Â years	 Â and	 Â a	 Â 
state	 Â  credit	 Â  of	 Â  30	 Â  percent	 Â  over	 Â  four	 Â  years	 Â  (high	 Â  cost	 Â  areas	 Â  and	 Â  qualified	 Â  census	 Â  tracts	 Â  get	 Â  increased	 Â 
federal	 Â credits).	 Â Projects	 Â with	 Â a	 Â federal	 Â subsidy	 Â receive	 Â a	 Â four	 Â percent	 Â federal	 Â credit	 Â each	 Â year	 Â for	 Â ten	 Â 
years	 Â  and	 Â  a	 Â  13	 Â  percent	 Â  state	 Â  credit	 Â  over	 Â  four	 Â  years.	 Â  The	 Â  CTCAC	 Â  also	 Â  administers	 Â  a	 Â  Commercial	 Â 
Revitalization	 Â Deduction	 Â Program.	 Â 
                                                                  City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â |	 Â Housing	 Â Element	 Â Background	 Â Report	 Â                    3-Â­â€18	 Â 
	 Â 

                                                                                               	 Â                          3.	 Â 	 Â RESOURCES	 Â 
	 Â 
Local	 Â Housing	 Â Trust	 Â Fund	 Â Program.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â The	 Â Local	 Â Housing	 Â Trust	 Â Fund	 Â program,	 Â also	 Â funded	 Â through	 Â HCD,	 Â 
provides	 Â matching	 Â grants	 Â to	 Â local	 Â housing	 Â trust	 Â funds.	 Â 	 Â 
Multifamily	 Â  Housing	 Â  Program	 Â  (MHP).	 Â  	 Â  MHP	 Â  administered	 Â  by	 Â  State	 Â  Department	 Â  of	 Â  Housing	 Â  and	 Â 
Community	 Â  Development	 Â  (HCD),	 Â  assists	 Â  rental	 Â  housing	 Â  developments	 Â  that	 Â  will	 Â  be	 Â  affordable	 Â  to	 Â 
extremely	 Â low-Â­â€	 Â and	 Â low-Â­â€income	 Â households.	 Â 	 Â 
Preservation	 Â  Interim	 Â  Repositioning	 Â  Program	 Â  (PIRP).	 Â  PIRP	 Â  is	 Â  a	 Â  short-Â­â€term	 Â  loan	 Â  program	 Â  designed	 Â  to	 Â 
preserve	 Â housing	 Â at	 Â risk	 Â of	 Â conversion	 Â to	 Â market	 Â rates.	 Â Only	 Â non-Â­â€profits,	 Â dedicated	 Â to	 Â the	 Â provision	 Â of	 Â 
affordable	 Â  housing,	 Â  may	 Â  apply.	 Â  Local	 Â  matching	 Â  funds,	 Â  together	 Â  with	 Â  PIRP	 Â  funds,	 Â  may	 Â  not	 Â  exceed	 Â  20	 Â 
percent	 Â of	 Â total	 Â costs.	 Â 
O R G A N IZ A T IO N A L 	 Â  R E S O U R C E S 	 Â  	 Â 
The	 Â  following	 Â  organizations	 Â  providing	 Â  housing	 Â  and	 Â  human	 Â  services	 Â  that	 Â  benefit	 Â  lower	 Â  income	 Â

assistance,	 Â for	 Â households	 Â living	 Â throughout	 Â Sonoma	 Â County.	 Â 	 Â The	 Â Task	 Â Force	 Â disseminates	 Â information	 Â

Force	 Â  convenes	 Â  meetings	 Â  of	 Â  housing	 Â  and	 Â  service	 Â  providers	 Â  to	 Â  facilitate	 Â  information	 Â  sharing	 Â  and	 Â 
coordination	 Â of	 Â services	 Â and	 Â provides	 Â financial	 Â assistance	 Â to	 Â providers.	 Â 	 Â 
Veterans	 Â  Service	 Â  Office.	 Â  	 Â  Provides	 Â  assistance	 Â  and	 Â  advocacy	 Â  for	 Â  veterans	 Â  and	 Â  their	 Â  dependents	 Â  and	 Â 
survivors,	 Â and	 Â other	 Â eligible	 Â individuals	 Â and	 Â organizations	 Â to	 Â claim	 Â state	 Â and	 Â federal	 Â benefits.	 Â Provides	 Â 
information,	 Â assistance	 Â and	 Â referral	 Â in	 Â obtaining	 Â medical	 Â and	 Â other	 Â services.	 Â 
Women,	 Â  Infants,	 Â  and	 Â  Children.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  Sonoma	 Â  County	 Â  Department	 Â  of	 Â  Health	 Â  Services	 Â  operates	 Â  the	 Â  WIC	 Â 
program,	 Â which	 Â provides	 Â financial	 Â assistance	 Â to	 Â purchase	 Â healthy	 Â food	 Â as	 Â well	 Â as	 Â nutrition	 Â services	 Â and	 Â

                             3.	 Â RESOURCES	 Â                                                                            	 Â

E N E R G Y 	 Â  C O N S E R V A T IO N 	 Â 
Energy	 Â conservation	 Â associated	 Â with	 Â residential	 Â development	 Â primarily	 Â occurs	 Â in	 Â two	 Â ways:	 Â 1)	 Â reducing	 Â 
the	 Â  energy	 Â  demands	 Â  associated	 Â  with	 Â  the	 Â  operation	 Â  and	 Â  maintenance	 Â  of	 Â  the	 Â  residence	 Â  and	 Â  property	 Â 
(e.g.,	 Â  design	 Â  for	 Â  passive/natural	 Â  cooling,	 Â  natural	 Â  lighting,	 Â  efficient	 Â  heating	 Â  and	 Â  cooling	 Â  mechanisms,	 Â 
insulation,	 Â energy	 Â efficient	 Â appliances	 Â and	 Â lighting,	 Â â€œsmartâ€	 Â switches,	 Â etc.)	 Â and	 Â 2)	 Â reduce	 Â energy	 Â demand	 Â 
associated	 Â with	 Â vehicle	 Â use.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
Energy	 Â  conservation	 Â  improvements	 Â  offer	 Â  the	 Â  most	 Â  viable	 Â  means	 Â  of	 Â  addressing	 Â  high-Â­â€energy	 Â  costs.	 Â  The	 Â 
City	 Â encourages	 Â energy	 Â conservation	 Â in	 Â new	 Â development	 Â and	 Â retrofit	 Â projects.	 Â The	 Â building	 Â orientation,	 Â 
street	 Â  layout,	 Â  lot	 Â  design,	 Â  landscaping,	 Â  and	 Â  street	 Â  tree	 Â  configuration	 Â  of	 Â  all	 Â  residential	 Â  projects	 Â  are	 Â 
reviewed	 Â  in	 Â  order	 Â  to	 Â  maximize	 Â  solar	 Â  access	 Â  and	 Â  energy	 Â  conservation. The	 Â  objective	 Â  of	 Â  energy	 Â 
conservation	 Â efforts	 Â directed	 Â towards	 Â new	 Â development	 Â includes	 Â the	 Â maximum	 Â feasible	 Â use	 Â of	 Â passive	 Â 
or	 Â natural	 Â cooling	 Â and	 Â lighting,	 Â water	 Â conservation,	 Â and	 Â walkability/connectivity	 Â to	 Â other	 Â neighborhoods	 Â 
and	 Â  community	 Â  destinations.	 Â  	 Â  Examples	 Â  of	 Â  passive	 Â  cooling	 Â  opportunities	 Â  include	 Â  the	 Â  design	 Â  of	 Â  lots	 Â  to	 Â 
allow	 Â the	 Â proper	 Â orientation	 Â of	 Â a	 Â structure	 Â to	 Â take	 Â advantage	 Â of	 Â prevailing	 Â breezes	 Â or	 Â available	 Â shade.	 Â 	 Â 
Passive	 Â  heating	 Â  opportunities	 Â  include	 Â  the	 Â  design	 Â  of	 Â  lots	 Â  to	 Â  allow	 Â  structures	 Â  to	 Â  be	 Â  aligned	 Â  in	 Â  an	 Â  east-Â­â€west	 Â 
direction	 Â for	 Â southern	 Â exposure.	 Â 
There	 Â are	 Â a	 Â number	 Â of	 Â methods	 Â available	 Â to	 Â improve	 Â conditions	 Â of	 Â existing	 Â structures	 Â and	 Â to	 Â decrease	 Â 
their	 Â energy	 Â demand,	 Â all	 Â of	 Â which	 Â fall	 Â under	 Â the	 Â general	 Â label	 Â of	 Â â€œretrofit.â€	 Â 	 Â Among	 Â the	 Â most	 Â common	 Â 
techniques	 Â  for	 Â  increasing	 Â  building	 Â  efficiency	 Â  are:	 Â  	 Â  insulation	 Â  of	 Â  ceilings,	 Â  heating-Â­â€ventilating	 Â  air	 Â 
conditioning	 Â  ducts	 Â  and	 Â  hot	 Â  water	 Â  heaters;	 Â  weather	 Â  stripping	 Â  and	 Â  caulking;	 Â  night	 Â  setback	 Â  thermostats;	 Â 
spark	 Â  ignited	 Â  pilot	 Â  lights;	 Â  low-Â­â€flow	 Â  shower	 Â  heads;	 Â  window	 Â  treatment	 Â  to	 Â  provide	 Â  shade;	 Â  and	 Â  furnace	 Â 
efficiency	 Â modifications.	 Â 	 Â Weatherization	 Â in	 Â existing	 Â dwellings	 Â can	 Â greatly	 Â cut	 Â down	 Â heating	 Â and	 Â cooling	 Â 
costs.	 Â 	 Â Weatherization	 Â is	 Â generally	 Â done	 Â by	 Â performing	 Â or	 Â improving	 Â attic	 Â insulation,	 Â caulking,	 Â weather	 Â 
stripping	 Â  and	 Â  storm	 Â  windows,	 Â  furnace	 Â  efficiency	 Â  modifications,	 Â  and	 Â  certain	 Â  mechanical	 Â  measures	 Â  to	 Â 
heating	 Â and	 Â cooling	 Â systems.	 Â 	 Â Other	 Â means	 Â of	 Â energy	 Â conservation	 Â in	 Â retrofitting	 Â residential	 Â structures	 Â 
includes	 Â proper	 Â design	 Â and	 Â location	 Â of	 Â windows,	 Â window	 Â shades,	 Â orientation	 Â of	 Â the	 Â dwelling	 Â in	 Â relation	 Â 
to	 Â sun	 Â and	 Â wind	 Â direction,	 Â and	 Â roof	 Â overhang	 Â to	 Â let	 Â the	 Â winter	 Â sun	 Â in	 Â and	 Â block	 Â the	 Â summer	 Â sun	 Â out.	 Â 	 Â 
City	 Â of	 Â Cotati	 Â Sustainable	 Â Development	 Â and	 Â Energy	 Â Efficiency	 Â Requirements	 Â 
CALIFORNIA	 Â GREEN	 Â BUILDING	 Â STANDARDS	 Â CODE	 Â 
In	 Â March	 Â 2011,	 Â the	 Â City	 Â repealed	 Â its	 Â Sustainable	 Â Building	 Â Program	 Â and	 Â adopted	 Â CalGreen,	 Â the	 Â California	 Â

Tier	 Â  1	 Â  standards.	 Â  	 Â  CalGreen	 Â  addresses	 Â  five	 Â  areas	 Â  of	 Â  green	 Â  building:	 Â  1)	 Â  planning	 Â  and	 Â  design,	 Â  2)	 Â  energy	 Â

2008	 Â Energy	 Â Efficiency	 Â Standards	 Â by	 Â 15	 Â percent,	 Â and	 Â comply	 Â with	 Â one	 Â measure	 Â from	 Â each	 Â of	 Â the	 Â sites,	 Â

Title	 Â 17	 Â of	 Â the	 Â Cotati	 Â Municipal	 Â Code	 Â includes	 Â a	 Â variety	 Â of	 Â standards	 Â that	 Â interact	 Â to	 Â implement	 Â resource	 Â

                                                                                                	 Â                   3.	 Â 	 Â RESOURCES	 Â 
	 Â 
Chapter	 Â 17.51,	 Â Resource	 Â Conservation,	 Â provides	 Â standards	 Â to	 Â assist	 Â new	 Â development	 Â in	 Â achieving	 Â the	 Â

SONOMA	 Â COUNTY	 Â ENERGY	 Â INDEPENDENCE	 Â PROGRAM	 Â 
Sonoma	 Â  County's	 Â  Energy	 Â  Independence	 Â  Program	 Â  is	 Â  a	 Â  new	 Â  opportunity	 Â  for	 Â  property	 Â  owners	 Â  to	 Â  finance	 Â 
energy	 Â  efficiency,	 Â  water	 Â  efficiency	 Â  and	 Â  renewable	 Â  energy	 Â  improvements	 Â  through	 Â  a	 Â  voluntary	 Â 
assessment.	 Â These	 Â assessments	 Â will	 Â be	 Â attached	 Â to	 Â the	 Â property,	 Â not	 Â the	 Â owner	 Â and	 Â will	 Â be	 Â paid	 Â back	 Â 
through	 Â  the	 Â  property	 Â  tax	 Â  system	 Â  over	 Â  time,	 Â  making	 Â  the	 Â  program	 Â  not	 Â  only	 Â  energy	 Â  efficient	 Â  but	 Â  also	 Â 
affordable.	 Â Program	 Â specifics	 Â include:	 Â 
          â€¢     Participation	 Â in	 Â this	 Â Sonoma	 Â County	 Â program	 Â is	 Â completely	 Â voluntary.	 Â 	 Â 
          â€¢     Energy	 Â  efficiency,	 Â  water	 Â  conservation	 Â  and	 Â  renewable	 Â  energy	 Â  generation	 Â  upgrades	 Â  must	 Â  be	 Â

                dishwashers	 Â  and	 Â  other	 Â  appliances	 Â  are	 Â  not	 Â  allowed.	 Â  Improvements	 Â  like	 Â  insulation,	 Â  cool	 Â  roofing,	 Â

	 Â 
       heating	 Â  and	 Â  air	 Â  conditioning	 Â  systems,	 Â  waterless	 Â  urinals,	 Â  solar	 Â  panels	 Â  and	 Â  energy	 Â  efficient	 Â

     â€¢ Improvements	 Â must	 Â be	 Â for	 Â existing	 Â buildings;	 Â new	 Â construction	 Â does	 Â not	 Â qualify.	 Â 	 Â 
     â€¢ Assessments	 Â are	 Â a	 Â lien	 Â on	 Â the	 Â property	 Â itself:	 Â when	 Â the	 Â property	 Â is	 Â sold,	 Â the	 Â assessment	 Â stays	 Â

The	 Â 2012	 Â Housing	 Â Element	 Â program	 Â strategy	 Â focused	 Â on	 Â achieving	 Â an	 Â adequate	 Â supply	 Â of	 Â safe,	 Â decent	 Â

appropriate.	 Â  	 Â  As	 Â  discussed	 Â  in	 Â  Table	 Â  4-Â­â€2,	 Â  many	 Â  housing	 Â  programs	 Â  continue	 Â  to	 Â  be	 Â  appropriate	 Â  and	 Â  the	 Â

housing	 Â needs,	 Â constraints,	 Â or	 Â other	 Â concerns	 Â identified	 Â as	 Â part	 Â of	 Â this	 Â update.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
The	 Â policies	 Â and	 Â programs	 Â of	 Â the	 Â 2012	 Â Housing	 Â Element	 Â that	 Â were	 Â developed	 Â to	 Â modify	 Â the	 Â Cityâ€™s	 Â Land	 Â 
Use	 Â  Code	 Â  are	 Â  being	 Â  implemented	 Â  and	 Â  will	 Â  be	 Â  adopted	 Â  concurrently	 Â  or	 Â  before	 Â  the	 Â  completion	 Â  of	 Â  this	 Â 
Housing	 Â  Element	 Â  Update.	 Â  	 Â  These	 Â  programs	 Â  will	 Â  be	 Â  removed	 Â  from	 Â  the	 Â  Housing	 Â  Element	 Â  as	 Â  they	 Â  are	 Â  no	 Â 
longer	 Â  necessary.	 Â  	 Â  The	 Â  City	 Â  has	 Â  experienced	 Â  further	 Â  reductions	 Â  in	 Â  staffing	 Â  and	 Â  budget	 Â  since	 Â  the	 Â  2012	 Â 
Housing	 Â Element,	 Â so	 Â programs	 Â that	 Â are	 Â not	 Â feasible	 Â to	 Â implement	 Â due	 Â to	 Â staff	 Â or	 Â funding	 Â constraints	 Â will	 Â 
be	 Â  identified.	 Â  	 Â  In	 Â  some	 Â  cases,	 Â  it	 Â  is	 Â  appropriate	 Â  to	 Â  maintain	 Â  these	 Â  programs	 Â  in	 Â  the	 Â  event	 Â  that	 Â  staff	 Â  and	 Â 
funding	 Â levels	 Â increase.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
This	 Â  update	 Â  to	 Â  the	 Â  Housing	 Â  Element	 Â  will	 Â  revise	 Â  existing	 Â  programs	 Â  and	 Â  include	 Â  new	 Â  programs,	 Â  where	 Â

addressed,	 Â and	 Â that	 Â constraints	 Â to	 Â housing	 Â are	 Â removed,	 Â to	 Â the	 Â extent	 Â feasible.	 Â

HOUSING	 Â WORKSHOP	 Â 
The	 Â  City	 Â  conducted	 Â  an	 Â  additional	 Â  housing	 Â  workshop	 Â  on	 Â  April	 Â  15,	 Â  2015	 Â  to	 Â  solicit	 Â  additional	 Â  public	 Â

needs	 Â and	 Â priorities:	 Â 
         â€¢      Seek	 Â methods	 Â to	 Â reduce	 Â permit	 Â fees	 Â for	 Â affordable	 Â housing	 Â development.	 Â 
         â€¢      Coordinate	 Â  with	 Â  housing	 Â  developers	 Â  to	 Â  seek	 Â  creative	 Â  and	 Â  collaborative	 Â  solutions	 Â  to	 Â 
                facilitate	 Â  the	 Â  construction	 Â  of	 Â  affordable	 Â  housing.	 Â  	 Â  Examples	 Â  may	 Â  include	 Â  allowing	 Â 
                housing	 Â  providers	 Â  to	 Â  construction	 Â  affordable	 Â  units	 Â  on	 Â  developer-Â­â€owned	 Â  lands	 Â  and	 Â  make	 Â 
                deferred	 Â  payments	 Â  on	 Â  the	 Â  land	 Â  acquisitions	 Â  costs	 Â  after	 Â  the	 Â  units	 Â  are	 Â  completed	 Â  and	 Â 
                sold.	 Â 	 Â 	 Â 
         â€¢      Provide	 Â mechanisms	 Â to	 Â encourage	 Â and	 Â facilitate	 Â transitional	 Â housing.	 Â 
         â€¢      Emphasize	 Â  services	 Â  and	 Â  resources	 Â  to	 Â  extremely	 Â  low	 Â  and	 Â  very	 Â  low	 Â  income	 Â  groups	 Â  to	 Â
